subject: Jackie's DC Dashboard for the week of February 10-16, 2020

As I said on the House floor, I am an equal to every one of my male colleagues in Congress until I walk out the door and down the steps of the Capitol. Then I am relegated to second-class status because women are not recognized in the Constitution as fully equal to men under the law. Thursday’s vote on H.J.Res.79, my resolution to facilitate ratification of the ERA, was a vote for equality, the American dream, and that more perfect union. I am proud of House Democrats, and five of our Republican colleagues, who joined me in championing the fight for women’s rights and greater equality. House Democrats also continued our work to protect our environment and natural spaces with a sweeping wilderness protection bill, and we voted to establish the first museum in the United States dedicated to the celebration and recognition of women’s history. We also turned the spotlight on threats to our nation with the Military Personnel Committee hearing that I chaired and that focused on the rise of white supremacy in our military, the House Armed Services Committee hearing on the malign actions of foreign adversaries including Russia and China, and my work to expose and eradicate the corrosive effects of sexual assault on our brave servicemembers – which threatens unit cohesion and military readiness. I was proud to introduce a resolution with Congressman Jim McGovern (D-MA) to establish an international anti-corruption court to address the impact that corruption has on human rights worldwide and the challenge of holding kleptocrats accountable for their crimes, and much more as you will read below. I am looking forward to being home in the 14th District this coming week. Then it’s back to Washington, DC the week of February 24th, and a return of Jackie’s DC Dashboard, so be sure to keep an eye out for the next update.                   As a Member of Congress, it is my honor and privilege to share information with my constituents in California's 14th District. If you would like to receive more information from my office, please sign up for my online newsletter by clicking the signup button above. You can also remove yourself from the email list at any time by selecting the unsubscribe option at the bottom of this page.           Legislative Highlights Passed My Bill to Facilitate Ratification of the Equal Rights Amendment  When Congress passed the ERA in 1972, it attached an arbitrary seven-year ratification deadline to the preamble which was later extended three more years. By 1982, 35 states out of the required 38 states voted to ratify the amendment. In the past three years, grassroots campaigns have successfully secured the final ratification votes in Nevada, Illinois, and most recently, Virginia. Unfortunately, the Department of Justice (DOJ) Office of Legal Counsel recently put out a legal opinion that the current ERA push is dead and that Congress lacks the authority to revive it. The Archivist, who is responsible for certifying amendments to the Constitution once ratified by three-fourths of the states, has decided to follow DOJ’s guidance even though Article V makes clear the Executive has no role in the Constitutional amendment process. Our vote to eliminate the arbitrary deadline brings us closer to placing this important guarantee of women’s equality in our founding document. It is now up to the Senate to follow suit and vote on companion legislation by Senators Murkowski and Cardin, and the Archivist to move forward with certifying the ERA.  Voted for Sweeping Wilderness Bill This week, the House took a major step toward protecting our public lands by voting to designate almost 1.4 million acres of land as wilderness and adding 1,000 river miles to the National Wild and Scenic River Systems. H.R. 2546, the Protecting America’s Wilderness Act, would preserve natural spaces in California, Colorado, and Washington for generations to come by protecting them from logging, mining, drilling, and new construction. It would also improve recreational access for underserved communities, safeguard ancestral homelands and tribal access, and boost local economies. Despite the bipartisan House vote, the Senate Majority Mitch McConnell is likely to relegate this critically-needed bill to his legislative graveyard. President Trump has also threatened to veto this legislation if it reaches his desk. But this fight is far from over. Our public lands are our most important natural heritage and an important tool in the fight against climate change. House Democrats will continue to push for wilderness and environmental protections as Americans across the continue to demand action this election year. Voted to Create a Smithsonian Women’s History Museum On Tuesday, House Democrats passed H.R. 1980, the Smithsonian Women’s History Museum Act. This bipartisan legislation would establish a Smithsonian museum dedicated to women’s history on the National Mall. Currently, we do not have a comprehensive museum in America documenting women’s history. Without it, women’s contributions to the nation are too often forgotten and could be lost as distant and forgotten memories. The stories of women in this country are too integral to our history to push aside. I was proud to vote for this historic legislation and urge my colleagues in the Senate to quickly pass it so that we can get to work building this museum!    Where’s Jackie? Chaired MILPERS Hearing on White Supremacists in the Military  There are several warning signs that these efforts have found success. Recent high-profile examples include a Marine attending the 2017 Charlottesville rally, a Coast Guard officer arrested with a cache of weapons, and a West Point graduate espousing hate on social media. It seems that the military is not only not taking this threat seriously enough, it also lacks the tools it needs and has failed to dedicate sufficient resources to fighting this threat. At the hearing, we discussed necessary improvements to the accessions process, how we investigate and punish white supremacist activity in the forces, and how we report and track these individuals after they have been expelled from the military. I look forward to an update from military leadership soon on the progress that they will make in focusing on this issue with the seriousness and commitment that it demands. You can watch the hearing here.  House Armed Services Committee Hearing on Threats Posed by Russia and China This week, I attended the House Armed Services Committee hearing on the Defense Department’s role in our national efforts to address the threats and challenges posed by Russia and China—two formidable countries that do not share our values. The DoD is focused on ensuring that the United States is ready to compete with those countries militarily, but at the hearing we discussed the importance of addressing less traditional acts of aggression, such as propaganda operations, cyber-attacks, and predatory economic practices. Countering these threats will require a comprehensive strategy across our government, executed in partnership with our allies.  Spoke on a Panel about Military Sexual Assault  On Wednesday night, I attended Heroine, a one-woman show about a female soldier performed at the beautiful Kennedy Center. The play, which is based on a real story, describes a woman’s struggle with addiction, depression, and suicide after being raped by soldiers in her unit. I was deeply impressed by how the performance conveyed the horror of military sexual assault and lasting pains with which survivors must wrestle. After the play, I sat on a panel with military justice experts to discuss our ongoing efforts to address this issue. As the Chair of the Military Personnel Subcommittee, I have made eradicating military sexual violence a top priority because our military cannot succeed while battling this scourge within its ranks.     Meetings with Jackie Meeting with Local Veterans Affairs Department Union On Wednesday, I met with leaders of AFGE Local 2110, the union that represents workers at our local VA hospital and clinic. We discussed our ongoing efforts to improve VA locality pay to offset the high cost of living in our area and help the VA recruit and retain staff. The VA representatives also shared the way that the Trump Administration’s anti-union actions have constrained their ability to operate. I remain committed to helping AFGE as it fights for its members to receive a living wage and fair representation.  Met with Northern California Special Olympics Delegation  Met with the Golden Gate Bridge Highway and Transportation District On Wednesday I met with representatives of the Golden Gate Bridge Highway and Transportation District (GGBHTD) to discuss opportunities for supporting San Francisco’s infrastructure needs. The District shared their plans for upcoming federal grant opportunities, and I look forward to lending my support to their work. We discussed the District’s concerns around the lack of federal funding to California for critical infrastructure needs, such as seismic retrofitting of the Golden Gate Bridge and expansion of the ferry boat system. I share many of their concerns, especially given President Trump’s vindictive attitude toward California.  The GGBHTD also provided updates on important projects and policies such as drone restrictions over the bridge, construction of the suicide net, and new safety measures for the bridge. The Golden Gate Bridge is an icon of the Bay Area as well as a vital piece of infrastructure for the region. I remain committed to supporting GGBHT and the needs of all Bay Area residents.    Voices of California’s 14th District  Here are some issues raised this week:   99 constituents expressed support for H.R. 230, the Ban Toxic Pesticides Act of 2019. I am a cosponsor of this crucial piece of legislation that would ban the use of the pesticide chlorpyrifos and prohibit any future registration of the pesticide. Please know that I will always fight to protect public health and safety, and ensure that our water, produce, and environment is safe from toxic chemicals. 87 constituents expressed concern with fracking.  Like you, I am deeply concerned about the effect of fracking on water sources. I take regulation of hydraulic fracturing seriously and will fight to protect the health and safety of all Americans. I am also deeply committed to supporting clean technology innovation, including solar, wind, hydropower, geothermal, advanced biofuels, and other renewable energy sources 27 constituents expressed support for our public lands. Our landscapes and national parks are treasures that must be preserved for future generations. I am proud to have been named a "Friend of the National Parks," and I am committed to conserving our natural heritage. name: Congressman H. Morgan Griffith
subject: No Road Back for the ERA
body: No Road Back for the ERA There are few things from 1972 that you could just pick up and dust off for use today. Clothes would be out of fashion if they even fit, cars would need plenty of maintenance and care to be driven, and disco music had not even made its way onto the music charts. The Equal Rights Amendment (ERA) passed Congress in that year! It proposes a solution to a problem that existed prior to 1972 and was being resolved with good legislation at the federal and state levels. For an amendment to pass, the United States Constitution requires the approval of two-thirds of both the House of Representatives and the Senate, followed by ratification in three-fourths of the states. It is not supposed to be an easy process, and only 27 amendments have been added since the Constitutions adoption. The ERA included a seven-year deadline for ratification. By the time it arrived in 1979, 31 states had ratified the ERA. Four others had ratified it but rescinded their ratifications by the deadline. By no measure had the required 38 states ratified the ERA. Congress then passed an extension to 1982, although the extension only passed by a simple majority rather than the two-thirds vote required for constitutional amendments, rendering the extension legally very suspect. A federal district court in Idaho found the extension invalid in 1981. In any event, no more states ratified the ERA by the 1982 deadline. The Supreme Court that year declared a lawsuit about the extension moot because the amendment had failed. The House of Representatives in 1983 tried to pass a new Equal Rights Amendment, another concession that the ratification process begun in 1972 was dead, but that new ERA did not attain the required two-thirds vote. You dont have to go back almost four decades to find Supreme Court justices who think the ERA is dead. Liberal Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg, an ERA supporter, said on February 10, 2020, Id like it to start over, noting the controversy with states adopting it late and others rescinding it before ratification. Nevertheless, supporters of the ERA are plowing ahead. Virginias new Democrat majority in the General Assembly spent valuable legislative time on ratification, and the Democrat majority in the U.S. House of Representatives passed a resolution by simple majority to remove the deadline. ERA proponents cite the 27th Amendment, which prohibited congressional pay raises from taking effect before an election of representatives had intervened. This amendment was proposed as part of the original Bill of Rights in 1789 and only ratified in 1992, but unlike the ERA, it never had a deadline. Other amendments, such as the Eighteenth Amendment imposing Prohibition, did include a deadline but were ratified in time. In light of these facts, the recent activity regarding the ERA is little more than a sideshow. But what of Justice Ginsburgs suggestion that supporters of the amendment start over? The country is in a different place than it was in 1972, when the ERA passed Congress. It is certainly in a different place than it was in 1943, when the text was first introduced, or 1923, when the original ERA was proposed. I am sympathetic to those who advocated the amendment prior to 1972. In the 1960s, my mother sought a loan for our house on Broad Street in Salem. The house I grew up in was at risk of being lost. At the time, she was ineligible because she was a divorced woman. A divorced man earning the same would have had no problem. That was wrong. Fortunately, a sympathetic loan officer checked the box that she was widowed, thus making her eligible. By the 1970s, when she applied for a loan for a house on Main Street, that legal barrier had been eliminated by good legislation without the need for a constitutional amendment. In just a few years, the situation had changed and my mother was treated more fairly. ERA supporters overlook our ability to make progress, whether by specific legal changes, cultural shifts, or other means apart from the drastic step of amending the Constitution. Any injustices that exist today should be remedied by legislation. The ERA is a blunt instrument. Its very broadness could lead to applications that are far from promoting equality. For instance, some states that have included ERAs in their constitutions have been forced to support abortion. Courts could very well force the same outcome at the federal level. Legally, the ERA has been long dead, and it should not be resurrected. If you have questions, concerns, or comments, feel free to contact my office. You can call my Abingdon office at 276-525-1405, my Christiansburg office at 540-381-5671, or my Washington office at 202-225-3861. To reach my office via email, please visit

Every time I step on the House floor, I’m focused on legislation that will help our district - whether that’s lowering out of pocket health care costs or making sure every student gets a quality education. No matter what is happening in Washington, I won’t lose sight of the issues we face back home.  I was especially lucky to introduce Kathy Zeman to the House Agriculture Committee earlier this week. Kathy farms in Rice County and she came to Washington to testify in support of the Local Agricultural Markets Program which promotes farmers’ markets around the country.         Expanding Higher Ed Opportunities  On Tuesday, I spoke with Minnesota State about how we can expand higher ed opportunities for our students. If education isn’t affordable, it’s not accessible.         Improving Rural Health CareRight now, there are insufficient health care resources in our rural communities. Wednesday, I met with folks from the Minnesota Department of Health to talk about the unique healthcare challenges facing rural patients and providers.       Advocating for Minnesota River Funding This week, I sat down with the Assistant Secretary of the Army for Civil Works, and the Waterways Council to discuss the importance of the Minnesota River Dredging project in keeping the river fully operational. The river transports about 4 million tons annually, worth more than $362 Million in economic value.         Pushing for Ratification of the ERA: Equal rights for women should not have a deadline. In fact, it’s long past time. That’s why I voted to remove the deadline for the ratification of the equal rights amendment on Thursday.  Protecting Medicare, Medicaid, and Social SecurityThe President’s budget proposes cuts to Medicare, Medicaid, and Social Security. I’ll never stand for that. Watch my video about these cuts here.   Supporting the Special OlympicsThis week was Special Olympics Hill Day! It was great meeting with our Minnesota delegation about empowering folks with different abilities.       Meeting Rescue PuppiesThursday, I stopped by the ASPCA Paws for Love pet adoption event to give out some belly rubs.         Funding Recreational TrailsThis week, I introduced the Recreational Trails Full Funding Act of 2020 with Rep. Welch to make sure folks have quality trails to enjoy Minnesota’s four seasons for hiking, cross country skiing and taking their ATV’s out. Not only will this bill invest in these opportunities right now, but it also makes sure future generations of Minnesotans and visitors can experience the beauty of the Minnesota River Valley and our well-traveled trails from Zumbrota to Cottage Grove.   Upcoming Event:Excited to announce my February town hall! I hope you can join me on Feb. 19th in Savage          Sincerely,   Angie CraigMember of Congress           Washington, DC Office 1523 Longworth House Office Building Washington, DC Phone: (202) 225-2271   Burnsville, MN Office 12940 Harriet Avenue South Suite 238 Burnsville, MN Phone: (651) 846-2120         Open in browser window        Open plain text version    Unsubscribe

It was a very eventful week and I'm excited to tell you about what we accomplished. Here are some highlights:   I was the Grand Marshall for the Ninth Annual Historic North Turn Legends Beach Parade I toured the Indian River Lagoon to see living shorelines and learn more about preserving our environment I attended the signing of the Supporting Veterans in STEM Careers Act by President Trump at the White House I spoke on the House floor in recognition of Dr. Mary McLeod Bethune and her contributions to our community and country  CELEBRATING OUR RACING HISTORY: This weekend I had the honor of serving as the Grand Marshall of this year’s Historic North Turn Legends Beach Parade! Since the 1920s, Daytona Beach has been the home of NASCAR, with drivers setting records racing down our beach to the famous North Turn and A1A. This race is an important part of our community’s history and it’s always one of my favorite events every year!    Serving as Grand Marshall at the 9th annual Historic North Turn Legends Beach Parade  CONSERVING OUR SHORELINE: Our beautiful and natural shorelines can co-exist with development when done correctly. Living shorelines and mangroves are important for our communities because they are the best natural barriers against storm surges. Estuaries and mangroves are also important to commercial fisherman. Around 80 percent of them rely on estuaries and mangroves for spawning. I enjoyed touring our local living shorelines to learn more about how conservancies bring free market, volunteering and community based solutions to our community. It's important we maintain our living shorelines to help keep Florida resilient.     Views of our Indian River Lagoon living shoreline  SUPPORTING OUR VETERANS: This week, I went to the White House to see President Trump sign another bill supporting our veterans into law — and this time, it was a bill I co-sponsored! The Supporting Veterans in STEM Careers Act supports our veterans, helping them find opportunities for jobs in STEM fields when they return to civilian life. I was glad to work on this bill with two fellow Florida congressmen, Senator Marco Rubio and Congressman Neal Dunn, and I was proud to be there as the President signed it into law!    President Trump signing the Supporting Veterans in STEM Careers Act into law RECOGNIZING SERVANT LEADERSHIP: I can't think of anyone better to highlight great servant leadership in our community and our country this Black History Month than our district's very own Dr. Mary McLeod Bethune. Bethune founded and was President of the all African-American girls school in Daytona Beach, which later became Bethune–Cookman University. Bethune selflessly dedicated herself to fighting for the equality and civil rights of all Americans through education and because of her, Florida and America are a better place.  Click below to watch me honor Dr. Bethune on the House floor:    Please follow my daily work on social media by liking my Facebook page and following me on Twitter, YouTube and Instagram. As always, feel free to reach out to my offices in Florida or Washington, D.C. if my team or I can ever be of service. Safe travels back to the Natural State! The House convened and voted on a series of bills, including the Homeland Security for Children Act (), the DHS Acquisition Reform Act of 2019 (), the providing for consideration of the bill (H.R. 2546) to designate certain lands in the State of Colorado as components of the National Wilderness Preservation System, and for other purposes; providing for consideration of the joint resolution () removing the deadline for the ratification of the equal rights amendment; and for other purposes. (), the Smithsonian Women's History Museum Act (), the Protecting America’s Wilderness Act (), and the removing the deadline for the ratification of the equal rights amendment (). Budget season has officially begun. Earlier this week, I received the President’s budget request for Fiscal Year 2021. While Congress holds the Article I powers of the Constitution, or the “power of the purse,” the President’s budget outlines his vision for the nation. The release of the President’s budget request historically kicks off the congressional budget process in both the House and the Senate. It serves as a starting point for lawmakers to make spending decisions and analyze the economic outlook for the coming year. The framework of the budget process can be divided up into :   President submits the budget to Congress House and Senate mark up and pass budget House and Senate conference the budget resolution Consideration and passage of Appropriations bills Consideration of reconciliation/authorization Start of new Fiscal Year (October 1st)   I applaud President Trump for putting forward a budget proposal. That’s more than we can say for the People’s House, where, for the second straight year, the Democrat majority has failed to produce a budget. That’s not leadership.  This is interesting to me because, on the House Budget Committee majority’s website, there is a section titled “Responsibility.” The first sentence in this section reads, “The Committee’s chief responsibility is to draft an annual concurrent resolution on the budget that provides a congressional framework for spending and revenue levels, the federal surplus or deficit, and public debt.”  In every business, in every city, in every state, a budget is done. Yet, here in the House, in the greatest country in the world, we’re not doing a budget. Simply put, a failure to budget is a failure to govern.  We must start doing our job to put our country on a sustainable, responsible fiscal path. This is our duty to the American people, not promoting budget-busting policies, including Medicare-for-All and the Green New Deal, that will leave future generations saddled with the consequences of House Democrats’ eagerness to spend with no way to pay. It’s time for Democrats to stop punting one of our most basic responsibilities in Congress. I’m ready for them to join us at the table to do the difficult work.  While we can’t analyze the Democrats’ budget – because they won’t put one forth – the House Budget Committee did hold a hearing on the President’s FY 2021 budget proposal with OMB Acting Director Russell Vought. As we discussed, the proposal seeks to balance our fiscal constraints with the need to fund the priorities of the country, including national defense. The President’s budget includes deficit reduction measures, specifically $4.6 trillion between 2021-2030. This is a strong start, but more work remains to be done to put our country on a solid fiscal path. Moving forward, it is imperative that we work together in a bipartisan, bicameral fashion to advance a budget that funds our nation’s important priorities while acknowledging our very real fiscal challenges. You can read my full opening remarks .  MEETINGS  In between votes and legislative business, I also had the opportunity to meet with organizations from the Natural State! It was a pleasure to meet with Keturah Finch and Tanner Arnwine of Bentonville to talk about neurofibromatosis (NF), a genetic, tumor-generating disorder. We discussed research through the Congressionally Directed Medical Research Program (CDMRP) and the National Institutes of Health, as well as its value to civilians, warfighters, and veterans suffering from NF. Novel research has led to a new era of medical breakthroughs for a variety of illnesses, but there is still much more work to be done across many fields. We must continue to make smart investments that build our pipeline of science, research, and medical discovery. The next morning, I invited my Republican House Budget Committee colleagues to join me at the Office of Budget and Management to hear more about the President’s recently released budget proposal, as well as fiscal priorities of the White House. As I mentioned earlier, I appreciate the Administration for drafting a budget. Congress should be doing the same thing, but House Democrats have refused to put forth a proposal yet again. In the real world, everyday Americans and Arkansans are held accountable for their income, expenses, and savings. Main Street job creators and business leaders are held accountable for demonstrating fiscal restraint, for making tough choices, and for setting priorities. Congress should not be any different. But in the House, Democrats are refusing to put forth the very document that tells us what we need to know about how much we’re spending, what we’re raising in revenue, and the impact of our deficits and debt on our economy and the nation. The American people deserve better.  Representatives from NorthWest Arkansas Community College (NWACC) were in Washington, and I had the opportunity to hear some important school and curriculum updates. We talked about enhancing Career and Technical Education (CTE), the Fostering Undergraduate Talent by Unlocking Resources for Education (FUTURE) Act – which I voted for – and the National Science Foundation’s Advanced Technological Education (ATE) program. NWACC just received an ATE grant for a project that will create a Technical Certificate in Integrated Design to help expand the skilled technical workforce, especially in construction fields and engineering design. NWACC is helping prepare our students for the jobs of today and the future, and I appreciate their dedication to providing quality education and opportunities in the Third District. I thank Dr. Evelyn Jorgenson, Dr. Ricky Tompkins, Jim Hall, Rachel Harris, and DeAnne Witherspoon for their time and work!  I then met with the Arkansas Fraternal Order of Police. I always appreciate meeting with our law enforcement officers and hearing more about their work to protect and serve our communities. We discussed many issues, including The Protect and Serve Act (HR 1325). I’m a cosponsor of this legislation, which creates new federal penalties for individuals who deliberately attack or attempt to cause significant bodily injury to any law enforcement officer. This bill aims to deter attacks against police officers who have increasingly been targeted and face higher levels of hostility because of the uniform they wear. I’m extremely thankful for the work of the men and women who wear the badge each day!  My next meeting was with the Enlisted Association of the Arkansas National Guard. It was wonderful to sit down with Arkansas National Guard members from Fort Smith and other parts of the state to talk about their work, duties, and programs that support their efforts. We also had a productive discussion on the National Guard’s role going forward in the Space and Cyber domains. The Arkansas Air National Guard has both Space and Cyber missions. As a 30-year veteran of the Arkansas Army National Guard, I salute their service and thank them for their commitment to the Natural State and our nation! I then welcomed Dr. John Lorsch, Director of the National Institute of General Medical Sciences, to my office to speak about the Institutional Development Award (IDea) program and its impact on Arkansas. Our conversations focused on the NIH’s research and biomedical investments within the Natural State.  I wrapped up the day at the National Guard Association, where I joined National Guard members from across the country to talk about defense efforts, legislative advocacy, and my work on the House Budget Committee. I shared stories about my time in uniform, as well as my perspectives on appropriations work in Congress. I talked about the constrained resource environment we face, and how growing mandatory spending is squeezing the portion of discretionary funding available for national priorities. The Guard brings great value to the fight, and it was my honor to talk to this great group and answer questions.  The next morning, I met with Dan Hendrix, President and CEO of the World Trade Center Arkansas. I appreciated an update on their work, economic development in the community, small business grants, and the impact of recent trade deals on the state. Arkansas is a state of opportunity, and the World Trade Center Arkansas is a pivotal resource that has supported bilateral trade services, global connections, and export development programs for local businesses.  Our region is full of opportunity, and it was great to speak with students from the Future Leaders Exchange (FLEX) program. FLEX students spend an academic year in the U.S. living with a volunteer host family and attending high school. The students, who are from Kazakhstan and Kyrgyzstan, are currently living and going to school in Russellville and Springdale! They said that they have learned a lot during their time living and studying in the region – and that they love the sense of community in Arkansas!    Modernized infrastructure is vital to keeping our communities economically competitive and strong. It was great to wrap up my week in Washington with Department of Transportation Secretary Elaine Chao. We had very productive conversations on rural infrastructure grants, local projects like I-49 and regional airport improvements, and budget and appropriations. We also highlighted the importance of addressing U.S. infrastructure needs using smart and effective methods that provide results and maximize our resources. Today, I also want to wish everyone – especially my wonderful wife, Terri – a Happy Valentine’s Day! I'm grateful that my office was able to present some special valentines to residents at Methodist Village Senior Living in Fort Smith. Spreading some cheer and happiness is what this day is all about! I’m looking forward to being back in the district and traveling the Natural State next week. Wishing everyone a Happy Presidents’ Day on Monday! Let us reflect and honor the leaders who've held our nation's highest office to serve the American people. By swearing an oath to “preserve, protect and defend the Constitution of the United States,” they each answered the call to lead our great country throughout history. From George Washington to Donald Trump, Happy Presidents' Day to all our leaders – past and present!  Remember to keep an eye on my  or check out my Twitter and Instagram pages to stay up-to-date with the latest news from the Third District and Washington.     From the front...
