Because of their immense sacrifices, we enjoy liberty and freedom. As a Member of Congress, I strive every day to honor their commitment to the United States by ensuring the health and well-being of the more than 25,000 veterans in our Congressional District and the more than 19 million veterans across our country.  I’m proud to have voted for the 24 bipartisan bills the House passed this year to strengthen care for our veterans. It’s our collective responsibility to ensure that every American who wears a uniform to defend our country will have the services, opportunities, and care they’ve earned. Our legislation addresses the full spectrum of the needs of veterans: veteran suicide prevention; military to civilian transition assistance; resources to end veteran homelessness; increasing VA accessibility; and improved health care for veterans. I’m also very proud to have helped launch the Women Veterans Task Force to ensure that the more than 2 million women veterans have the access to health care, benefits, and resources they’ve earned.  This year, I’m especially proud to have made strides to secure housing for veterans and their families. I cosponsored and passed the Homeless Veterans Families Act, legislation to increase funding to help homeless veterans with children have a safe place to live, and I was thrilled to dedicate the opening of the second Fisher House at the Palo Alto VA. The Fisher House program is a unique private-public partnership that supports America's military by providing "homes away from home" built on the grounds of major military and VA medical centers. I’ve fought for funding for a second Fisher House for over a decade, and I’m pleased the families of veterans are now benefiting from the new house that provides lodging for an additional 20 families of veterans and military at no cost, allowing them to be close to their loved ones as they receive treatment at the Palo Alto VA. The Fisher Houses are beautiful in every way and are a comfort to our veterans’ families during incredibly stressful periods. Service members and their families will save more than $3.387 million a year because of the Palo Alto VA Fisher Houses.   We owe so much to our service members and veterans, and I hope you’ll take a moment today to bow your head and quietly give thanks to our great patriots for their service and love of country. Warm regards,   Anna G. name: Senator Cory Gardner
subject: A message from Senator Cory Gardner
body: /* Client-specific Styles */ body { width: 100% !important; margin: 0px;} .ReadMsgBody { width: 100%; } .ExternalClass { width: 100%; display:block !important; } /* Force Hotmail to display emails at full width */ /* Reset Styles */ body { margin:0; padding: 0; } img { outline: none; text-decoration: none; max-width :100%;} br, strong br, b br, em br, i br { line-height: 100%; } h1, h2, h3, h4, h5, h6 { line-height: 100% !important; -webkit-font-smoothing: antialiased; } table td, table tr { border-collapse: collapse; } p { margin-bottom: 1em; } table.menu-change a { text-decoration:none; } /* pre-header */ .preheader { display:none !important; visibility:hidden; mso-hide:all !important; font-size:0px; color:#ffffff; line-height:0px; max-height:0px; max-width:0px; opacity:0; overflow:hidden; }     p { margin-bottom:1em; }                            Home  Press Releases                Dear Friend,  Happy Veterans Day Weekend      Click here or the picture above to view a Veterans Day message from Senator Gardner.    To all of the men and women in Colorado and across our country who have ever donned a uniform for the United States military, thank you for your service. Thank you for all you do to make our country’s freedoms and opportunities possible. We must honor the immeasurable debt we owe to past and present military members for their dedicated service by ensuring there are tools and support available to navigate civilian life.    Earlier this year I announced my VA Readiness Initiative, a comprehensive package of legislative items to ensure the Department of Veterans Affairs (VA) is always ready to deliver excellent care to veterans. This initiative includes measures to expand access to services, encourage innovation for veteran healthcare solutions, increase accountability at the VA, and empower transitioning service members as they pursue civilian careers.  Happy Veterans Day weekend, may God continue to bless you and the United States of America.  Fighting for Colorado Military Funding For the second time in two months, partisan politics has prevented the U.S. Senate from moving forward on vital funding for the U.S. military. The Centennial State’s six military bases and critical military commands such as the newly formed U.S. Space Command at Peterson Air Force Base rely on this funding, and face an uncertain future because of Washington gridlock. Altogether, the Senate defense appropriations bill contains roughly $344 million to support military priorities important to Colorado.  Read my latest op-ed in the Colorado Springs Gazette, calling on all of my Senate colleagues to come to the table and provide the vital military resources that impact our national security and the lives of Colorado military families. Colorado’s service members exemplify the best of our nation, and they deserve better from Washington.  Akron Med Evac Tour & Roundtable      The staff at Med Evac in Akron work around the clock to help Coloradans in need and save lives during emergencies. Thank you to the pilots, medics, and everyone involved for a great tour and discussion about the services they provide to Colorado residents and how I can support their efforts at the federal level. Thatcher and Caitlyn were really impressed! New U.S. Secretary of the Air Force Barbara Barrett    It was an honor to attend the swearing-in ceremony for the 25th Secretary of the U.S. Air Force, Barbara Barrett, in Colorado Springs. We were lucky to be joined by members of the Tuskegee Airmen, the famed group of African-American World War II military pilots. I’m grateful for their remarkable service to our nation.  Secretary Barrett’s new position is incredibly important to Colorado’s military installations and the future of U.S. Space Command in Colorado. With her strong background in aviation and government service, I have great confidence in her ability to serve as the new head of the U.S. Air Force and I wish her and her family well. Encouraging Investments in Every Corner of Colorado  Senator Gary Peters (D-MI) and I introduced bipartisan legislation to reform the approval process for charitable investments, so organizations can more easily invest in community improvement and job creation. Private charities are more than willing to invest in and grow the economy, but are too often deterred by government bureaucracy. The Philanthropic Facilitation Act (PFA) benefits rural economies in particular by cutting red tape and removing barriers between philanthropists and small businesses, ultimately leading to more job creation. This legislation is a common-sense solution that gets government out of the way and encourages more investments across Colorado where it is needed most. Fighting the Rise of Meth in Colorado  Click here or the picture above to view Senator Gardner’s remarks.    I successfully included a bipartisan amendment to increase funding for an anti-meth program in the domestic spending appropriations package passed by the Senate. In between 2011 and 2018, Colorado has experienced a nearly 40 percent increase in admissions for meth addiction. We have to provide new tools and resources to deal with the dangers caused by methamphetamines in our communities. My amendment increases funding for the COPS Anti-Methamphetamine Program to help state law enforcement agencies fight the rise of meth. Pushing for Full LWCF Funding Senator Michael Bennet and I introduced a bipartisan amendment to fully fund the Land and Water Conservation Fund, the crown jewel of conservation programs for Colorado. This conservation program comes at no cost to the taxpayer, but has only been funded to its maximum authorization level twice in its history. We were successful in permanently reauthorizing the LWCF earlier this year, and the next step is to make funding automatic. Colorado’s beautiful public lands rely on this critical conservation program, and it’s time for Congress to fully and permanently fund it.  The Ski Area Fee Retention Act Moves Forward  Click here or the picture above to view Senator Gardner’s remarks.    My bipartisan Ski Area Fee Retention Act gained traction with a recent hearing in the Senate Committee on Energy and Natural Resources. I was fortunate to introduce Brendan McGuire, Vice President of Public Affiars at Vail Resorts Management Company, as he testified that this bill would give ski areas in Colorado an important tool to invest in development projects. The Ski Area Fee Retention Act would help local ski areas keep more of the fees they produce, which will lead to increased local investments and improvements. I’ll continue working to see this important legislation for Colorado ski areas signed into law. Colorado Priorities Pass the Senate I’m proud to have secured funding for a number of Colorado priorities in the domestic spending package passed by the U.S. Senate. This appropriations bill is important for rural Colorado, with full funding of the Payment in Lieu of Taxes (PILT) program and an increase of funding for the Land and Water Conservation Fund (LWCF) that will help ensure our beautiful public lands are preserved for future generations to enjoy. Click here to learn more about the Colorado priorities funded in the appropriations package, including a sizable increase for scientific research and the Manufacturing Extension Partnership.  Maintaining a Critical Relationship with South Korea      I was honored to be the first Member of Congress to meet with Lee Soo-hyuck, in his new capacity as the Ambassador of the Republic of Korea to the United States. The United States-Republic of Korea alliance is critical to U.S. economic and national security interests, and it is a lynchpin of peace and stability in the Indo-Pacific region. Our countries have worked together to promote international peace, security, economic prosperity, human rights, and the rule of law. The friendship between our two countries remains ironclad, and we will work together to make it even stronger. Tracking Chinese Intimidation of American Businesses Recently we’ve seen American companies censor themselves to avoid Chinese retaliation, which sends a chilling ripple effect across our country and further empowers the Chinese Communist Party. The first step to solving any problem is knowing its full extent, which is why Senator Jeff Merkley (D-OR) and I introduced bipartisan legislation to create a U.S. government taskforce to monitor instances of China intimidating U.S. companies that exercise free speech.  TAIPEI Act Passes Senate Unanimously The U.S. Senate unanimously passed the Taiwan Allies International Protection and Enhancement Initiative (TAIPEI) Act, which Senator Chris Coons (D-DE) and I authored. This bipartisan legislation is intended to strengthen Taiwan’s standing around the world and comes in response to increased Chinese pressure and bullying tactics intended to restrict Taiwan’s international space and global diplomatic recognition. The United States should use every tool to support Taiwan’s standing on the international stage, and I applaud the Senate for sending a strong message to nations that there will be consequences for supporting Chinese actions that undermine Taiwan. Need Help with a Federal Agency?  My staff is available to assist you with finding out the status of a case and requesting additional information from a federal agency. I have offices in Denver, Durango, Pueblo, Grand Junction, Fort Collins, Greeley, Yuma, and Colorado Springs. Click here!                                                Dear Cormack, Following a busy week meeting with folks across eastern Connecticut, here to provide you with some updates on my work as we head into Veterans Day Weekend:    An Important Update for our Blue Water Navy Vietnam Veterans  As we head in to this Veterans Day weekend, I’m looking forward to honoring all of our veterans at events across eastern Connecticut. Eastern Connecticut is home to so many of our nation’s veterans and active-duty service members, and it’s an honor to represent them in Congress. Today, ahead of Veterans Day, I announced the creation of a new resource page on my website to provide Blue Water Navy Vietnam veterans and their families with important information on how to apply for new resources being made available to Blue Water vets through the VA.   The new resources are being made available following Congress’s passage and the signing-into-law of the Blue Water Navy Vietnam Veterans Act (H.R. 299), a bill that I’ve fought for years to get across the finish line. The new law will take effect on January 1, and my resource page will help provide veterans and their families with more information on the bill, and on how to file or re-file a claim with the VA so that they can receive the benefits they deserve.  The debt we owe to our Blue Water Navy veterans for their service, and for the subsequent obstruction to their care, can never be repaid. However, the Blue Water Navy Vietnam Veterans Act will soon be the law of the land, and it will help ensure that we do right by them moving forward. I encourage all Blue Water veterans, their families, and anyone else interested in taking advantage of these powerful new benefits to visit the Blue Water Navy Vietnam Veterans Act resource page on my website, and to contact a Veterans Caseworker in my office so that we can make sure folks have the information they need to get the care they deserve.         Click here to visit my Blue Water Resource Page     Last Green Valley 25th Birthday   Last week, it as great to join friends, community members, local leaders, and the staff of Last Green Valley (LGV) at Allen Hill Farm in Brooklyn to celebrate 25 outstanding years of the LGV. There was no better way to celebrate LGV’s big milestone than with a walking tour of the beautiful valley we’ve all worked so hard to protect, and I’m grateful to Lois Bruinooge, Executive Director of LGV, and her team for inviting us all out to commemorate the occasion. Following last week’s announcement of over half a million dollars in federal funding for our region’s state parks and wildlife conservation areas – which included $94,250 to expand the Quinebaug River Wildlife Management Area within the Last Green Valley – there was plenty to celebrate. Click here to learn more about the recently announced federal grant awards that will help bolster the Last Green Valley, and other state parks and conservation areas in our region.   Thank you to the folks at Last Green Valley and Allen Hill Farm for hosting Saturday’s great event, and to everyone who joined us. I’m looking forward to another 25 great years!         Congressman Courtney at Allen Hill Farm last weekend celebrating 25 years of Last Green Valley     New Gap Financing Program for Homeowners with Crumbling Foundations  Last week, I joined Governor Lamont in announcing the launch of the Supplemental Collapsing Foundation Loan Program – a new statewide program for homeowners with crumbling foundations that will allow for folks who have received assistance from the Connecticut Foundation Solutions Indemnity Company (CFSIC) to receive a loan from participating banks in Connecticut to cover other repairs. The new program will help to cover the cost of repairs that CFSIC isn’t able to cover. For example, if a deck, patio, or plumbing system needed to be destroyed or altered in order to repair a home’s foundation, CFSIC could help cover the cost of the foundation repair, and this new program could help cover the cost of repairing the deck, patio, plumbing system, etc. Homeowners can repay a loan from this program through the federal property casualty loss deduction – for more information, visit my resource page online.   I’m working to find resources to respond to the crumbling foundations crisis at the local, state, and federal levels, and the new supplemental loan program is an important piece of the puzzle. However, one persisting gap in addressing the problem at every level has been a lack of reliable standards for evaluating what quantity of pyrrhotite must be present in concrete in order to pose a danger to a foundation’s structural integrity. The University of Connecticut and others have efforts underway to explore this missing element, but it’s clear that more research is needed to help affected homeowners and communities.  Earlier this year, the House passed a spending package for FY2020 that included my amendment to provide NIST – the leading federal expert in cement and concrete standards – with $4 million to conduct research on the crumbling foundations crisis, to develop a standard testing method for at-risk homes and other structures for the presence of pyrrhotite, and to create a risk-rating scale so that homeowners, small businesses, and local governments have a better understanding of what quantity of pyrrhotite poses a danger to their foundation’s structural integrity. The Senate’s spending bill included $1.5 million for NIST to conduct this research, and now – as the House and Senate are preparing to conference a final spending package – we’re pushing for the research to be funded at the full $4 million agreed to here in the House.          Click here to read the full letter to the House appropriators      Community Discussion on the Lower Prescription Drug Costs Now Act  On Wednesday, I hosted a panel discussion and community conversation at the Groton Senior Center to address the skyrocketing cost of prescription medication, and to highlight the work being done in Congress to give Americans a better deal on prescription drugs through bills like the Lower Drug Costs Now Act (H.R. 3).  I was joined by an impressive group of regional healthcare experts to discuss how out-of-control drug prices are impacting people and families of all ages and from all from all walks of life, and to talk about some of the ways in which H.R. 3 would give Americans a better deal on prescription medication. The Lower Drug Costs Now Act would change the law by finally allowing for Medicare to negotiate with pharmaceutical companies for fairer, lower drug prices -- the kind of prices they offer to other countries, but not to us. It would also charge drug manufacturers for a rebate if they increase the price of their drugs faster than inflation; it would create a $2,000 out-of-pocket limit on prescription drug costs for Medicare beneficiaries; and it would reinvest savings into research at the National Institutes of Health, and into improving Medicare.   The Lower Drug Costs Now Act has a chance to be the most significant legislation on health care that the 116th Congress will accomplish. Prescription drug prices are out of control, and I’m proud that the House majority has made this issue one of our top priorities this year. In just the past few weeks, H.R. 3 was introduced, hearings were held, and my committee moved to approve the bill so that it can come before the full House of Representatives for a final vote. I’m grateful to Nora Duncan, Laura Hoch, and Judy Stein for joining me in Groton to talk more about the importance of passing this bill, and I’m looking forward to pressing ahead so that we can get H.R. 3 across the finish line once and for all.         Congressman Courtney speaking at Groton Senior Center this week on the Lower Drug Costs Now Act     Touring the Newly Upgraded New England Central Rail  On Thursday morning, I was joined by officials from Genesee & Wyoming (G&W) and the Connecticut Department of Transportation (CTDOT) to tour the final upgrades of the New England Central Rail (NECR). These recently completed upgrades are an impressive sight, and they’ll provide firms and small businesses throughout our region with a real opportunity for economic success and growth.  Over the past decade, our region has come together to secure federal funding to make much-needed upgrades to the NECR – a rail line that’s about 100 years old, that until now hasn’t been able to move at high speeds or to tolerate heavier weights. In September 2014, my office helped secure an $8.3 million federal grant through the U.S. Department of Transportation to upgrade the NECR, which was the culmination of an effort that started five years earlier in 2009. In her article on the new upgrades and what they mean for our region’s economy, The Day’s Julia Bergman noted that the $8.3 million federal grant made up about 66% of the total project, while G&W covered the remainder.  The completed project is a great achievement, and it means great things for our region. These upgrades will improve our freight rail service, will help relieve congested highways by getting big trucks off the road and placing more of that cargo onto rail lines, and will open up new economic opportunities and frontiers for the many firms and small businesses here in eastern Connecticut who rely on the NECR to do business. We took a ride up the new rail line on Thursday, and it’s now smooth as silk – no joints, no delays, no ‘clackety-clack’ – just a smooth ride. The new and improved NECR will make a big difference for the economy of our region, and I was proud to help secure the federal TIGER grant that made it happen         Congressman Courtney touring the final upgrades of the New England Center Rail     Thank you, as always, for taking the time to read this update. Please do not hesitate to contact me if you have any questions or need assistance. Wishing everyone a happy, safe, and meaningful Veterans Day Weekend,  Have a great weekend,                                     Joe CourtneyMember of Congress                   OFFICE LOCATIONS        Washington, DC Office 2332 Rayburn HOBWashington, DC 20515Phone: (202) 225-2076Fax: (202) 225-4977 Norwich Office 55 Main Street, Suite 250Norwich, CT 06360Phone: (860) 886-0139Fax: (860) 886-2974 Enfield Office 77 Hazard Ave, Unit JEnfield, CT 06082Phone: (860) 741-6011Fax: (860) 741-6036           |            p { margin-bottom:1em; } /***** SMARTPHONE STYLING RULES *****/ @media only screen and (max-width: 497px) { body, td, div, span, p {font-size:40px !important;} a { text-decoration:none; } *[class*="container"] { width:100% !important; table-layout:auto !important;} *[class*="footer"] td { font-size: 12px !important;} *[class*="mobileimg"] { width: 300px !important;} *[class*="mobile-hidden"] { display:none !important; } *[class*="mobileshare"] img { width: 288 !important; height: 50 !important;} }

body: /* Client-specific Styles */ body { width: 100% !important; margin: 0px;} .ReadMsgBody { width: 100%; } .ExternalClass { width: 100%; display:block !important; } /* Force Hotmail to display emails at full width */ /* Reset Styles */ body { margin:0; padding: 0; } img { outline: none; text-decoration: none; max-width :100%;} br, strong br, b br, em br, i br { line-height: 100%; } h1, h2, h3, h4, h5, h6 { line-height: 100% !important; -webkit-font-smoothing: antialiased; } /*ly, tr#221562, add same margin as margin-block-start/end*/ h1{margin-top:0.67em;margin-bottom:0.67em;} h2{margin-top:0.83em;margin-bottom:0.83em;} h3{margin-top:1em;margin-bottom:1em;} h4{margin-top:1.33em;margin-bottom:1.33em;} h5{margin-top:1.67em;margin-bottom:1.67em;} h6{margin-top:2.33em;margin-bottom:2.33em;} table td, table tr { border-collapse: collapse; } p { margin-bottom: 1em; } table.menu-change a { text-decoration:none; } /* pre-header */ .preheader { display:none !important; visibility:hidden; mso-hide:all !important; font-size:0px; color:#ffffff; line-height:0px; max-height:0px; max-width:0px; opacity:0; overflow:hidden; }                                         Contact                                           Hello Friend, I wanted to update you on recent progress we’ve made in Congress to protect the integrity of our elections.  "The Russian government interfered in the 2016 presidential election in sweeping and systematic fashion." In the first paragraph, Special Counsel Robert Mueller's report succinctly sums up the stakes of why we must do more to safeguard our democracy from hostile foreign actors. A bipartisan Senate report released a few weeks ago backed up these findings and called on the executive branch to act before it was too late. The extensive interference in the 2016 election is shocking, and it is clear that 2020 will be no different and possibly even worse. Despite warnings from intelligence agencies and lawmakers on both sides of the aisle, I believe the administration has not yet taken any concrete steps to shore up our election security.   In fact, during a televised interview in June, the President stated that he may not alert the FBI if offered information on one of his 2020 rivals, and in September, thanks to the courage of a whistleblower, the nation learned about a phone call between the President and the President of Ukraine where the President said, "I would like you to do us a favor though because our country has been through a lot and Ukraine knows a lot about it." The call concerned congressionally-mandated security assistance to Ukraine that had been held up for several months. Since then, several witnesses from the State Department have come forward to share their concerns about how American foreign policy is being run.  On October 23, the House passed the Stopping Harmful Interference in Elections for a Lasting Democracy, or SHIELD, Act. I proudly voted for this bill that would require campaigns to report acts of foreign election interference, close loopholes allowing foreign nationals and governments from spending money to influence U.S. elections, and boost transparency in political advertising.   House Democrats have made election reform a priority since taking the majority. One of the first bills passed by the House this Congress was H.R. 1, the For the People Act, a bill I cosponsored aimed at getting money out of politics, cracking down on the influence of lobbyists and special interests, and expanding voting rights. Additionally, the House passed an appropriations bill earlier including $600 million for states to replace electronic-only voting machines with ones that include paper ballots. The Senate has not yet taken it up.  Are you concerned about foreign interference in the 2020 election?  Yes   No    If using Microsoft Outlook, click here.     *By participating in this survey you are subscribing to receive email updates from my office.  House Democrats will continue fighting for legislation that protects the integrity of our elections, and the impeachment inquiry that we launched a few weeks ago will continue working in conjunction with our committees to get the truth out to the American people.  Please know that I will continue to fight for our Constitution, and I will continue to support legislation that protects our elections.        Sincerely,Katherine ClarkMember of Congress (MA-05)                           Washington, DC Office 2448 Rayburn HOBWashington, DC 20515Phone: (202) 225-2836Hours: M-F 9-5:30pm District Office 157 Pleasant Street, Suite 4Malden, MA 02148Phone: (617) 354-0292Hours: M-F 9-5:30pm MetroWest Regional Office 116 Concord Street, Suite 1Framingham, MA 01702Phone: (508) 319-9757                        body,table tr,table td,a, span,table.MsoNormalTable { font-family: Arial, sans-serif; !important; } p {margin-bottom:1em;}

Here’s more about what I’ve been working on for you and what has been happening in our District:  Helping One Family Navigate the Federal Bureaucracy  The Farlow family had been struggling to secure adequate medical supplies for disabled brothers Nathan and Andrew since their grandmother switched from Medicaid to Medicare.  We finally secured a waiver for the family after I personally reached out to the Director of the Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services.  You can read more about it here.  If I can be of assistance to you or your family, please contact one of my district offices in Bel Air, Kent Island, or Salisbury.  Hosting Town Halls on the Eastern Shore    Responding to constituents at my Easton Town Hall  I had the opportunity to host three town halls on the Eastern Shore in early October.  The first was held at the Greensboro VFC Community Hall in Caroline County, the second at the Talbot County Free Library in Easton, and the third at Stephen Decatur High School in Worcester County.  We covered a wide variety of topics including: global warming, the impeachment inquiry, gun control, the Ocean City offshore wind project, the Turkey-Kurdish Conflict in Northern Syria, and more.  I look forward to hosting more town halls in the northern part of the district this fall and having you join me on one of our telephone town halls in the future.  To get added to the telephone town hall list, please call my DC office.  Saving the Bay One Oyster Shell at a Time  I joined Comptroller Franchot and local leaders at the Tidewater Inn in Easton to thank them for their participation in the Oyster Shell Recycling Tax Credit Program.  Businesses can take advantage of this program that helps to repopulate native oysters in the Bay.  More info can be found here.     I joined Comptroller Franchot, Senator Eckardt, and Delegate Mautz in thanking the Tidewater Inn for their participation in the Oyster Shell Tax Credit Program  Dorchester County Celebrates 350 Years  On September 22nd, we celebrated the 350th anniversary of the founding of Dorchester County.  I was glad to meet with local community leaders, discuss fisheries policy with local watermen, share the county's rich history, and greet the distinguished guest of the afternoon, Lt. Governor Boyd Rutherford.    Chatting with members of the Dorchester Seafood Heritage Association at the County's 350th Anniversary  Dedicating the Harriet Tubman Mural in Cambridge    Locals and dignitaries look on during the Harriet Tubman dedication event  The formal dedication for the Harriet Tubman mural was held in early September.  It is a stunning work of art that recognizes the resiliency of this amazing woman.  As an author of the legislation that created the Harriet Tubman Underground Railroad National Historical Park in Maryland, I am proud this mural has been added to our local memorials honoring Ms. Tubman.  Next time you’re on Route 50 coming across the Choptank, take 15 minutes to go downtown and admire this great rendition of a real Eastern Shore hero.  In Washington  Arguing for a Fair and Transparent Impeachment Inquiry  I remain very concerned by the way Congress is pursuing the impeachment inquiry into President Trump, held behind closed doors.  I believe that all hearings, depositions, and testimony should be made available to the public.  Here's a link to my comments on this topic from the floor of the House.  Honoring one of Maryland's Distinguished Leaders  On October 17th, Congressman Elijah Cummings (D-Maryland-07) passed away.  While Mr. Cummings and I worked together on issues of importance to Maryland (but agreed less frequently on other issues), he was a respected public servant who had a passion for serving his district and his constituents.  His body lay in state at the U.S. Capitol on October 24th.  My and Nicole's thoughts and prayers are with his family.     Thank you for your continued energy and enthusiasm, as reflected in your letters and Facebook posts. If you haven’t already, . You can also follow me on Twitter .   It is a pleasure to serve you in Congress!   Sincerely, Andy Harris, M.D.Member of Congress    Service Academy Nomination Deadline I am privileged to get to nominate outstanding young men and women for appointment to the nation's military academies.  My applications for a nomination are due November 15th, please see this link for more information or contact my Kent Island office.     Federal Dollars Awarded to the First District  Congressman Andy Harris Announces Awards To Md. body: /* Client-specific Styles */ body { width: 100% !important; margin: 0px;} .ReadMsgBody { width: 100%; } .ExternalClass { width: 100%; display:block !important; } /* Force Hotmail to display emails at full width */ /* Reset Styles */ body { margin:0; padding: 0; } img { outline: none; text-decoration: none; max-width :100%;} br, strong br, b br, em br, i br { line-height: 100%; } h1, h2, h3, h4, h5, h6 { line-height: 100% !important; -webkit-font-smoothing: antialiased; } /*ly, tr#221562, add same margin as margin-block-start/end*/ h1{margin-top:0.67em;margin-bottom:0.67em;} h2{margin-top:0.83em;margin-bottom:0.83em;} h3{margin-top:1em;margin-bottom:1em;} h4{margin-top:1.33em;margin-bottom:1.33em;} h5{margin-top:1.67em;margin-bottom:1.67em;} h6{margin-top:2.33em;margin-bottom:2.33em;} table td, table tr { border-collapse: collapse; } p { margin-bottom: 1em; } table.menu-change a { text-decoration:none; } /* pre-header */ .preheader { display:none !important; visibility:hidden; mso-hide:all !important; font-size:0px; color:#ffffff; line-height:0px; max-height:0px; max-width:0px; opacity:0; overflow:hidden; }                                                       Dear Friends, Last week, Missouri received great news from the Department of Agriculture, announcing that the Economic Research Service (ERS) and the National Institute of Food and Agriculture (NIFA) will be based in in the Show Me State!  I’m thrilled that the Department of Agriculture has chosen Missouri to host the ERS and NIFA. Missouri is once again showing that it is open for business, welcoming these important agencies with a qualified workforce, lower costs of living, and a business climate that allows for families to thrive. I am honored to have been a part of this process and am excited to welcome them to the Heartland. Since August of 2018, I have worked in bipartisan fashion with my Congressional and University colleagues to bring ERS and NIFA closer to stakeholders. Missouri is well suited to provide a direct pipeline of top talent to these two agencies. I’m incredibly happy that Missourians will contribute to the research produced by ERS and NIFA as it continues to assist some of Missouri’s most important economic industries.                                              ____________ On Wednesday of this week, the House Agriculture Committee approved H.R. 4895, a bill to reauthorize the Commodity Futures Trading Commission (CFTC). This bipartisan legislation modernizes the CFTC, ensures charitable organizations and church retirement plans are treated fairly, and protects customer assets in the event of a commodity broker bankruptcy.    Following the committee markup, the Biotechnology, Horticulture, and Research Subcommittee held a hearing to gain insight from producers on the state of organic agriculture.  Throughout the hearing, producers expressed the need for strong regulations that ensure the integrity of the National Organic Program, especially as organic fraud from foreign sources continues to threaten the industry, and the need for reliable labor.  As interest in the organic market continues to expand and all farmers continue to face uncertainty, I enjoyed visiting with these organic farmers about their operations and the growing market for their products.  I look forward to continuing to monitor how provisions in the 2018 Farm Bill seek to address challenges for America’s farmer and ranchers both short and long term.                                               ____________ This week the House took a vote to try to legitimize Speaker Pelosi’s impeachment inquiry process. It was another sad step in a demonstration of misplaced priorities by House Leadership Instead of bringing up a vote on the U.S.-Mexico-Canada Agreement (USMCA), which would create 176,000 jobs, the Speaker is devoting House time trying to bring up impeachment charges against our President.  The way they are doing this is denies the President the basic due process other presidents have been afforded such as having counsel present, being able to cross-examine witnesses, or have his witnesses subpoenaed.   It continues the unfair proceedings of the past several weeks where Speaker Pelosi and Chairman of the Intelligence Committee, Adam Schiff, have held closed-door meetings, haven’t allowed Republicans to call in witnesses, and have prohibited the vast majority of Congressmembers from accessing information collected during these hearings.  We’ve seen how the Democrats have preferred to build a preemptive narrative against President Trump, tainting the process with selective leaks and controlling who gets to say what and when. It’s just not right.  This inquiry the House of Representatives voted on last week tries to make up for the sham but falls short allowing the secret hearing to continue and the president to be denied counsel and other rights.  As a Congress, we should be focusing our time addressing the problems faced by Americans; not trying to impeach a president. I will continue to work on behalf of the good people of the 4th Congressional District and fight to ensure Congress prioritizes the people, not politics.  Legislative Update On Tuesday, the House of Representatives passed H.R. 4334, the Dignity in Aging Act with my support. As a granddaughter who was close to my grandparents growing up and someone who has worked with senior citizens my entire life, I have a special place in my heart and the utmost respect for those who have led the way in our country for so long.  Many of them have served this nation, sacrificed for future generations, and put their life on the lines for our freedoms. We owe it to them and future seniors to ensure the strength and solvency of those programs they need and rely on for support. This important legislation builds on the Older Americans Act (OAA), increasing seniors’ access to food, transportation, and services they need to live independently, including caregivers and programs to counter social isolation. OAA currently aids 11 million Americans age 60 and over every year. It funds a wide range of popular programs and services that millions of seniors rely upon every day, including Meals on Wheels, transportation services, and part-time job opportunities to support financial security and combat social isolation. For many older individuals, OAA programs are vital to their health, wellbeing, and independence. I was glad to support this vital legislation.  District Update I had the honor of speaking this week to a Women in Agriculture Conference in Columbia. Women play an important role in our state’s number one industry, and this gathering was designed to provide leadership and hands-on training for women primarily involved in livestock production and to provide ideas for how key decisions are made in farms across Missouri.    I mentioned how I am one of just a handful of working farmers serving in Congress today and how this background in agriculture was such an asset as I worked with my colleagues on the House Agriculture Committee to pass two FARM bills and to work toward creating the right trade policies for those involved in our agriculture industry.  One of those policies is the USMCA, which is awaiting a vote in the U.S. House. This agreement has already been approved by Mexico and is expected to pass in Canada as it will be a good deal for all three countries, adding an estimated $2.2 billion in U.S. agriculture and food exports to Canada and Mexico.     Hopefully, Speaker Pelosi will bring this bill up soon for a vote. America wins when USMCA passes.  Constituent Update While in Columbia, I had the opportunity to meet the new Director of the Harry S. Truman Memorial Veterans’ Hospital and to visit with the medical team at Truman about PTSD treatment and suicide-prevention among veterans. I was encouraged by our discussion. Patricia Hall is a retired Army colonel who took over the reins of the Truman VA in September. She is already familiar with the VA in Missouri and the needs of veterans here as she previously served as Director of the John J. Pershing VA Medical Center in Poplar Bluff.    She and her team shared all the PTSD treatment options available to our veterans.  They are focused on helping veterans get the help they need and are taking proactive steps to partner with groups like Welcome Home in Columbia which provides shelter and services to homeless vets. The Mid-Missouri region is blessed to have such compassionate and competent professionals and volunteers in the area reaching out and helping veterans overcome challenges and live lives of hope and purpose. Gallagher                                           Getting our Fiscal House in Order       Friends,  We've known for years that the trust funds supporting our nation’s most vital programs are on the brink of collapse. Yet rather than try to solve this problem, Congress has kicked the can down the road and avoided the tough debates needed to fix the mess we can all see coming.  This is unacceptable. These trust funds support critical programs like Medicare and Social Security, which people across Northeast Wisconsin depend on. We must find a way to ensure the federal government keeps the promises it has made and preserves these programs for years to come.  That's why this week I introduced the TRUST Act, a plan to help get our  in order. This bill would establish Congressional rescue committees tasked with strengthening each federal trust fund at risk of insolvency, and require Congress to vote on the ideas these committees come up with. It's not a silver bullet solution, but it's an  that will force Congress to work in a bipartisan fashion to find a plan we can agree on--something Congress has failed to do on its own.  We don’t know what answers the rescue committees will come up with, but we do know that without any action, we risk cuts to Social Security and Medicare or massive tax hikes down the road, both of which would be devastating to Northeast Wisconsin.   Problems don't age well, and it's time for Congress to get serious about this problem. Many of these trust funds are projected to become insolvent within the next 13 years. There's no time to waste.   Semper Fi,      Congressman Mike Gallagher (WI-08) Longworth House Office Building | Washington, DC  20515 (202) 225-5665Click here and sign up for Rep. As a Member of two of the committees overseeing in the inquiry, I’m extremely grateful for the courage and dedication demonstrated by these lifetime civil servants who, at unimaginable personal and professional risk, have put the country and our Constitution above their own welfare and have helped the House get to the truth. In one particularly remarkable interview, we heard from Purple Heart recipient Lieutenant Colonel Alexander Vindman, the first current White House employee to testify and someone who has been the subject of vile slander and baseless attacks by the President and Republicans who know the evidence and testimony are damning. Because they can’t defend against the facts, they are attacking the individuals providing the evidence and first-hand accounts of the illegal and inappropriate pressure Trump used against Ukraine in order to force “investigations” into his political rival. Also this week, the impeachment process entered a new phase with the passage of H.Res. 660, a resolution setting forth the process we will use for bringing the evidence to the American public and the Judiciary Committee for consideration of articles of impeachment. This process provides protections for the President not seen by his predecessors and will lay out the mountain of evidence that the three committees have unearthed over the last several weeks. There was a great deal of other House business, as you will see below. And be sure to check your email for the next edition of Jackie’s DC Dashboard during the week of November 11th, when the House is back in session.                   As a Member of Congress, it is my honor and privilege to share information with my constituents in California's 14th District. If you would like to receive more information from my office, please sign up for my online newsletter by clicking the signup button above. You can also remove yourself from the email list at any time by selecting the unsubscribe option at the bottom of this page.        Votes and Legislative Highlights Voted for Next Phase of Impeachment Inquiry and Heard More Explosive Testimony about the President’s Corruption On Thursday, House Democrats proudly passed H.Res. 660, a resolution setting forth the process we will use for bringing the evidence to the American public and the Judiciary Committee for consideration of articles of impeachment. The process outlined in H. Res 660 includes holding open hearings, releasing public transcripts, and transmitting evidence to the Judiciary Committee. This resolution demonstrates that the House remains committed to a fair, lawful, and open process that Americans can trust. While such a resolution is not required for the impeachment to lawfully proceed, we are taking this extraordinary step in the interest of transparency and fairness. The mountain of damning evidence gathered by the three committees can no longer be brushed aside or carelessly denied. It’s time for the facts and evidence to be put to the American people so that they can decide the matter for themselves.   On Tuesday, I was proud to vote with 404 of my colleagues to pass a historic resolution formally recognizing the Armenian Genocide. This vote, decades in the making, affirms that the Ottoman Empire and its forces engaged in an extermination campaign against Armenians during World War I. It also upholds the long U.S. record of recognizing the genocide, which began with our then-Ambassador to the Ottoman Empire and continued with Presidents Theodore Roosevelt and Ronald Reagan. Growing up, my Armenian mother often talked about the genocide with fear and anger. As I said in my remarks on the House floor, passing this resolution helps quell some of this fear and anguish and affirms the legacy of those who perished for millions of Armenians worldwide. I am especially proud to have such overwhelming, bipartisan support for this critically important recognition of genocide. Given Turkey’s ongoing ethnic cleansing campaign in Syria, this vote also served as a warning that these atrocities will not be forgotten and perpetrators will be held to account for their crimes.  House Passes Sanctions on Turkey to Condemn Acts of War in Northern Syria This Tuesday, I joined 354 of my House colleagues in voting to sanction Turkey for its aggression in Northeast Syria. This resolution, which rebuked the President’s haphazard and irresponsible Syria policy, will signal to Turkey and our allies that the President does not speak for the American people or Congress. The resolution will also give the Administration specific tools needed to encourage Turkey to adhere to the existing ceasefire and deter future aggression, such as the ability to sanction Turkish officials, military leaders, and soldiers. Congress has shown that we will stand with our Kurdish and other Middle Eastern partners and against Turkey’s incursion. I hope passing this bill will lead the Administration to stop abdicating its responsibilities and start leading in Syria.  Protected Public Lands and Natural Resources On Wednesday, House Democrats moved a series of bills that would protect our beautiful natural spaces from exploitation and destruction. H.R. 1373, the Grand Canyon Centennial Protection Act, would ban new uranium mining claims around the Grand Canyon, one of our most remarkable national treasures and home to critical biodiversity and water resources. H.R. 2181, the Chaco Culture Heritage Protection Act, would protect a sacred site for Pueblo nations that houses close to 4,000 historical archaeological sites by prohibiting oil and gas development within a ten-mile radius of the Chaco Canyon National Historic Park. H.R. 823, the Colorado Outdoor Recreation and Economy Act, would address years-long oil and gas disputes within the Thompson Divide Withdrawal and Protection Area by designating nearly 80,000 acres as new recreational land, establishing a voluntary lease relinquishment process, and creating a pilot program to capture and utilize methane emissions.  These bills take an important step toward preserving America’s incredible natural resources and public lands for future generations and I will continue to work with my Democratic colleagues to ensure greater protections in the face of Republicans’ ongoing attacks on our environment and precious natural resources.    Where’s Jackie? Chaired Roundtable on the Electronic Health Record Implementation at the Departments of Defense and Veterans Affairs On Wednesday, I co-chaired a Joint Roundtable between the House Armed Services Committee and the House Veterans Affairs Committee addressing the roll-out of a new electronic health care record system. The new system is housed within the Department of Defense and Department of Veterans Affairs and comes in response to the previous VA health care systems that have clearly failed our veteran populations. Wednesday’s roundtable brought together experts from the DoD and VA to discuss the rollout of the new electronic health record system across military bases and VA regions, and how it will provide continuity of care for active-duty servicemembers transitioning to veteran status. This is an important and complex process that will require continued congressional oversight and my colleagues and I are committed to ensuring that this new health care record system addresses numerous problems that have plagued our veterans for far too long.     As co-chair of the bipartisan Congressional UXO/Demining Caucus, I spoke at a briefing on Tuesday that included representatives from demining and advocacy groups as well as the U.S. Department of State who discussed efforts to remove thousands of unexploded cluster munitions that remain in Laos from U.S. wars in Southeast Asia. Over 2 million bombs were dropped on Laos during this time, with roughly 30 percent failing to detonate. They remain a terrible danger to human health and development. Over 50,000 Laotians, 40 percent of them children, have been injured or killed by our weapons while they play, farm, or walk to school. Last year, I saw firsthand the impact of these remnants of war on the people of Laos and I was inspired to create the UXO/Demining Caucus. This year, I led my colleagues in keeping funding for UXO removal in Laos in the budget and I co-sponsored H.R. 2097, the Legacies of War Recognition and Unexploded Ordnance Removal Act. As I’ve said many times, it’s our responsibility to clean up our mess and to do whatever we can to ease the burden on Laos, the most heavily bombed country worldwide.    Meetings with Jackie Met with Artsakh Foreign Minister On Wednesday, I met with Masis Mayilyan, the Foreign Minister of the Republic of Artsakh, which democratically governs lands freed from Azerbaijan in the early 1990s. Meeting in Washington, DC provided an excellent follow up on my visit to Artsakh earlier this month, providing an opportunity for us to discuss Artsakh’s upcoming elections, its inclusion in the peace process with Azerbaijan, and demining efforts. I look forward to continuing to support Artsakh in the years to come and working together in the pursuit of a peaceful and prosperous future for the region.   On Tuesday, I met with a delegation of constituents and leaders from J Street, a pro-Israel, pro-peace group, in town for the organization’s annual conference. We discussed the importance of the two-state solution, a diplomacy-first approach with Iran, and values-based foreign policy. J Street has proved an invaluable partner for me and fellow Members of Congress who believe in fighting for a Jewish, democratic Israel.    Voices of California’s 14th District Each week, hundreds of my constituents reach out to my San Mateo and Washington, D.C. offices to express their concerns and support for issues and get information about legislation and policies. Every constituent who writes in receives a personal response. Some issues constituents raised this week include:  • 80 constituents shared their support for H.Res 296, a resolution affirming the United States record on the Armenian Genocide. As one of only three Members of Congress of Armenian heritage, I am heartened that this measure was agreed to in the House by a vote of 405-11. By passing this resolution, we have affirmed that we will continue to stand against evil and that history cannot be rewritten.  • 62 constituents expressed their continued concern regarding climate change. President Trump’s flat denial of climate change science in favor of advancing his personal agenda to bail out polluting industries is a direct threat to the safety and prosperity of the American people. You have my word that I will be a vigorous advocate for bold       Washington, DC 2465 Rayburn House Office BuildingWashington, DC 20515Phone: (202) 225-3531Fax: (202) 226-4183 San Mateo Office 155 Bovet Road, Suite 780San Mateo, CA 94402 Phone: (650) 342-0300Fax: (650) 375-8270               p { margin-bottom:1em; }

Slotkin‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌                 Greetings,  I wanted to send an update on a big priority: what we’re doing in Congress to lower the cost of prescription drugs. This is the number one issue people in our district ask me about, and has been my priority since getting to Congress.  Back in June, a Republican member and I introduced a bill called the “Real-Time Benefits Act.” It’s a bipartisan bill, and it will help lower out-of-pocket costs for prescription drugs.  Well, on Monday night it passed the U.S. House of Representatives with unanimous, bipartisan support. It’s now on to the Senate.  Here’s how it works: insurers would be required to upload information on drug prices which doctors would access through their electronic prescribing program. Doctors and Medicare Part D patients could then receive details, right in their doctor’s office, on the price of a drug based on insurance plan, the price of any cheaper drugs that would fit their needs, and the price difference at each pharmacy. Patients would leave their doctor’s office knowing the cheapest price for a prescription, and where to get it.   This will not only lower the out-of-pocket costs that seniors, in particular, are paying for drugs, but it will inject much-needed price transparency into our system. Price transparency will help support good old-fashioned competition –– which helps lower costs across the board.     Since I got to Congress, I’ve been focused on what we can do to follow through on those bipartisan areas of agreement, and come up with practical legislation that can drive costs down. Democrats and Republicans have both said the right things when it comes to lowering prescription drug costs. They have talked the talk. Now it’s time for the Senate to walk the walk.  I am incredibly proud that our legislation passed, and I’ll be sure to keep you updated on the next steps.     Sincerely, Elissa Slotkin Member of Congress        Unsubscribe

body: Congressman Richard Hudson, 8th District of North Carolina *Friends, * *It takes an incredible person to answer the call to serve our great nation.* For some Americans who are born into military families, service is in their blood. Others enlist for duty and honor. Many join to be a part of something bigger than oneself. And everyone serves to defend and protect our great country. As Vice President Mike Pence recently told service members stationed abroad, "You come from the rest of us, but you are the best of us - heroes all." While I didn't have the honor to serve in our Armed Forces, many of my family members have and I consider serving as your United States Representative my chance to fight for our active duty service members, veterans and your families in Congress.* I wanted to share a few updates on legislation I've been working on that will go a long way to support veterans.* Right now, my staff and I spend a lot of time cutting through needless bureaucracy and red tape for veterans who need access to their service and medical records - a process that can drag on for months. *Veterans regularly come to my office with stacks and stacks of papers, service records and medical files.* Sometimes it's enough papers and files to fill several boxes because the Department of Veterans Affairs (VA) still hasn't transitioned to electronic health records. It's almost 2020 - it's past time for our veterans to have the best technology available when it comes to their care. *I'm proud to tell you the Trump Administration has made fixing this problem a top priority. *Under President Donald Trump's leadership, the VA is working to deliver a unified electronic health record (EHR) solution between the Department of Defense (DoD) and the VA. This will grant doctors and veterans alike access to the complete picture of a veteran's health information - improving the VA's ability to care for veterans.* This is a massive, 10-year modernization effort and I want to make sure we do it right. I recently introduced the *Department of Veterans Affairs Electronic Health Record Advisory Committee Act* (H.R. 4693), a bipartisan bill to ensure we have transparency and accountability to make this transition as seamless as possible for veterans. *The new electronic health record system is too important to veterans' health care for the VA to get wrong, and my bill will provide strong oversight.* * [image = In this same vein, it's important to ensure professionals who care for our veterans are the very best available.* I was extremely concerned when I found out the VA was hiring some providers with revoked licenses. *That's why I introduced a bill to ensure there are clinical reviews for all care recommended by these providers. If the third-party review finds a practitioner would have recommended a different treatment plan, the veteran will be notified. *This legislation* *is a common-sense step to hold accountable providers* *who had a revoked license and to ensure our veterans received proper treatment and* *care.* As Fort Bragg's Congressman and a voice for veterans across the district, I will continue to do everything in my power to fight for our veterans and ensure you have the best health care out there. *If any veterans in the Eighth District can't get an answer from the VA in a timely fashion or if they feel they have been treated unfairly, please reach out to my Concord office at 704-786-1612, my Fayetteville office at 910-997-2070, or my Pinehurst office at 910-246-5374. * *I am here to serve you and will work hard to help in any way I can.* *Until next week,* * [image = *Richard Hudson* *Member of Congress (NC-08)* [image = [link 1] [image = [link 2] [image = [link 3] [image = [link 4] [image = [link 5] [image = [link 6] [image = [link 7] [image = [link 8] ---------------------- footnotes ---------------------- [link 1] [link 2] [link 3] [link 4] [link 5] [link 6] [link 7] [link 8] Website: Office Locations: Washington, DC Office 2112 Rayburn House Office Building Washington, DC 20515 Phone: 202-225-3715 | Fax: (202) 225-4036 Hours: M-F 8:30am-6:00pm Concord Office 325 McGill Avenue, NW, Suite 500 Concord, NC 28027 Phone: (704) 786-1612 Fax: (704) 782-1004 Hours: M-F 8:30am-5:30pm Fayetteville Office 225 Green Street, Suite 202 Fayetteville, NC 28301 Phone: (910) 997-2070 Fax: (910) 817-7202 Hours: Tues/Thurs 8:30-5:30pm and by appointment Pinehurst Office Sandhills Community College Logan Building 3395 Airport Road, Suite 221 Pinehurst, NC 28374 (910) 246-5374 Hours: Tues/Thurs 8:30am-5:30pm and by appointment Privacy Policy: Unsubscribe:

subject: Congresswoman Clarke Honors the Life and Legacy of Chairman Elijah E. Cummings
body: Congresswoman Yvette D. Clarke, Proudly serving the 9th District of New York October 25, 2019 *Congresswoman Clarke Honors the Life and Legacy of * *Chairman Elijah E. Cummings* *Washington, D.C.- **I relayed the following sentiments in honor of Chairman Elijah Eugene Cummings (MD-07) as he is laid to rest today:* "Our great nation mourns the devastating loss of a giant, Chairman Elijah E. Cummings. As one of seven children born to sharecroppers, it is safe to say that Chairman Cummings embodied the epitome of our ancestors' wildest dreams, as one of the greatest leaders in the United States Congress. Chairman Cummings represented Baltimore, Maryland with pride and dignity, and dedicated his career to ensuring that his beloved community was never left behind. As Chairman of the House Committee on Oversight and Reform, Mr. Cummings used his voice to protect our democracy and Constitution until his last breath and we are forever indebted to his lifelong dedication to public service. He will be remembered as a steadfast advocate of the Congressional Black Caucus who used his voice to elevate our colleagues in leadership positions and to mentor Black staffers. Let us take comfort in knowing that Chairman Cummings' legacy will be forever ingrained in the halls of Congress through the next generation of leaders that his work impacted and inspired. Chairman Cummings completed his mission--he is now dancing with the angels and will go down in American history as a pillar in preserving our democracy and our core American values. Words cannot express the pain that our community feels during this time of sorrow, but we must lift our heads and continue to walk in the light of Chairman Cummings' legacy. We are standing on the shoulders of a giant and we will live out his mission of creating a better America for all. On behalf of the Clarke Family and the Ninth Congressional District of New York, I am lifting Mrs. Maya Rockeymoore Cummings, his children, and loved ones in prayer. Thank you for sharing such a beautiful spirit with the American people. May Chairman Elijah E. Cummings Rest in Power. We will miss him." ### ---------------------- footnotes ---------------------- Contact Information: Website: Office Locations: Washington, DC Office 2058 Rayburn House Office Building Washington, DC 20515 Phone: (202) 225-6231 Fax: (202) 226-0112 Brooklyn Office 222 Lenox Road, Suites 1 & 2 Brooklyn, NY 11226 Phone: (718) 287-1142 Fax: (718) 287-1223 Privacy Policy: Unsubscribe:

Select "Always display images" or  Click here to open in browser.                       Defending our Democracy             A SHIELD to Protect Our Elections On Wednesday, the Democratic House voted 227-181 to pass the SHIELD Act, a strong and commonsense legislation to secure our elections from foreign interference.   Yet, sadly, not a single House Republican voted to strengthen our nation’s defenses, even as our elections face relentless, ongoing foreign attacks.          Instead, they have chosen to brazenly ignore the clear conclusion of America’s top law enforcement and intelligence officials, who have warned that we face a ‘365-day-a-year threat’ from the Russians, whose attacks last year on our elections were simply ‘a dress rehearsal for the big show in 2020.’   Their vote also disregards the findings of the Senate Intelligence Committee, which concluded on a bipartisan basis that election systems in all 50 states were targeted by Russia during the last elections.  House Republicans prove yet again that they are more concerned with protecting the President, who has invited these foreign attacks, than with protecting our elections. American elections should be decided by Americans, just as our Founders intended.  We urge the Senate to show the patriotic leadership that their counterparts in the House have abandoned, and take up this legislation to defend our elections, national security and democracy.  We also urge them to honor their oath by finally taking up H.R. 1, the For The People Act, and the SAFE Act, which strengthen our defenses against foreign assault.  We have no time to waste to safeguard our democracy from the attacks that we know are coming.              Intern for your Congresswoman Do you have an interest in government? Do you want to better understand the legislative process? Do you want to give back to your community?  If you answered yes to any of these questions then you might be interested in an internship in either the San Francisco or D.C. office! Congresswoman Pelosi’s internship program offers college students and recent college graduates a unique opportunity to learn about the functions of the U.S. House of Representatives, as well as the Congresswoman's work as the representative of the City and County of San Francisco (12th Congressional District, California) and her role as the Speaker of the House. Last year, House Democrats took an historic step forward to ensure that our Congressional community reflects the diverse perspectives, voices and experiences of the American people it is our profound honor to serve by creating the House Paid Internship Fund. The Congress and the country are greatly strengthened when opportunities are extended to all, no matter their zip code, socioeconomic status or background, and when our halls are open to young people who embody the beautiful diversity of America. Under the Paid Internship Fund, at least one paid intern slot in the office is reserved for a student that is a Pell Grant recipient, who will be paid at the maximum cap of $1,800 a month, working a 30-hour internship week. In the busy atmosphere of a Congressional office, it is important that interns conduct themselves in a mature, professional manner; are well-organized and able to take initiative, follow instructions, perform well under pressure; and work as an integral part of a team. Skills required include:   Effective and professional phone manner Computer experience Good typing ability Punctuality Attention to detail Ability to follow instructions Ability to complete tasks efficiently and thoroughly   Congresswoman Pelosi supports students requesting credit for their internship through their school or university.  The deadlines for our Spring internship applications are November 8th for the D.C. office and November 23rdth for the San Francisco office.  Apply today!         A constituent recently contacted my office because he was denied entry by U.S. Customs and Border Protection (CBP) at an international port of entry. As part of the denial, the constituent was banned from entering the United States for ten years. The office contacted CBP with additional information and clarification provided by the constituent. As a result, he was able to contact the State Department and reapply for a visa to successfully enter the United States.  Caseworkers in my San Francisco office work to address any problems or concerns you may have with a federal government agency. To submit a Casework Authorization Form, please visit my website.       Please feel free to forward this information to your family and friends. To learn more about these efforts, express your views, or sign up for email updates, please visit my website.                 best regards,           This mailing was prepared, published and mailed at taxpayer expense Unsubscribe                WASHINGTON, DC 1236 Longworth HOBWashington, DC 20515Phone: (202) 225-4965 DISTRICT OFFICE 90 7th Street, Suite 2-800San Francisco, CA 94103Phone: (415) 556-4862                      /***** SMARTPHONE STYLING RULES *****/ @media only screen and (max-width: 497px) { *[class*="container"] { width:100% !important; table-layout:auto !important;} }   p { margin-bottom:1em; }

Weekly Update: Visiting Galway Library; Speaking Out with House
 Leadership; Introducing the State Workforce Incentive Act; Voting to
 Censure Chairman Schiff

This brand new library is a beautiful facility with updated features for readers, including expanded collections of books and e-books, a larger children’s section and dedicated teen area, a 45-seat multi-use program room, and more computers and technology equipment. In addition to touring, I was able to visit with a group of 3rd graders from Joseph Henry Elementary School in the Galway Central School District. I am a proud advocate for increased funding for libraries, and sent a letter to House Appropriators earlier this year to request added funding for the Library Services and Technology Act. Speaking Out with House Republican Leadership About Lack of Transparency    This week, I was proud to stand with members of House Republican leadership and voice my concerns over the conduct of Democrats, and House Intelligence Chair Rep. Adam Schiff, throughout the impeachment process. The impeachment inquiry has been a closed door, unfair and unprecedented process from the beginning.  Not only have Republican members on the Intelligence Committee been barred from reading certain documents related to the impeachment inquiry, the vast majority of Members of Congress have had no access at all to any transcripts or depositions. I believe all Members of Congress and the American public should have access to the transcripts. Adam Schiff has turned this very serious matter into a political game and he is unfit to Chair the House Intelligence Committee. Watch my full statement here or above.  Introducing the State Workforce Incentive Act  This week, I introduced the State Workforce Incentive Act along with Congressman Fred Keller (PA-12.) This legislation reforms the Public Service Loan Forgiveness (PSLF) program, shifting it to a state-directed program of annual loan repayment benefits for workers in high-need occupations. While too many hardworking Americans carry the burden of student debt, the broken PSLF program has only sown confusion and frustration for borrowers seeking relief. I was recently asked by constituents about how we can fix and modernize this program at my Coffee With Your Congresswoman in Lowville. My legislation levels the playing field for borrowers and targets loan relief to low- and middle-income households. Further, it empowers states to address the workforce and public-service needs in their communities, such as beginning farmers or childcare professionals. It is time for a new approach, and this bill delivers a state-led solution to the $1.5 trillion student debt problem facing our nation. Read more about the legislation here.   Voting to Censure Chairman Schiff  This week, I voted in favor of bringing a resolution to the House Floor to censure Rep. Adam Schiff, Chairman of the House Intelligence Committee. As an original cosponsor of the resolution, I was one of the first Members to ask when Chairman Schiff had access to the whistleblower complaint. I was also the first Member to call him out publicly for his 'parody' testimony while millions of Americans tuned in. Adam Schiff is unfit to serve as Chairman of the bipartisan House Intelligence Committee and I voted to bring this Resolution to the House Floor to censure him because of his continued failed leadership and lack of transparency with both Members of the House and the American public. The American people deserve better. Read more here.   Speaking on Ending Discrimination Against Pregnant Women in the Workplace    Discrimination against pregnant women in the workplace is an indefensible practice, and I am glad to see Congress take an active role to ensure they are given robust protection under the law. This week, I spoke in a House Education and Labor Committee hearing about the protections and accommodations necessary for pregnant women in the workplace. I am proud to recently have introduced the Pregnancy Discrimination Amendment Act along with my colleagues to enhance protections for this specific group of women in the workplace, and I will continue to work to ensure their rights are protected. Watch my questioning here or above.   Meeting with the Australian Embassy, Albany Academies' Head of School, and the Fulbright Association       I had a great meeting this week with Australian Ambassador Katrina Cooper and Australian Embassy Congressional Liaisons Elizabeth Willis & Sarah Storey. We spoke about national security and strengthening the U.S. — Australia partnership. I also met with the Albany Academies' Head of School. I proudly attended the Albany Academy for Girls and it was great to talk about the importance of maintaining access to private and public schools in Upstate New York and how to best prepare grade school students for higher education – one of my top priorities in Congress. Additionally, I met with the Fulbright Association, including a constituent who served at Fort Drum, to discuss constituent stories of the impact that the Fulbright Program has at home and abroad.   Remembering Congressman Elijah Cummings  Yesterday, Civil Rights icon Congressman Elijah Cummings lied in state in the U.S. Capitol. He was one of the most deeply respected Members on Capitol Hill, and it was a true honor to serve the American people with him. He will be missed walking the halls of Congress but his legacy will endure. May he rest in peace.  As always, thank you for subscribing to my weekly updates!     Sincerely,    Elise StefanikMember of Congress             Social Media Corner:         ___________________  Featured Read:   North Country Now: North Country Rep. Stefanik recognized for leadership, support of independent colleges, universities  North Country Congresswoman Elise Stefanik, R-Schuylerville, was recognized Oct. 17 for her leadership and support of independent colleges and universities.  She was recognized by Barbara K. Mistick, president of the National Association of Independent Colleges and Universities, with the presentation of a framed replica of her Congressional Independent Colleges Caucus (CICC) Member Spotlight.      “As a proud graduate of an independent college, the CICC caucus allows me to be a leading voice in Congress on the issues impacting independent colleges and universities,” Stefanik said. “I continue to see the impact independent colleges make on the lives of students, and in the communities across my district and throughout the nation. A strength of our higher education system is the variety that exists across the sector, in which independent colleges have an important place in providing students with distinct learning opportunities to foster their individual growth and development.” St. Lawrence University President William L. Fox, Ph.D. credited Rep. Stefanik with recognizing how higher education empowers students.  “Congresswoman Stefanik understands the transformational power of higher education and has been a leader and strong supporter of issues such as access and affordability that are important to colleges and universities in the North Country,” Fox said.               _________________  Constituent Services  Please contact my Glens Falls office at (518) 743-0964 if you would like help with:   Federal agencies. Purchasing U.S. flags. Military Academy Nominations. Tours and tickets for your visit to Washington, D.C. Internships. And other resources.  Glens Falls Office  5 Warren Street, Suite 4  Glens Falls, NY 12801  _________________  Weekly Legislative Recap  Below find a list of legislation that the House of Representatives voted on this week.  H.R. 4405 - Women's Business Centers Improvements Act of 2019 (Passed via Voice Vote)  H.R.4387 - To establish Growth Accelerator Fund Competition within the Small Business Administration, and for other purposes. (Passed via Voice Vote)  H.R.4406 - Small Business Development Centers Improvement Act of 2019 (Passed via Voice Vote)  H.R.4407 - SCORE for Small Business Act of 2019 (Passed via Voice Vote)  H.R.835 - Rodchenkov Anti-Doping Act of 2019 (Passed via Voice Vote)  H.R.2426 - Copyright Alternative in Small-Claims Enforcement Act of 2019 (Passed 410-6; I voted Yes)  S.693 - National POW/MIA Flag Act (Passed via Voice Vote)  H.R.724 - PACT Act (Passed via Voice Vote)  H.R.1123 - Divisional Realignment for the Eastern District of Arkansas Act of 2019 (Passed via Voice Vote)  H.R.598 - Georgia Support Act (Passed via Voice Vote)  H.Res.552 - Calling on the Government of the Russian Federation to provide evidence of wrongdoing or to release United States citizen Paul Whelan. (Passed via Voice Vote)  H.Con.Res.32 - Expressing the sense of Congress regarding the execution-style murders of United States citizens Ylli, Agron, and Mehmet Bytyqi in the Republic of Serbia in July 1999. (Passed via Voice Vote)  H.R.2513 - Corporate Transparency Act of 2019 (Passed 249-173; I voted No)  H.R.4617 - SHIELD Act (Passed 227-181; I voted No)  H.R.777 - Debbie Smith Reauthorization Act of 2019 (Passed 402-1; I voted Yes)                   Washington, DC  318 Cannon H.O.B.Washington, DC 20515Phone: (202) 225-4611Fax: (202) 226-0621 Glens Falls 5 Warren Street, Suite 4Glens Falls, NY 12801Phone: (518) 743-0964Fax: (518) 743-1391 Watertown88 Public SquareSuite AWatertown, NY 13601Phone: (315) 782-3150Fax: (315) 782-1291  Plattsburgh Office 137 Margaret Street Plattsburgh, NY 12901Phone: (518) 561-2324Fax: (518) 561-2408           Unsubscribe - Privacy
