body: /* Client-specific Styles */ body { width: 100% !important; margin: 0px;} .ReadMsgBody { width: 100%; } .ExternalClass { width: 100%; display:block !important; } /* Force Hotmail to display emails at full width */ /* Reset Styles */ body { margin:0; padding: 0; } img { outline: none; text-decoration: none; max-width :100%;} br, strong br, b br, em br, i br { line-height: 100%; } h1, h2, h3, h4, h5, h6 { line-height: 100% !important; -webkit-font-smoothing: antialiased; } /*ly, tr#221562, add same margin as margin-block-start/end*/ h1{margin-top:0.67em;margin-bottom:0.67em;} h2{margin-top:0.83em;margin-bottom:0.83em;} h3{margin-top:1em;margin-bottom:1em;} h4{margin-top:1.33em;margin-bottom:1.33em;} h5{margin-top:1.67em;margin-bottom:1.67em;} h6{margin-top:2.33em;margin-bottom:2.33em;} table td, table tr { border-collapse: collapse; } p { margin-bottom: 1em; } table.menu-change a { text-decoration:none; } /* pre-header */ .preheader { display:none !important; visibility:hidden; mso-hide:all !important; font-size:0px; color:#ffffff; line-height:0px; max-height:0px; max-width:0px; opacity:0; overflow:hidden; }        News from Representative Speier Click here to open this e-mail in its own browser window     Click here to open a plain text version of this email                        October 25, 2019 The impeachment inquiry continued at a rapid pace this week despite House Republicans storming a secure facility in violation of House rules and causing a security risk by bringing and using cell phones and other electronic devices that are prohibited from the zone reserved for top secret conversations and materials. The desperation of President Trump and House Republicans to distract the public from the damning facts of the impeachment investigation with this juvenile stunt underscores the fact that they have no defense for the President's blatant and illegal solicitation of a foreign government to dig up dirt on his political opponent. It also shows contempt for the institution and those charged with protecting it, including the US Capitol Police. And their claims fly in the face of the fact that Republicans conducted more than 100 private interviews in the Republican-controlled Benghazi investigation. The Benghazi investigation was underway for four months before a public hearing was held. After two and a half years and spending more than $7 million in taxpayer funds they found no evidence of their accusations. In fact, the Republican Majority report on Benghazi stated, “Interviews are a more efficient and effective means of discovery. Interviews allow witnesses to be questioned in depth by a highly prepared member or staff person.” I want to assure everyone, including the President and Republicans in Congress, that public hearings on the impeachment inquiry are coming soon and the American public will get the full story. There was also regular House business, including the passage of the Stopping Harmful Interference in Elections for a Lasting Democracy (SHIELD) Act in response to the Russian attack on the 2016 election and future attacks. We also passed the bipartisan Corporate Transparency Act, which requires companies to report who owns them (“beneficial ownership”) to the Financial Crimes Enforcement Network (FinCEN). This critical legislation will cast a light on the dark inner workings of shell companies and elaborate corporate structures. And we voted for the Debbie Smith Reauthorization Act to extend funding for this critical legislation to close the rape kit backlog from 2019 through 2024. The Act provides grant funding for crime labs to process DNA evidence and is the central program to end the backlog. That’s not all, as you will see below, and be sure to check out the next edition of Jackie’s DC Dashboard for further updates.                   As a Member of Congress, it is my honor and privilege to share information with my constituents in California's 14th District. If you would like to receive more information from my office, please sign up for my online newsletter by clicking the signup button above. You can also remove yourself from the email list at any time by selecting the unsubscribe option at the bottom of this page.           Votes and Legislative Highlights Pressed Ahead with Impeachment Inquiry to Hold President Accountable The House Intelligence, Oversight, and Foreign Affairs Committees heard more damning testimony this week about the President’s corrupt conduct in his dealings with Ukraine despite an attempt by Republicans to disrupt the proceedings in violation of House rules.   On Tuesday, we heard explosive testimony from former Ambassador to Ukraine William Taylor about the “irregular, informal channel of U.S. policy-making with respect to Ukraine” used by the President for his own political ends while putting the fledgling democracy of Ukraine in peril. On Wednesday, the House Committees heard from Deputy Assistant Secretary of Defense Laura Cooper to gain additional insight into the impact of the withheld military assistance to Ukraine. Rest assured that we will follow the facts, and our constitutional duty to hold the President accountable for abuses of power and dereliction of his own duties to the American people.  Passed the SHIELD Act to Protect the Integrity of U.S. Elections On Wednesday, I voted to pass the bipartisan Stopping Harmful Interference in Elections for a Lasting Democracy (SHIELD) Act. This critical legislation responds to the Russian attack on the 2016 election and would shore up our electoral defenses for the impending 2020 onslaught. To ensure that another campaign like Trump’s 2016 campaign will not collude with foreign nationals or risk becoming a foreign asset, the SHIELD Act creates reporting requirements for contacts with foreign entities and prohibits campaigns from providing sensitive campaign material to covered foreign nationals. The bill also fights foreign interference by closing loopholes that have let foreign nationals run free with online political ads and permitted foreign nationals to use dark money to exert influence on political expenditures by non-profits and other legal entities. The SHIELD Act’s passage builds on the bold action House Democrats took to close dangerous gaps in our voting security by passing H.R. 1, the For The People Act, and H.R. 2722, the Securing America’s Federal Elections (SAFE) Act, earlier this year.  Voted to End Shell Company Abuses of Tax, Legal Systems This week, I voted for and the House passed the bipartisan Corporate Transparency Act on a vote of 249-173. By requiring companies to report who owns them (“beneficial ownership”) to the Financial Crimes Enforcement Network (FinCEN), this legislation will cast a light on the dark inner workings of shell companies and elaborate corporate structures, which can easily be abused for nefarious ends.  Through anonymous shell companies, bad actors have gained unimpeded, untraceable access to our financial system, allowing them to engage in money laundering, sanctions violations, tax evasion, and countless other crimes and frauds. That’s why national security and law enforcement groups support it and the White House has endorsed this crucial House bill. I call on the Senate to quickly pass this much-needed legislation so it can be presented to the President for his signature and become law.  Reauthorized the Debbie Smith Act to Close the Rape Kit Backlog This week, I voted for and the House passed the Debbie Smith Reauthorization Act to extend funding for this critical legislation to close the rape kit backlog from 2019 through 2024. Sexual violence is an epidemic in America. One in three women experience sexual violence in their lifetime, one in five women are sexually assaulted on college campuses, and 84 percent of Native women have experienced violence. The landmark Debbie Smith Act provides grant funding for crime labs to process DNA evidence and is the central program to end the backlog, which includes both evidence that arrived at a crime lab that was never tested and evidence that was never sent to a lab in the first place. Ensuring that states have adequate funding to test rape kits will keep our communities safer, hold perpetrators accountable for their crimes, and ensure that survivors get the justice owed to them.    Where’s Jackie? Roundtable on Financial Difficulties of Enlisted Military Life On Wednesday, I chaired a Military Personnel Subcommittee roundtable featuring six military spouses who bravely discussed the challenges they face and the ability of military programs to help them.   Hearing on Armenia’s Democratic Progress On Tuesday, I participated in a hearing hosted by the U.S. Helsinki Commission on Armenia’s democratic progress and U.S. policy and shared my impressions from my recent trip to Armenia. Though Armenia’s government has a limited window in which to enact fundamental reforms to its Constitution while improving the quality of daily life through better delivery of basic services, I came home deeply impressed by the passion and talent of young Armenians working toward a brighter future. The country is in good hands and U.S. aid programs should follow Armenia’s lead. Tuesday’s hearing provided a great reminder of the potential and difficulties that can arise with reform. It also offered an opportunity for Congress to hear directly from an Armenian parliamentarian and civil society leaders. As a co-chair of the Congressional Caucus on Armenian Issues, I look forward to working with Armenia as we continue to build a strong relationship between our countries for a more secure and prosperous future for both of our countries.  Unveiled the Democratic Women’s Caucus Policy Agenda for Unleashing the Power of Women and Girls  Our bold vision includes legislation to close the gender wage gap, provide paid family and medical leave, reauthorize the Violence Against Women Act, repeal the Hyde amendment, protect pregnant workers from discrimination, and extend rights against harassment to all workers. We will be pushing the Committees of jurisdiction to take up our proposals so that all women and girls can thrive, making our communities stronger, safer, and more prosperous.    Meeting with Jackie The San Francisco Health Network and California Association of Public Hospitals and Health Systems  At the meeting, we discussed pressing issues facing San Francisco’s health care network, such as the future of Medicaid Disproportionate Share Hospital (DSH) payments and the homelessness crisis. DSH payments provide critical financial support to hospitals that serve a large number of Medicaid and uninsured patients. I am committed to fighting for a health care system that ensures accessible, high quality care for everyone.    Voices of California’s 14th District Each week, hundreds of my constituents reach out to my San Mateo and Washington, D.C. offices to express their concerns and support for issues and get information about legislation and policies. Every constituent who writes in receives a personal response. Here are some issues constituents raised this week:   • 33 constituents shared their support for the continued protection of public lands. Our nation is filled with natural beauty. In northern California alone, Gulf of the Farallones National Marine Sanctuary, Point Reyes, Muir Woods, Fort Point, Big Sur, and Yosemite have dazzled millions of Americans and foreign tourists with the splendor of nature. We should be investing in conservation projects to ensure these magnificent places will exist for generations to come, not stripping the land of its resources. I will continue to fight for public land ownership and robust conservation funding. • 18 constituents wrote to me to discuss the need for climate smart infrastructure, which refers to infrastructure that is tougher and more resilient to damage caused by extreme weather patterns. I very much support infrastructure that is “climate smart” and designed in a way to reduce heat trapping emissions to the maximum extent possible. name: Senator Martin Heinrich
subject: My recent visit to Silver City
body: October 24, 2019 Dear Friend, It is always a pleasure to visit with New Mexicans in every corner of our great state. I wanted to take a moment to let you know about my recent visit to Silver City earlier this month. I was honored to open the second annual New Mexico Outdoor Economics Conference. It was refreshing to be joined by so many leaders from across our state who are finding ways to grow the outdoor industry. Public lands fuel our thriving outdoor recreation economy in New Mexico and sustain outdoor traditions. Silver City is a shining example of a gateway community that thrives because of its access to the nation's first wilderness area, the Gila Cliff Dwellings National Monument, the Gila River, and the Continental Divide Trail. PHOTO: U.S. Senator Martin Heinrich (D-N.M.) celebrates the 51st anniversary of the Wild & Scenic Rivers Act and is presented with a Conservation Champion Award by the New Mexico Wilderness Alliance in Silver City. Pictured from left: Simon Sotelo, Tisha Broska, and Nathan Newcomer, October 2, 2019. I also enjoyed celebrating the 51st anniversary of the Wild & Scenic Rivers Act at Little Toad Creek Brewery and Distillery with the New Mexico Wilderness Alliance. Wild & Scenic designations have protected portions of Rio Grande up in northern New Mexico, the Rio Chama, the East Fork of the Jemez, and the Pecos. Sections of the Gila and San Francisco watershed deserves similar protections. While I was in Silver City, I sat down with local community stakeholders to discuss legislation Senator Tom Udall and I are beginning to draft to permanently protect sections of the Gila. PHOTO: U.S. Senator Martin Heinrich (D-N.M.) visits with Syzygy Tile owner Josh White in Silver City, October 2, 2019. Finally, I toured a local small business, Syzygy Tile, and learned about how the company produces unique hand-crafted tiles that are both beautiful and environmentally sound. I am committed to providing resources and support to local small businesses that are the backbone of our economy and critical to job creation and sustained economic growth. I remain committed to working hard to deliver results for all New Mexico communities. I hope you can stay in touch about issues that are important to you and your family. It is an honor and privilege to serve you in the Senate. Sincerely, MARTIN HEINRICH United States Senator Follow Martin Heinrich on Facebook, Twitter, and Instagram: To unsubscribe from this mailing list, click here. With only 21 legislative days left in the calendar year — and issues like prescription drug prices, the United States-Mexico-Canada Agreement, surprise medical bills, border security, and so many others left to resolve —  their contempt for President Trump has fueled a closed-door, behind the scenes, hyper-partisan "impeachment inquiry" where Congress and the American people are kept in the dark. Congressional Democrats need to bring their impeachment process out of the shadows and get back to the business of the American people.    In the interest of securing our elections, the Democrats brought a bill — the SHIELD Act — to the floor yesterday that would federalize our elections by substantially restricting free speech through government overreach all while failing to actually secure our elections. In its place, we offered a Republican alternative that actually targets foreign actors to prevent meddling in our elections, and modernizes our existing laws for the 21st Century. Unfortunately, our amendment was defeated as the Democrats continued advancing their socialist agenda. Keep reading to learn about what we've been doing in the Ways and Means Committee.   Speaker Pelosi's Fewer Cures for Patients Act Last week, the Ways & Means Committee held a hearing on H.R. 3, the Democrat’s drug pricing bill. This bill would tie the prices paid by consumers in America to an international index of countries with much different healthcare systems. The resulting government price setting would result in fewer resources for investment in research and development of cures and life-saving drugs for patients in need. Scientists researching how to cure new diseases, manufacturing jobs, and other critical areas of drug development and product delivery would all be detrimentally impacted. In fact, the Congressional Budget Office (CBO) has reported that 8-15 new drugs would not come to the market over the next 10 years if H.R. 3 were implemented. A more appropriate title for Speaker Pelosi's bill would be the Fewer Cures for Patients Act. Unfortunately, by advancing this disastrous bill, House Democrats are working towards fewer cures instead of fighting for life-saving treatments for patients.  Click below to watch my remarks during a Ways and Means hearing on the bill.                Ways and Means Committee Markup This week, on Tuesday, the Ways and Means Committee marked up the Fewer Cures for Patients Act, with the Democrats advancing the partisan bill out of committee along party lines. The Ways and Means Committee also marked up H.R. 4742 — a bill that would put an excise tax on the nicotine in e-cigarettes and vaping devices. I offered an amendment to address the very serious health crisis of vaping related illness. Click the video below to watch.                I also introduced H.R. 4716 which would require certain high deductible health plans to cover the cost of inhalers for the treatment of any chronic lung disease, including asthma, before the plan’s deductible is met. This bill’s addition of inhalers is similar to President Trump’s efforts to expand preventative services for HSAs. I am proud of the members of the Ways and Means Committee who worked in a bipartisan fashion to pass this bill out of committee.                Military Academy Nominations It is my honor to nominate students from Georgia's Third District to the United States Service Academies. The deadline to apply is this Friday, October 25th. If you are interested, click here for more information.        National Prescription Drug Take-Back Day This Saturday, October 26th, 2019, is National Prescription Drug Take-Back Day. National Take-Back Day allows you to safely and responsibly dispose of any unused or expired prescriptions. They will also be collecting vape pens and other e‐cigarette devices. Click here to find a location near you!        Week in Photos     It was great to tour the Kason Industries in Newnan. This plant manufactures hardware for refrigeration, foodservice, and industrial equipment that gets distributed around the world.            Thank you to the folks at the Cargill Plant in Newnan for hosting me!            It's always an honor to have the Fort Benning International Military Officers stop by our Nation’s Capital!           Productive talk with the NCR Corporation team in my Washington, DC office last week.     Spring Internship Interested in spending a semester in Washington, DC interning on Capitol Hill? My office is accepting applications for the Spring 2020 internship program. Click here for more information or to fill out an application.      Constituent Services My office is here to help! If you are in need of assistance from a federal agency, have comments or concerns to share with me, or would like to set-up tours for your next trip to Washington, DC, please feel free to contact my district office in Newnan or my office in Washington, DC. You can also send me a message through my website by clicking here!     As always, it is an honor to serve the great folks of Georgia's Third District!      Sincerely, Drew FergusonMember of Congress              Washington, DC 1032 Longworth House Office BuildingWashington, DC 20515Phone: (202) 225-5901 Newnan Office 1601 E Hwy 34Suite BNewnan, GA 30265Phone: (770) 683-2033           Unsubscribe from Future Mailings       /***** SMARTPHONE STYLING RULES *****/ @media only screen and (max-width: 497px) { *[class*="container"] { width:100% !important; table-layout:auto !important;} }

These newsletters will cover a variety of topics, including events happening in northeast Indiana, legislation being considered in Congress, and my perspective on current issues. My hope is to keep you updated and informed on how issues in Washington may impact our region. I welcome your feedback.    Honoring our Hoosier Heroes   I was honored to recently welcome veterans from honor flight Northeast Indiana, some of whom are visiting Washington for the first time.These Hoosier heroes served in World War II, Vietnam, and Korea, and our state and nation are grateful for their sacrifices.   Winona Lake Town Hall Meeting   I appreciate the people of Winona Lake joining me for my seventh town hall meeting of the year. It was a pleasure discussing a wide range of issues important to Hoosiers and I look forward to taking their feedback with me to Capitol Hill. Click here to learn more.   NBA Silences GM After Pro-Hong Kong Tweet   The NBA employs an egregious double standard. They are okay when members of the league are critical of America. But not okay when members are critical of China. Here are a few examples:  (1) The NBA boycotted North Carolina over their bathroom policy, but they're silent when China puts Muslims in internment camps.  (2) The NBA was fine letting players protest police brutality on the court, but police in Hong Kong shot protesters with rubber bullets (and in one case a real bullet), tear gas and water canons against peaceful pro-democracy demonstrators. (3) And this May, when asked about players criticizing Trump, NBA's Adam Silver responded, "This is America." But when Houston Rockets' General Manager Daryl Morey posted a meme showing support for Hong Kong, the NBA pressured him to apologize.  Click here to watch my full interview on CNN's Your World Today.   Adam Schiff Deserves To Be Censured   House Intelligence Committee Chairman Adam Schiff (D-CA) knew of the whistleblower allegations in August. His committee helped file the whistleblower complaint as the CIA changed the whistleblower standards, he fabricated a part of the president's phone call, then played dumb and subpoenaed for the complaint he helped file.   Adam Schiff deserves to be censured, but last night Congressional Democrats sent a loud and clear message that you can lie and get away with it. By striking down the censure resolution, they impugned not just the impeachment inquiry but the entire U.S. House of Representatives. From the Trump-Russia collusion hoax, to the treatment of SCOTUS Justice Brett Kavanaugh, and now these fake impeachment inquiries, Schiff is the first of many who should be held accountable for their bad actions. Click here to watch my full interview with Lou Dobbs.   Named Co-Chair of Future of Defense Task Force House Armed Services Committee Chairman Adam Smith (D-Wash.) and Ranking Member Mac Thornberry (R-Texas) recently announced the official activation of the Future of Defense Task Force. The future is coming, and we need our military to be ready. I am honored to announce that I have been tapped to co-chair this important Task Force and help our country brace for new, complex national security threats coming from China and Russia. The bipartisan Future of Defense Task Force is chartered to review U.S. defense assets and capabilities and assess the state of the national security innovation base to meet emerging threats. Click here to learn more.   Beto’s Plan an Outrageous Assault on the First Amendment   At a recent televised town hall, former Rep. Beto O'Rourke called for religious institutions to lose their tax-exempt status if they disagree with him on same-sex marriage. CNN's Don Lemon asked O'Rourke, “Do you think religious institutions like colleges, churches, charities – should they lose their tax-exempt status if they oppose same-sex marriage?” Without missing a beat, O'Rourke emphatically said, “Yes.” This is an outrageous assault on the First Amendment and our country's beautiful tradition of religious freedom. O'Rourke's proposal, in addition to being unconstitutional, would pit churches with millions of American members against the U.S. government. Click here to read my most recent op-ed in The Journal Gazette.   Chinese Communist Propaganda on Capitol Hill   The House and Senate Postal Operations services distribute several American newspapers to Congressional staff every day. These newspapers are provided for free by outlets like the Washington Post and National Journal. However, an outside newspaper logistics company, the National News Agency, delivers a separate list of publications to Congressional offices, bypassing normal Congressional media distribution procedures. One of those newspapers is the China Daily, an English language project by the Chinese Communist Party to, in the words of Xi Jinping, “tell China’s story well.”  As we learn more about the economic and military threat China poses to the United States, it is completely inappropriate that Chinese-funded propaganda is proliferating in the halls of Congress. Every single morning, each member of Congress finds a copy of China Daily on their doorstep. If we can’t win the information war in Congress, how can we hope to win it anywhere else? I recently sent a letter to the Chief Administrative Officer of the House, Philip Kiko, to find out why and how this propaganda arrives at our doors. Click here to read my full letter.   Student Veteran Protection Act Last week, Rep. Susie Lee (D-NV) and I introduced the bipartisan Student Veteran Protection Act. The bill would change how GI Bill overpayments are reimbursed by making schools, not student veterans, responsible for reimbursing the Department of Veterans Affairs (VA) for GI Bill overpayments.   Veterans have already sacrificed so much for our country, they shouldn’t be forced to deal with the bureaucratic process of repayment. This common-sense and bipartisan bill would ensure veterans won’t have to endure unnecessary financial hardship or bureaucratic red-tape.  A 2015 GAO report that found the VA identified $416,000,000 in overpayments under educational assistance program during fiscal year 2014, affecting approximately one in four veteran beneficiaries and about 6,000 schools.  By making overpayments the responsibility of schools instead of students, schools would return overpayments directly to VA, instead of sending the payments to students who would then be responsible for reimbursing VA. Click here to learn more about the bill.    In the News  WBIW | Banks Leads 67 Republicans Calling on DOJ to Investigate Klopfer Townhall | Banks Challenges NPR Host to Pick Part of Transcript That Incriminates Trump Fox Business | Dems Fixated on Taking Down President Trump Fox and Friends First | Dems Remain Hushed on Impeachment Inquiry NPR | Indiana Republican Rep. Sen. Collins Honors Maine Firefighters; Warns Seniors of New Scam;
 Announces $15 Million for Lead Hazard Removal; and More

font-size:0px; color:#ffffff; line-height:0px; max-height:0px; max-width:0px; opacity:0; overflow:hidden; }                 Can't see the images? Make sure your e-mail is set to download pictures in order to see the full content of this e-newsletter                            Item 2  October 21, 2019                    Senator Collins Honors Maine Firefighters at Memorial Service in Augusta   U.S. Senator Susan Collins delivered remarks at the Maine State Firefighter Memorial Service, which is held by the Maine State Federation of Firefighters each year during National Fire Prevention Week at the Firefighters Memorial in Augusta.  A roll call of names was read of all Maine firefighters that passed away during the previous year, and memorial plaques were displayed.  The event was attended by approximately 100 firefighters, their friends and families, and government leaders.  “This annual memorial service is always powerful and inspiring, but it had a special significance this year.  Just last month, Farmington Fire Captain Michael Bell gave his life responding to a terrible tragedy in the town he loved so dearly and defended with such courage and devotion,” Senator Collins continued.  “Our  As co-chair of the Congressional Fire Services Caucus, Senator Collins has been an advocate for Maine's first responders, fighting hard to ensure they have the resources and support necessary to protect lives and property.  Click HERE to read Senator Collins' full remarks.   Seniors Warned of New Social Security Scam  Con artists are calling Mainers claiming that their Social Security number has been compromised and used by someone else. In another version of this scam, Mainers are told that their Social Security number has been suspended and that there is a warrant for their arrest. Sometimes these scammers may pose as Social Security personnel by “spoofing” victims’ caller ID to make it appear as though they are calling from a Social Security office. Never give out personal information to an unsolicited caller.  Anyone who receives such a call should immediately hang up.   This scam can also be reported to the Aging Committee’s Fraud Hotline at 1-855-303-9470.      Senator Collins Secures Nearly $15 Million to Remove Lead Hazards in Maine Homes   The cities of Lewiston, Portland, and Biddeford and the Maine State Housing Authority received a total of $14,813,466 to address lead hazards in Maine homes.  The funding was awarded as a result of the advocacy of Senator Collins, the Chairman of the Housing Appropriations Subcommittee. “Lead poisoning poses a great threat to families that do not have the resources to afford costly lead abatement programs,” said Senator Collins.  “Since the beginning of my Senate service, I have worked to raise awareness and secure funding to address this largely preventable health problem, which remains one of the most prevalent environmental issues facing children today.  This funding, which I strongly advocated for, will help eliminate lead hazards in hundreds of homes, making them safe for Maine families.” Click HERE to read more.   World’s Largest 3D Printer and Largest 3D Printed Boat Unveiled at UMaine   Senator Collins attended a ceremony at the University of Maine to help unveil the world’s largest 3D printer and christen a 25-foot, 5,000-pound 3D printed boat named 3Dirigo.     The UMaine Advanced Structures and Composites Center received three Guinness World Records for the world’s largest prototype polymer 3D printer, largest solid 3D-printed object, and largest 3D-printed boat.  UMaine is partnering with Oak Ridge National Laboratory, the U.S. Department of Energy’s largest science and energy laboratory, to research using wood fiber for large-scale 3D manufacturing.  This project will strengthen environmentally responsible advanced manufacturing throughout America as well as the forest-products industry in Maine. As a senior member of the Senate Appropriations Committee, Senator Collins secured $20 million for this promising collaboration, and she successfully worked to include an additional $20 million in the committee-approved energy funding bill. Click HERE to read more.  Click HERE to watch the ceremony.    $300 Million Secured by Senator Collins for New Maine Maritime Training Ship Clears Key Senate Hurdle The Appropriations Committee unanimously approved a funding bill authored by Senator Collins, the Chairman of the Transportation Appropriations Subcommittee, that included $300 million for the construction of a new training vessel for Maine Maritime Academy (MMA). The new training vessel, known as a National Security Multi-Mission Vessel (NSMV), will provide increased training capacity on a state-of-the-art training platform for cadets at MMA. State of Maine, is almost 30 years old and the oldest ship in the fleet is more than 55 years old.” Senator Collins strongly opposed the Administration’s proposal earlier this year that requested $205 million to construct an inadequate training vessel that would not have provided sufficient capacity for MMA.  In addition, changing the design would have required the U.S. Maritime Administration to start from scratch in designing a brand new ship. Click HERE to read more.  Groundbreaking for New Business District at The Downs in Scarborough Attended by Senator Collins   Senator Collins delivered remarks at the groundbreaking ceremony of The Downs’ Innovation District, a 150 acre commercial-light industrial subdivision located in the center of Scarborough. With its mix of business and commercial uses, it is projected that The Downs will eventually host more than 3,000 jobs.   The Downs is the vision of two sets of brothers and life-long friends—the Risbaras and the Michauds—who purchased this land in their hometown in 2018.  Once completed, the project will host Scarborough’s future Town Center, preserve 200 acres of greenspace, and create 10 miles of recreational trails that connect to a mixed-use residential area that will include single family homes, condominiums, and affordable housing.   Senator Collins Attends 65th Annual Forestry Field Day   Senator Collins delivered remarks at the 65th Annual Forestry Field Day, which was held at Newell Tree Farm in Unity.  The event, which was co-hosted by Maine Tree Farm Program and Maine Woodland Owners, celebrated the achievements of the 2019 Outstanding Tree Farmer of the Year, Don Newell, and his family. The event featured wagon and walking tours of the woodlot to explore the management and stewardship of the property.  Senator Collins is a member of the Senate Working Forests Caucus. “Congratulations to Newell Tree Farm on being named the 2019 Outstanding Tree Farm of the Year!” said Senator Collins.  “In contrast to most of the United States where forests are publicly held, 95 percent of Maine woods are privately owned.  These landowners, like Don Newell and his family, serve as the caretakers of the natural resources that are vital to our forest products industry and recreation economy.  Thank you to the Maine Tree Farm and Maine Woodland Owners for their efforts to uphold the Maine tradition of providing public access to private lands and to preserve our state’s beautiful forests for generations to come.”  Click HERE to read more.    Bangor YMCA CEO Diane Dickerson Testifies about Healthy Aging at Senator Collins’ Invitation  At the hearing, Diane also made the exciting announcement that the Bangor YMCA is partnering with The Jackson Laboratory and the Alzheimer's Association, Maine Chapter, to launch the Brain Health Initiative, which will help Alzheimer’s patients and their families.  Click HERE to read more.    Senator Collins Attends Dedication of St. André Memory Care Garden in Biddeford “Collins helps dedicate St. André Health Care Memory Care Garden” Journal Tribune | Ed Pierce  “Surrounded by trees and nature, the new 5,600-square-foot garden was praised by special guests at the event including U.S. Sen. Susan Collins and Roman Catholic Bishop Robert P. Deeley of the Diocese of Portland. Created in back of the health care facility at 407 Pool St. in Biddeford, the garden features an expanded and enclosed outdoor patio which is safe for residents experiencing memory loss.  “St. André is a not-for-profit, 96-bed residence offering rehabilitation and skilled medical care, short-term respite care, long-term nursing care, Alzheimer’s and dementia care, and palliative and hospice care. The Memory Care Unit at St. André is home to patients diagnosed with memory loss, specifically dementia and Alzheimer’s disease.” … Click HERE to read the full article in the Journal Tribune.    Senators Collins and King Rededicate Maine Lobsterman Statue   On Maine Avenue along Washington, D.C.’s, waterfront, Senators Susan Collins and Angus King celebrated National Lobster Day by participating in a rededication ceremony of the Maine Lobsterman Memorial.  The statue was first brought to D.C. and placed near a fish market in 1983.  When the area recently underwent a significant redevelopment, Senator Collins coauthored a bill requiring the Memorial to be displayed in a prominent position. “Once hard to find and surrounded by overgrown shrubbery, the Maine Lobsterman now kneels proudly with his catch on the pier adjacent to the bustling fish market, greeting visitors and reminding them of the importance of the Maine lobster industry to our state and the country as a whole,” said Senator Collins.  “As the industry faces a number of challenges from changing ocean conditions to retaliatory tariffs, this statue reminds us of who the industry is built upon and who the delegation stands in support of – hardworking Mainers and their families.” The Maine Lobsterman was sculpted by Victor A. Kahill, a Lebanese immigrant and Mainer.  The artist modeled the statue after Harpswell lobsterman H. Elroy Johnson, who frequently visited the Maine State House to participate in discussions on fisheries policy.  National Lobster Day was established through a resolution introduced by Senators Collins and King that passed the Senate in August.    Meeting with Mainers        Top Row: Senator Collins with Caribou High School Boys Basketball Team State Champions  Middle Row: Senator Collins with Lariska Bengehya, an intern in her Portland office; and Senator Collins with Donna Peirce, Director of Human Resources at BangorHousing; Paul Chaiken, Commissioner of BangorHousing; John Hodge, Executive Director of the Brunswick and Topsham Housing Authorities and President of PHADA.   Bottom Row: Senator Collins with Dan and Sylvia Bridgham of Aroostook County; and Senator Collins with Cape Elizabeth Police Chief Paul Fenton and his son, Chase                                OFFICE OF SENATOR SUSAN COLLINS  413 Dirksen Senate Office BuildingWashington, D.C. 20510Phone: (202) 224-2523Fax: (202) 224-2693   To UNSUBSCRIBE, please click here    Click here to open this e-mail in its own browser windowClick here to open a plain text version of this email

name: Senator Pat Toomey
subject: Pushing Back Against Erdogan's Aggression
body: Pushing Back Against Erdogan's Aggression Last week, the Trump administration announced the withdrawal of U.S. forces from Northern Syria. Subsequently, Turkey began attacking our Kurdish allies in the region. The dangers of withdrawing U.S. forces from northern Syria outweigh the benefits to American security interests. Nevertheless, I believe a sanctions regime will strengthen the hand of the Trump administration to negotiate with Turkey. This is why I am supporting Senators Lindsey Graham (R-S.C.) and Chris Van Hollen's (D-Md.) bipartisan Countering Turkish Aggression Act of 2019, which would levy heavy financial penalties against Turkey following their invasion of northern Syria. The legislation would apply new sanctions to senior Turkish officials, including President Recep Tayyip Erdogan, key Turkish banks, military transactions, and energy sector activities in support of the Turkish Armed Forces. The sanctions would remain in place until the administration certifies to Congress that Turkey has halted attacks against the Syrian Kurdish community, has withdrawn from all locations that they didn't occupy prior to the October 9, 2019 invasion, and is not hindering counterterrorism operations against ISIS. Making History for American Sikhs In my travels throughout southeast Pennsylvania, I've had the privilege of meeting many hard-working Sikh constituents. This week, I was honored to welcome Sikhs from Pennsylvania and across the nation to Washington D.C. for a special morning prayer and evening reception as they celebrated the 550th anniversary of the birth of Sikhism's founder, Guru Nanak. At my invitation, Giani Sukhvinder Singh, a Sikh religious leader from the Philadelphia Sikh Society Gurdwara and resident of Millbourne (Delaware County), became the first Sikh to deliver the morning prayer in the Senate chamber. In the evening, I joined the Sikh community for an Interfaith Conference to foster understanding and acceptance of different faiths. I was happy to help facilitate these events for our Pennsylvania Sikh friends and neighbors. The Sikhs' close-knit and vibrant communities are part of the rich cultural fabric of Pennsylvania. I enjoyed celebrating Guru Nanak's 550th birthday with them. Read more about the day here. Honoring World War II Icons World War II profoundly changed the course of history and required the mobilization of our entire country. I recently cosponsored two bills honoring two great World War II icons -- Merrill's Marauders and Rosie the Riveter. As a long-range penetration special operations jungle warfare unit, Merrill's Marauders fought in the Pacific Theater against the Japanese. The Merrill's Marauders Congressional Gold Medal Act directs the Treasury Department to strike a gold medal commemorating this unit for their heroic feats during World War II. Pennsylvania was home to 164 of the original Merrill's Marauders members - the highest of any state. Similarly, the Rosie the Riveter Congressional Gold Medal Act honors the cultural icon that galvanized women to join the workforce and assist with the war effort by directing the Treasury Department to strike a gold medal. The medal would honor not only Rosie the Riveter, but all the women who joined the workforce during this time. The members of Merrill's Marauders represented the bravery and determination that propelled the Allied troops to victory. While those brave men fought abroad, women all across the nation were inspired to join the workforce due to the iconic image of Rosie the Riveter. By honoring this cultural icon, we enshrine the contributions of those women. Introducing John Gallagher This week, Senator Casey and I introduced John Gallagher, a nominee for the United States District Court for the Eastern District of Pennsylvania, before the Senate Judiciary Committee. John Gallagher is an Assistant United States Attorney for the Eastern District of Pennsylvania, where he is the Chief of the Allentown Branch Office. Before joining the United States Attorney's Office, Mr. Gallagher held leadership positions in both the Miami and Philadelphia Police Departments and also served as a New York City Police Officer. Mr. Gallagher earned his B.S. from Long Island University and his J.D. from New York Law School. His many years as a federal and state prosecutor and law enforcement officer will serve him well as a judge. I am confident he will be an impartial jurist who treats everyone fairly. I am particularly glad Mr. Gallagher will be filling a seat in the Allentown federal courthouse. Since 2011, Senator Casey and I have worked together, in a bipartisan fashion, to fill vacancies on the federal bench in Pennsylvania. Together we have now vetted, recommended, and confirmed 23 Federal District Court Judges for Pennsylvania. Only two states - New York and Texas - have had more district court judges confirmed to their federal benches during this time. Despite the increased partisanship that has been created by the Speaker’s efforts to move their impeachment inquiry behind closed doors and out of the public view, I remain committed to focusing on the issues and priorities of the Sixth District. Hong Kong Legislation:   As Ronald Reagan once said, “America is a shining city upon a hill whose beacon light guides freedom-loving people everywhere." The United States will always stand for democracy, and the citizens of Hong Kong have taken to the streets in support of a fairer society. The desire to live in freedom leads individuals to do heroic acts in the face of certain condemnation, and I applaud the people of Hong Kong for using their voice to spur positive change.        Impeachment:  When Congress sought to impeach Presidents Nixon and Clinton, it was done with bipartisan support and in a transparent and fair fashion before the American people. Unfortunately, the Majority is pursuing impeachment behind closed doors and re-writing the rules to remove due process protections. At the expense of fundamental fairness, the Majority is pursuing impeachment at all costs and have let fall by the wayside the issues that matter most to the American people like passing the USMCA trade agreement, repairing the country's crumbling infrastructure, and fixing our broken immigration system.   Drug Pricing:  Congress should take action immediately to encourage lower prescription drug prices and better enable Americans to afford the medications they need. That is why I am the lead cosponsor of the Terminating the Extension of Rights Misappropriated Act (TERM Act). This bipartisan legislation would allow for the quicker introduction of generic medications to the marketplace by ending the practice of “evergreening” by the pharmaceutical companies. Unfortunately, Speaker Pelosi’s H.R. 3, which passed in the Education and Labor Committee this week, would use socialist price controls to crush the pharmaceutical industry, deter innovation, and dramatically reduce the ability of patients to access life-saving medicines. Further, this legislation could cost Virginia roughly 7,200 jobs and nearly $1.8 billion in yearly economic output. I am hopeful that we can address the problem of high prescription drug prices in a bipartisan way moving forward.          Constituent Meetings:  As Members of Congress, one of the great privileges we have is meeting with constituents both in the District and here in Washington. This week, a number of Sixth District residents visited my office to advocate on behalf of causes that matter most to them. Some constituents discussed increasing funding for muscular dystrophy research, others asked for support for the College of Osteopathic Medicine at Liberty University, and one family from Roanoke simply stopped by to tour the Capitol. It is always great to have a bit of the Valley in Washington and to have an opportunity to hear my constituents’ concerns. My door is always open.         For the latest updates from Washington, please follow my social media accounts: Facebook, Twitter, and Instagram.  Thank you for the opportunity to serve as your Congressman. If my office can ever be of assistance, please contact my Washington office at (202) 225-5431.                Washington D.C. name: Congressman Buddy Carter
subject: The Impeachment Sham Continues
body: THE IMPEACHMENT SHAM CONTINUES House Democrats continued their attempts this week to overturn the 2016 presidential election. This process has been secretive and baseless since day one. Speaker Pelosi has lost control of her party and the House Intelligence Committee Chairman leading the impeachment charge has lied to the American people. That is why I joined my friend Representative Andy Biggs and many of my Republican colleagues this week to push our resolution condemning and censuring Representative Adam Schiff for his false retelling of the phone conversation between President Trump and the president of Ukraine in a recent hearing, for spreading false information about the Trump campaign and Russia, and concealing his dealings with the whistleblower. Here is the text of our resolution: "Condemning and censuring Adam Schiff, Representative of Californias 28th Congressional District Whereas, President Trump released the transcript of a call between him and the President of Ukraine; Whereas, President Trump subsequently released the whistleblower complaint of August 12, 2019; Whereas, in a September 26, 2019, hearing on the whistleblower complaint, House Intelligence Committee Chairman Adam Schiff purported to relay the content of the phone call to the American people; Whereas, instead of quoting directly from the available transcript, Chairman Schiff manufactured a false retelling of the conversation between President Trump and President Zelensky; Whereas, this egregiously false and fabricated retelling had no relationship to the call itself; Whereas, these actions of Chairman Schiff misled the American people, bring disrepute upon the House of Representatives, and make a mockery of the impeachment process, one of this chambers most solemn constitutional duties; Whereas, for more than two years, Chairman Schiff has spread false accusations that the Trump Campaign colluded with Russia; Whereas on March 20, 2017, then Ranking Member Schiff read out false allegations from the Steele dossier accusing numerous Trump associates of colluding with Russia; Whereas, then-Ranking Member Schiff falsely claimed in a March 2017 interview to have more than circumstantial evidence of collusion with Russia; Whereas, then-Ranking Member Schiff negotiated with Russian comedians whom he believed to be Ukrainian officials to obtain materials to damage the President of the United States politically; Whereas, according to a New York Times article on October 2, 2019, Chairman Schiffs committee staff met with the whistleblower prior to the filing of his complaint and staff members communicated the content of the complaint to Chairman Schiff; Whereas Chairman Schiff concealed his dealings with the whistleblower from the rest of the Intelligence Committee and, when asked directly in a television interview whether he had any contact with the whistleblower, he lied to the American people and said, we have not spoken directly with the whistleblower. Whereas, members of the Intelligence Committee have lost faith in his objectivity and capabilities as Chairman, with every Republican member on the Committee having signed a letter calling for his immediate resignation as Chairman; Whereas, Chairman Schiff has hindered the ability of the Intelligence Committee to fulfill its oversight responsibilities of the Intelligence Community, an indispensable pillar of our national security. Resolved, That The House of Representatives censures and condemns Representative Adam Schiff for conduct that misleads the American people in a way that is not befitting an elected Member of the House of Representatives; Representative Adam Schiff will forthwith present himself in the well of the House for the pronouncement of censure; and Representative Adam Schiff will be censured with the public reading of this resolution by the Speaker." I've called for a vote on this resolution as soon as possible. The American people deserve the TRUTH. THIS WEEK ON BUDDY'S BRIEFING On this episode of Buddys Briefing, we discuss Speaker Pelosis drug pricing bill that tanked bipartisan efforts to lower prescription drug costs, the situation in Syria, and the Democrats continued impeachment sham. Click here to check out episode 5. Click here to watch this episode of Buddy's Briefing FROM OUR NATION'S CAPITOL CCXXXVIII Monday, October 14, 2019: Folds of Honor is a national foundation whose mission is to provide educational scholarships to spouses and children of our fallen and disabled service-members. Their motto is - "Honor their sacrifice. Educate their legacy." One of the many ways this great organization achieves this noble goal is through golf tournaments and today I am honored to participate in one of the largest Folds of Honor golf tournaments in Georgia at the Savannah Country Club on Wilmington Island in Chatham County. Organized locally by Dave Simons, I am honored to participate in the opening ceremonies by not only welcoming the golfers but also leading the Pledge of Allegiance to our flag. Also participating in the opening ceremonies is the St. Andrews School chorus who do an outstanding job of singing America the Beautiful and The Star-Spangled Banner. Later in the day I attend a meet and greet on Skidaway Island hosted by the Skidaway Island Republican Club. Tuesday, October 15, 2019: After an early morning flight, Im back in Washington and spend the remainder of the morning in staff meetings before recording a video for Veterans Day. Next, I meet with representatives from JCB, including my good friend Chris Giorgianni, to discuss tariff issues that could potentially impact the Savannah plant before beginning a series of interviews with potential candidates for a position on our Washington staff. Rep. Carter meeting with representatives from JCB Afterwards, I head to the Energy and Commerce (E&C) Committee room where I record a video on the upcoming National Prescription Drug Take Back Day then head back to my office where I meet with representatives from the Pharmaceutical Printed Literature Association. Rep. Carter meeting with representatives from the Pharmaceutical Printed Literature Association Next, I head to the House Visitors Center (HVC) for a GOP member update on the unprecedented and illegitimate impeachment inquiry that is being undertaken by House Democrats before heading to our weekly Whip Team meeting where we hear from U.S. Secretary of Defense Mark Esper regarding the situation in Syria. Rep. Carter recording a Public Service Announcement for National Prescription Drug Take Back Day After recording a video for the conservative Republican Study Committee (RSC) for the rollout of our health care framework, I head to the House Chamber for our first vote series of the day and afterwards, remain in the Chamber to pay tribute to my good friend from Brunswick, Dr. Pat Godbey, who has recently been sworn in as the President of the College of American Pathologists. A link to my tribute can be found here. Wednesday, October 16, 2019: My day begins with a member meeting of the E&C Committee where we discuss tomorrow's mark-up as well as other anticipated agenda items for the full committee and sub-committees in the upcoming weeks. Afterwards, I head to our weekly GOP Conference before heading to an E&C joint Communications and Technology (CT) and Consumer Protection and Commerce (CPAC) Subcommittees hearing on fostering a healthier internet. A link to my questions can be found here. Next, I have a meeting with representatives from the pharmaceutical manufacturers to discuss Part D restructuring before heading to a hearing in the E&C Health Subcommittee on reversing the youth tobacco vaping epidemic. A link to my questions can be found here. After attending the conservative RSC weekly meeting, I head back to my office where we have our weekly staff briefing before heading to the House Chamber for our first and only vote series of the day. Next, I head to the HVC where we have a GOP House member meeting with Sen. Lindsey Graham to discuss the latest on the ongoing unprecedented and illegitimate impeachment initiative before heading to the Capitol Rotunda where I film this weeks Buddys Briefing. After returning to my office for a scheduling meeting, I head to the Senate where I participate in a roundtable discussion on climate change with Conservation International, a group whose mission is to empower societies to responsibly and sustainably care for nature, our global biodiversity and the well-being of humanity. Among the board members of Conservation International who attend the meeting are actor Harrison Ford and retired Wal-Mart CEO Rob Walton. Thursday, October 17, 2019: There is a cloud of sorrow over the Capitol this morning as we learn of the death last night of Rep. Elijah Cummings (D-MD), the hard fighting and well-respected Chairman of the Committee on Oversight and Reform. I served on this committee my first session in Congress and worked closely with then-Ranking Member Cummings on an issue that we shared a common interest in - prescription drug pricing. I found Rep. Cummings to be a fair and honorable man. His district and our nation will miss his leadership greatly. A link to coverage on my statement of Rep. Cummings' passing can be found here. My morning begins early with a hearing in the Select Committee on Climate Change on cleaner, stronger buildings where I have the opportunity to highlight the State of Georgias role as the number one forestry state in the nation and the importance of wood products to absorbing carbon in our atmosphere. A link to my questions can be found here.  Rep. Carter at the E&C mark up on health care bills Afterwards, I head to an E&C full committee markup on four health care bills, including H.R. 3, Speaker Pelosis prescription drug price bill, as we begin at 10:00 a.m. and debate and vote on the various amendments and substance of these bills until 8:00 p.m. The only interruption during this marathon session is a vote series at 1:45 p.m. Of the four bills that we debate and vote on, we spend 9 hours and 40 minutes on H.R. 3 and 20 minutes on the other 3 bills. H.R. 3 is controversial to say the least and passes on a purely partisan vote with myself and my fellow Republicans voting against it for fear that not only will this lead to a halt in new drug development due to a stop in research and development, but also is the first step toward socialized medicine. A link to some of my comments during this mark-up can be found here. Friday, October 18, 2019: Im at the White House early this morning as Im assisting some constituents to gain access on what is a beautiful Fall morning in our Nations Capital. Once back at the Capitol, I head to the House Chamber where I pay tribute to Ludowici Mayor Pro-tem Mark Cheeser, who recently passed. A link to my tribute can be found here. After heading back to my office, I return to the Chamber a little while later for our first and only vote series of the day during which we pay tribute to our dear friend, Rep. Elijah Cummings. After a return flight home to Savannah, I head straight from the airport to Richmond Hill where I am honored to have the opportunity to speak to the Richmond Hill football team before their game and to perform the coin toss as the Wildcats faceoff against the Glynn Academy Red Terrors. Next, I head to the annual Great Ogeechee Seafood Festival at J.F. Gregory Park where, like so many who have come before me, I stuff myself with some of the best seafood anywhere. Keep scrolling for the latest from the U.S. Senate this week, and click here or the image below to watch my weekly video message.    Wild and Wonderful West Virginia I spent the first two weeks of October back home in West Virginia, which was great! I had the chance to visit with constituents from all across our state and hear about how the work we’re doing in Congress is affecting them. From ways programs in our state are playing a role in creating drug-free communities, to how industry professionals and community leaders are working to increase tourism in our state, it was great to hear so many stories and ideas. What’s important to West Virginians is important to me, and this feedback is critical as I continue to advocate for West Virginia priorities in Washington. Click here or the image below to watch a quick recap of my visits around our beautiful state.    Advocating for West Virginia Priorities Earlier this week, Senate Democrats’ introduced a resolution of disapproval under the Congressional Review Act to overturn the Affordable Clean Energy (ACE) Rule—a commonsense alternative to the Obama-era Clean Power Plan (CPP). West Virginians know all too well how devastating the Clean Power Plan would have been to our energy economy. That’s why I strongly supported the ACE Rule as an alternative, because it allows states and energy producers to reduce emissions at an achievable pace without cutting back on jobs or economic growth. That’s also why I voted against the Democrats’ effort to block the ACE Rule, which would have meant a revival of the devastating Clean Power Plan. West Virginians don’t have to choose between a clean environment and a thriving economy. We demand both; and with the ACE Rule, we can achieve both. Click here to read my full statement and click the image below to watch my floor remarks urging my colleagues to vote against this resolution.  Also on Wednesday, I advocated for our West Virginia miners on the Senate floor where I again urged my colleagues in Congress to act soon to protect the pensions of our nation’s retired coal miners. I have worked in a bipartisan way with others in the delegation, as well as my colleagues here in the Senate over the past several years to support legislation that stabilizes the mine worker pension fund and protects these men and women. These hardworking men and women deserve the pensions that they were promised, and we should make sure they receive the benefits they earned by passing legislation to protect their pensions this year. Click here or the image above to watch my full remarks on this. How Can We Help?  Whether you need help with a casework issue or have a question about scheduling a meeting at one of my offices, my staff and I are ready to assist you. Learn more about the services we offer at .  You can also submit your feedback and share your stories with me by visiting my “Share Your Stories” webpage here: /ShareYourStories. Calling All Students!  Last week, I posted my internship applications for spring 2020. If you want a hands-on experience in public service, check it out! Applications are due December 6. More details on my website here:  Social Media Recap                            Join me on Facebook, Twitter, and Instagram for regular updates and photos. Click here!                                              Dear Cormack,  Following a busy week in Washington, here with a few important updates and information on a number of key issues.    A Better Deal for America's Students  Whether it’s learning new skills through a certificate program, community college, or university, a post-secondary education has never been more important to securing a good career. It’s also never been more expensive. That’s why this week, along with my colleagues on the Education & Labor Committee, I helped introduced the College Affordability Act (CAA) (H.R. 4674), a bill that would overhaul our higher education system to lower the cost of post-secondary education, simplify the student loan repayment process, protect veteran-student borrowers, and ease the burden of student debt that millions of Americans are facing so that they can begin to participate in our economy in other ways. The benefits of making college more affordable and accessible aren’t just limited to the students earning the degrees – our entire economy will benefit from a more qualified workforce, and from Americans who aren’t saddled with such a crushing amount of college debt.   Included in the CAA are several provisions that I’ve worked hard to advance with my colleagues on both sides of the aisle of the Education & Labor Committee. For example, the CAA would help to ease student debt by allowing for current borrowers to refinance their loans down to today’s more competitive market rates – precisely what was proposed in my bill, the Bank on Students Emergency Loan Refinancing Act (H.R. 1707).  The CAA also improves the Public Service Loan Forgiveness Program by establishing a much-needed oversight and appeals process at the Department of Education, and expands the program to additional Veterans’ Service Organizations and farmers, which is what we proposed in the Young Farmers Success Act (H.R. 3232), a bill I introduced in June. The CAA is good for veterans in other ways, too – the bill would finally close the 90-10 loophole, which currently incentivizes shady for-profit schools to aggressively recruit our Armed Services members and veterans because their G.I. Bill benefits and Military Tuition Assistance are not counted toward their federal dollar maximum.   The College Affordability Act will save Americans money, create new opportunities for folks to access post-secondary educations that they previously may not have been able to afford, and will help better align our system of higher education with changing demographics and industry demands. I’m proud to support the bill, and look forward to working in bipartisan fashion to get it across the finish line.          Click here to watch Congressman Courtney discuss the recently introduced College Affordability Act     Lowering Prescription Drug Prices for Millions of Americans  The cost of healthcare, particularly the cost of prescription drugs, is a top-line issue for people in eastern Connecticut, and for millions across our country – we're paying drug prices that are nearly 4 times higher than other countries for the exact same prescription drugs, made by the exact same manufacturers. That’s why I’m a co-sponsor of H.R. 3, the Lower Drug Costs Now Act, a bill that was just recently introduced that would give Americans a better deal on prescription medication by allowing for Medicare to negotiate with pharmaceutical companies for fairer, lower drug prices – the kind of prices they offer to other countries, but not to us. Yesterday, my colleagues and I on the House Education & Labor Committee voted to approve the Lower Drug Costs Now Act, a major step forward that sets the bill up for a final vote by the full House.   Last week, my newsletter was focused squarely on how the House of Representatives is working to lower the cost of prescription medication. We're waging that fight on two major fronts: the Strengthening Health Care and Lowering Prescription Drug Costs Act (H.R. 987), a bill the House already passed in May which would help bring lower-cost generic drugs to market more quickly; and H.R. 3, the Lower Drug Costs Now Act, a bill to finally allow the Secretary of Health and Human Services to negotiate the best deal possible for American patients, and bring our prices more in line with what patients in other countries pay. Yesterday’s committee approval of H.R. 3 brings us one step closer to passing the bill here in the House, and I’ll keep working with my colleagues on both sides of the aisle to ensure that the House continues to get the job done on lowering the cost of health care. Watch some of my remarks from yesterday’s committee markup below.         Click here for Congressman Courtney's remarks during the House Education & Labor Committee hearing on the Lower Drug Costs Now Act     Protecting Social Security  Earlier this month, Social Security announced that recipients will receive a 1.6% cost of living adjustment (COLA) increase to their annual benefits in 2020. The bottom line is that a 1.6% increase doesn’t come close to covering what seniors need. It’s true that any COLA increase is welcome news, but this announcement was a stark reminder that the system is fundamentally flawed – the current method of measuring necessary benefit adjustments for Social Security just doesn’t take into account the true costs incurred by seniors, and COLAs like this aren’t keeping pace with the real value of a dollar. It's another reminder of why we need to pass Rep. John Larson's bill, the Social Security 2100 Act, which would implement a new and improved COLA method that measures the real-life costs of seniors, and would protect benefits for the next 75 years and beyond. The bill also provides an increase in benefits, reforms the cost of living increase formula to better reflect a senior citizens’ budget, and would give over 12 million Social Security recipients a tax cut by eliminating the tax on their benefits.   Social security is not an entitlement – it’s an insurance program paid into over the course of a lifetime. I’m proud to co-sponsor the Social Security 2100 Act, you can read more about the bill here.     Support for the Agent Orange Exposure Fairness Act   This week, I was grateful that the Disabled American Veterans (DAV) organization and the American Veterans (AMVETS) organization both joined the growing chorus of endorsements from veterans’ service groups in support of my bill, the Agent Orange Exposure Fairness Act (H.R. 566). The bill addresses a gap in our VA system that overlooks some Vietnam and Korean War Veterans who were exposed to the toxic chemical known as Agent Orange during their service, and who are now living with serious illnesses caused by that exposure. The system in place now requires that servicemembers demonstrate that the symptoms of their illnesses developed within a year of exposure in order to receive care – a totally unrealistic and onerous requirement to place upon veterans who should be focused on recovery, not on digging up decades-old documents to get the care and compensation they deserve. H.R. 566 eliminates these onerous and unfair requirements, and would give all servicemembers who were exposed to the pesticide access to the benefits they’re entitled to.    Both DAV and AMVETS are organizations made up of thousands of veterans serving other veterans – they are strong advocates for the millions of men and women who served our country. Their support and that of local veterans like Gerry Wright, who have done so much to raise support for H.R. 566, is critical to getting this bill across the finish line. You can read more about the Agent Orange Exposure Fairness Act – including the history of the bill, letters from supporting Veterans Service Organizations, and more – on my website, here.         Click here to read AMVETS' full letter of support     Responding to the President's Decision to Withdraw Troops from Northern Syria  On Wednesday, the House voted on an overwhelmingly bipartisan basis to pass H.J. Res 77, a resolution to rebuke President Trump’s decision to withdraw U.S. troops in northern Syria, effectively abandoning our Kurdish allies in the region. Kurdish forces in northern Syria have stood with America against ISIS when we’ve needed it most – they've sacrificed alongside US troops, and to abandon them with no plan in sight is to abandon decades of American leadership in the region.   Last week, I joined Congressman Jason Crowe (CO-06), a combat veteran who served three tours in the Middle East, and 56 of my colleagues in the House in writing to President Trump to warn that his decision to withdraw U.S. troops from northeastern Syria in advance of a known Turkish military operation puts U.S. allies in danger, and harms ongoing counter-ISIS efforts. You can read the full letter here.  The decision to withdraw U.S. personnel from the area is penny-wise and pound-foolish – U.S. military forces had a small presence in the area to begin with, but the cost of withdrawing them is steep. The decision dramatically alters our partnership with our Kurdish allies, who we rely on to guard thousands of ISIS prisoners, makes way for uninhibited Turkish incursions into Syria, and jeopardizes counter-ISIS efforts. The decision introduces uncertainty into U.S. foreign policy that will cause current and future allies to question the reliability of the U.S. as a partner, and invites further instability in this region. I was glad to see the House come together in bipartisan fashion this week to condemn the decision, and to express support for our Kurdish allies.         Congressman Courtney presides over the House floor during the vote opposing troop withdrawal from Northern Syria     I hope you enjoyed this snapshot of my work, and, as always, thank you for taking a moment to read my weekly update. If you have any questions or concerns about the information in this newsletter, you can contact me through my website or by calling my Norwich district office at 860-886-0139.      Have a great weekend,                                    Joe CourtneyMember of Congress                            OFFICE LOCATIONS        Washington, DC Office 2332 Rayburn HOBWashington, DC 20515Phone: (202) 225-2076Fax: (202) 225-4977 Norwich Office 55 Main Street, Suite 250Norwich, CT 06360Phone: (860) 886-0139Fax: (860) 886-2974 Enfield Office 77 Hazard Ave, Unit JEnfield, CT 06082Phone: (860) 741-6011Fax: (860) 741-6036           |            p { margin-bottom:1em; } /***** SMARTPHONE STYLING RULES *****/ @media only screen and (max-width: 497px) { body, td, div, span, p {font-size:40px !important;} a { text-decoration:none; } *[class*="container"] { width:100% !important; table-layout:auto !important;} *[class*="footer"] td { font-size: 12px !important;} *[class*="mobileimg"] { width: 300px !important;} *[class*="mobile-hidden"] { display:none !important; } *[class*="mobileshare"] img { width: 288 !important; height: 50 !important;} }

body: View this email in your browser (Friends and neighbors, The District Work Period from late Sept. to early Oct. had me happily traveling to all corners of our rich, diverse, and beautiful 44th District, and meeting with many of the constituents I so proudly serve. ** In the District: ------------------------------------------------------------ Veterans Welcome Home Event Very honored to host our 2nd Annual Veterans Welcome Home Event in Wilmington. This event gave veterans and their families the opportunity to connect with other members of the Vets community over a delicious lunch along with a chance to learn about dozens of valuable programs, services and resources to aid their transition into civilian life. These fine folks stood up for us in uniform and Im proud to stand up for them in Congress! Port of L.A.s All-Electric Top Loaders My team and I proudly celebrated California Clean Energy Day at the Port of L.A. to showcase their brand new, worlds-first, fully electric cargo top-handlers. These twin marvels can load, unload and stack cargo containers weighing upwards of 45,000 pounds while boasting zero-emissions! As a Member of the House Committee on Energy and Commerce, Im fighting to turn the Port of L.A. into the worlds first EMISSIONS-FREE port! WLCAC Meeting Had another great and insightful meeting with the amazing leadership team of the Watts Labor Community Action Committee, discussing their tireless and hugely impactful work in our community. The WLCAC has been providing incredible services to the Watts community for nearly 55 years, and Im incredibly proud to have them as one of the strongest and most effective pillars of our community. North Long Beach Neighborhood Associations My team and I hosted a lunch and chat with the leadership of the North Long Beach Neighborhood Associations. Had a chance to provide a great group of engaged CA44 residents an update on my work in this Congress and to talk about the constituent services my office provides. Also discussed: redistricting, infrastructure along the Artesia Corridor, the 2020 Census, immigration, LA County voting and more. Meeting with neighborhood associations is vital to my ability to serve our district. So, if I havent yet met with yours yet, PLEASE INVITE ME out! Hispanic Heritage Month and the High Holidays These last two weeks also saw the conclusion of Hispanic Heritage Month, the annual celebration of past leaders of the Latino community who paved the way forward for this current generation. This time was also saw the High Holidays, the most sacred of holidays for people of the Jewish faith. Hoping those celebrating Hispanic Heritage Month, and observing the High Holidays had a wonderful experience doing so! If you have any questions, please do not hesitate to contact my office.
