Some of the things we did this past week were:    I announced my co-sponsorship of a bill to establish a National Heritage Area (NHA) in Northeast Florida. NHAs promote cultural, natural and historic sites of importance in Northeast Florida and will boost our local economy. I spent time in our community, met with local organizations and businesses and went undercover as a United Sates Postal Service mail carrier.  I discussed the Turkish invasion of Syria and my bill to impose sanctions on Turkey with America’s Newsroom.  Please follow my daily work on social media by liking my Facebook page and following me on Twitter, Youtube and Instagram. As always, feel free to reach out to my offices in Florida or Washington, D.C. if my team or I can ever be of service.  In service,   Michael Waltz  NATIONAL HERITAGE AND NORTHEAST FLORIDA: Northeast Florida is one of the most beautiful, most historic areas in our country. Last week, fellow Florida Reps. John Rutherford, Al Lawson Jr. and I announced new legislation to make Northeast Florida a National Heritage Area. The Nation’s Oldest Port National Heritage Area Act will preserve our history, environment and bring tourism and jobs to our communities. We'll be working hard to get this bill passed very soon!    Meeting with a representative of the St. Augustine Lighthouse & Maritime Museum, where Rep. Rutherford and I announced the Nation’s Oldest Port Heritage Area Act  FACETIME IN FLORIDA: One of my favorite parts of being your Congressman is visiting with people like you, learning more about local businesses and sharing all our community has to offer. This week I visited Super Petrel USA  in Ormond Beach and flew in one of their amphibious test planes over the Halifax River, met with local veterans at the Daytona Beach Veterans Affairs Outpatient Clinic, discussed the Institute for Water and Environmental Resilience with Stetson University President Wendy Libby and spoke at the Tiger Bay Club of Volusia County.   Going on a test flight over the Halifax River in the Super Petrel Light Sports Biplane   Visiting a centenarian veteran of World War II and the U.S. Army Air Corps   Speaking at the Tiger Bay Club of Volusia County  UNDERCOVER CONGRESSMAN: If you live in Holly Hill, I may have delivered your mail last week! For the latest episode of Undercover Congressman, I joined the United Sates Postal Service as a mail carrier! I learned all about the hard work that goes into delivering mail to our community, rain or shine! There are over 340,000 mail carriers in the U.S. Did you know that 100,000 of those are veterans and 40% of mail carriers are women? I love visiting local businesses and living a "day in the life" of my constituents. So far, I've delivered packages with UPS, served chicken sandwiches and waffle fries at Chick-fil-A, dipped ice cream for customers at Dairy Queen, hand-tossed pizza dough at Giuseppe's Steel City Pizza and delivered mail with the USPS. Stay tuned to see where I head next!   Click below to watch me talk about my time going undercover and all the hard work that goes into delivering your mail:       Delivering mail with the United States Postal Service SYRIA AND AMERICAN PRIORITIES: I'm working with my colleague Rep. Liz Cheney in the House and Lindsey Graham in the Senate on bills imposing sanctions on Turkey. The decision to withdraw our specialized forces in Northeastern Syria is an enormous risk for our national security because now our Kurdish allies have no support to fight ISIS. Instead, they are fending off the Turks and ISIS prisoners are escaping as we speak. I'm very troubled by the situation in Syria. With more ISIS fighters on the loose, we could easily see a resurgence of terrorism and an ISIS 2.0 following us home. I'm working with Rep. Liz Cheney and Sen. Lindsey Graham on a sanctions package to punish Turkey for invading Northeast Syria. We must show support for our Kurdish allies and do what we can in Congress to stop Turkey's aggression in Syria.    Click below to watch me discuss Syria and sanctions against Turkey in full:       As a reminder, please follow my daily work on social media by liking my Facebook page, and following me on Twitter, YouTube and Instagram. As always, feel free to reach out to my offices in Florida or Washington, D.C. if we can ever be of service. Thanks for reading!  In Service, Michael Waltz Member of Congress                    Washington, DC 216 Cannon House Office BuildingWashington, DC 20515Phone: (202) 225-2706 Deland Office 120 South Florida Ave.Suite 324Deland, FL 32720Phone: (386) 279-0707 Palm Coast Office 31 Lupi CourtSuite 130Palm Coast, FL 32137Phone: (386)-302-0442 Port Orange Office Port Orange City Hall1000 City Center Circle2nd FloorPort Orange, FL 32129Phone: (386) 238-9711          Unsubscribe | Privacy  Open in browser window     Open plain text version

Here's a recap of my work for our district:       Getting Results for Our Veterans     On Tuesday, the House passed my bill to make health care more accessible to veterans with disabilities. The VA Website Accessibility Act would direct the Secretary of Veterans Affairs to conduct a study and submit a plan to Congress that would make VA websites accessible and understandable for veterans affected by blindness or hearing loss.  Our servicemembers put themselves in harm’s way to protect American freedom. It is only right that Congress uphold our end of the promise by giving disabled veterans the care they earned. I’m grateful the House has advanced my effort to eliminate barriers preventing some of our bravest men and women from receiving quality medical care, as well as disability, vocational, and educational benefits.        Watch as I speak in support of my bill to help veterans with disabilities.       Leading Efforts to Protect Our Chesapeake Bay     Last week, I met with my office’s Chesapeake Bay Advisory Board to inform our region’s stakeholders about my legislative efforts to improve the health of the Chesapeake Bay.  Last month, the House Transportation and Infrastructure Committee passed my bill - Chesapeake Bay Program Reauthorization Act - and recommended it for a vote in the full House of Representatives.  We also discussed how I advocated for the House passage of $110 million in funding for important environmental priorities. This funding included $85 million for the Environmental Protection Agency's Chesapeake Bay Program.     The Chesapeake Bay is an invaluable economic, environmental, and recreational resource that we must keep clean and thriving for future generations. I will continue to lead bipartisan efforts to preserve and protect this national treasure.      It was great to meet with my office's Chesapeake Bay Advisory Board and discuss how we can keep the Chesapeake Bay healthy for many years to come.       Standing By Our Allies     After the President decided to withdraw U.S. forces from the Syria-Turkey border and abandoned our Kurdish partners in the process, I demanded clarification on the President’s strategy.  As Turkish forces conducted an offensive military campaign into northeastern Syria, I joined over 50 fellow lawmakers in asking for answers. Together, we wrote a letter with 10 detailed questions about the administration’s plans going forward. We stressed that the U.S. has a national security and moral responsibility to maintain a presence in Northern Syria and support our Kurdish Syrian Democratic allies.  The President’s decision betrays the trust of the United States and undermines the security of our faithful Kurdish allies. In real time, the President is degrading America’s ability to respond to resurgent ISIS actions and future regional threats in the Middle East.       It was a pleasure to show French Ambassador Philippe Etienne around the USS JOHN C STENNIS with Vice Admiral Andrew “Woody” Lewis. Aircraft carriers are the centerpieces of our maritime strategy and critical to our national security.       On a lovely Thursday afternoon, I toured Colonial National Historial Park on the Peninsula and met with National Park Service leadership. This beautiful park has a rich history and offers therapeutic benefits to all. We’re so lucky to have it in our community!       I enjoyed meeting Veterans of Foreign Wars Post 3160 in Oceanview. I thank them for their service and I am honored to advocate for them in Congress.       I want to provide you with content that is tailored towards your interests! Check all the subject areas that you would like to receive tailored updates for.  Gun Violence   Health Care   Economy   Defense   Infrastructure   Environment   Veterans   Education       Click here to open in a separate window.           I enjoyed telling you about my week and I look forward to telling you about many more! Please follow my official Facebook and Twitter pages, and check out our website.  I hope that you will take some time to read the news articles below.    House passes Congresswoman Elaine Luria bill to help disabled veterans Congresswoman Luria highlights environmental priorities with Chesapeake Bay Advisory Board Rep. Elaine Luria demands clarification on withdrawal of U.S. troops from Syria      It’s the honor of my lifetime to serve you and Virginia’s Second Congressional District in the U.S. House of Representatives. As always, you have my word that I will continue working hard each day, and I welcome your thoughts!       P.S. If you have friends, family, and colleagues who would like to receive newsletters and other updates from my office, please forward this email to them and have them sign up here!         Washington, DC Office 534 Cannon HOBWashington, DC 20515Phone: (202) 225-4215 Virginia Beach Office 283 Constitution DriveOne Columbus Center, Suite 900Virginia Beach, VA 23462Phone: (757) 364-7650Fax:(757) 687-8298 Eastern Shore Office  25020 Shore Parkway, Suite 1B Onley, VA 23418Phone: (757) 364-7631 Peninsula Office 105 Professional Parkway, Suite 1512Yorktown, VA 23693 (757) 364-7634                 Unsubscribe | Privacy  Open in browser window     Open plain text version

The trip was part of an initiative by the Bipartisan Policy Center’s Congressional Exchange Program to bridge the partisan divide and build relationships between Members of Congress. Even though Congresswoman McMorris Rodgers and I may not agree on 100% of the issues, we found that there is a lot that unites us.   Video: Rep. Trone and Rep. McMorris Rodgers discuss rural broadband  Manufacturing In honor of National Manufacturing Day, Congresswoman McMorris Rodgers and I toured Accra-Fab, Inc., Kaiser Aluminum, and Hotstart - three manufacturing plants in Eastern Washington. Manufacturing is key to creating good jobs and lasting economic growth for Americans. The Congresswoman and I are both committed to advocating for the hardworking people of our districts.    Rep. Trone and Rep. McMorris Rodgers pose for a selfie and visit Accra-Fab, Inc. to learn about production and jobs  Rural Broadband Congresswoman McMorris Rodgers and I are also united on the issue of rural broadband. Broadband is essential infrastructure for education, health care, and businesses. That’s why I’m a proud cosponsor of the Congresswoman’s Broadband Data Improvement Act of 2019, which would revamp the mapping process so federal and private providers can better service our rural communities.  Thank you to Congresswoman McMorris Rodgers for hosting me and to the Bipartisan Policy Center for sponsoring this trip. When we come together to work toward common goals, we can create positive change for all Americans.  As my team and I continue to work on the issues that are important to you, don’t forget to follow my official Twitter, Facebook, and Instagram pages to stay in touch and let me know how we can do better.  My district office staff is also available to provide assistance with federal agencies. If you are experiencing problems with federal services such as Medicare or veterans' benefits, please contact the office at (301) 926-0300. We will work hard to ensure that your problem is resolved.  Sincerely,  David TroneMember of Congress     Please do not reply to this email.To share your thoughts please visit my website.    Unsubscribe

body: /* Client-specific Styles */ body { width: 100% !important; margin: 0px;} .ReadMsgBody { width: 100%; } .ExternalClass { width: 100%; display:block !important; } /* Force Hotmail to display emails at full width */ /* Reset Styles */ body { margin:0; padding: 0; } img { outline: none; text-decoration: none; max-width :100%;} br, strong br, b br, em br, i br { line-height: 100%; } h1, h2, h3, h4, h5, h6 { line-height: 100% !important; -webkit-font-smoothing: antialiased; } table td, table tr { border-collapse: collapse; } p { margin-bottom: 1em; } table.menu-change a { text-decoration:none; } /* pre-header */ .preheader { display:none !important; visibility:hidden; mso-hide:all !important; font-size:0px; color:#ffffff; line-height:0px; max-height:0px; max-width:0px; opacity:0; overflow:hidden; }     A message from Congresswoman Ann Wagner                                About Contact Services Media Center Issues                    Dear Lindsey,  Every year my office holds the 2nd Congressional District Art Competition where we invite students from Missouri’s 2nd District to enter their most creative pieces of artwork. I always enjoy seeing this beautiful creativity on display in my office and this year was no exception. We held our annual exhibition at the district office in Ballwin to meet the students who entered this year’s competition and announce the 2019 Best in Show award. Congratulations to Mia Kukorola from Lindbergh High School for winning this year’s prize. Her artwork will be displayed in the U.S. Capitol!  I met with local advocates from the Alzheimer’s Association to hear their personal experiences with Alzheimer’s and discuss ways we can partner together. Over five million Americans are living with Alzheimer’s and there is still a long way to go on the path to discovering scientific breakthroughs in prevention and effective treatment. I appreciate their dedicated advocacy as we work to fund research for cures and treatments for diseases such as Alzheimer’s.  This week I joined my colleagues and Gold Star mothers to honor the sacrifices made by their children in service to a nation that is forever grateful. Gold Star mothers are women of great conviction and have bravely experienced incredible hardship. As moms we advocate and fight for a strong America that can defend our freedoms and support those who put themselves in harm’s way.  I strongly support legislation protecting patients with preexisting conditions. Unfortunately, legislation the Democrats put on the floor this week was a political ploy that had nothing to do with preexisting conditions. Rather, it would reduce innovation in the healthcare field and hamstring a state’s ability to reduce premiums and help people access tailored healthcare plans. We should be working to make healthcare more affordable and more accessible to Missourians and all Americans, not restrict states that are trying to address the specific needs of their citizens. A standalone bill to protect individuals with preexisting conditions could pass right now, and I am a cosponsor of such legislation. But Democrats instead are passing legislation that would lead to raised premiums and ignoring bipartisan bills that would protect those with preexisting conditions. I cosponsored Rep. Walden's bill to protect those with preexisting conditions, H.R. 692, the Pre-existing Conditions Protection Act of 2019. I met with constituents from the Missouri Association of Insurance Agents to discuss how important it is that the National Flood Insurance Program (NFIP) is extended by Congress and not allowed to lapse. Extending NFIP will better protect homeowners and stabilize the housing market, and I am also committed to reauthorizing and reforming the program so it can best serve Missourians.   I spoke at a House Foreign Affairs Subcommittee hearing on China’s attempts to erode America’s influence through predatory trade and investment practices. In Missouri, exports support 88,000 jobs, almost 20% above the national average. China must be held accountable for its damaging trade policies, but we must be targeted and ensure that American consumers and business do not shoulder the consequences.    This week I spoke at our Financial Services Committee markup in support of Rep. Carolyn Maloney’s beneficial ownership legislation that fights human trafficking and exposes criminals who make money from exploitation. Traffickers launder money through shell companies and too often evade criminal liability. It is essential we have a transparency law to expose those who are profiting from trafficking.    Sincerely,   Ann WagnerMember of Congress                                        Washington, DC Office435 Cannon House Office Building Washington, DC 20515Phone: 202-225-1621    Ballwin District Office301 Sovereign CourtSuite 201Ballwin, MO 63011Phone: 636-779-5449               Click here to open this e-mail in its own browser window Click here to open a plain text version of this email If you no longer want to receive these emails, please click here to unsubscribe.  Please DO NOT reply to this email. body: Congressman Collin C. Peterson - Minnesota's Seventh Congressional District [image = *Parkers Prairie High School* *Dear Friends,* *October is National Principals Month, so I took the opportunity to spend the day at Parkers Prairie High School with their principal. I met with students to answer their questions about agriculture, education policy, and the need for mental health resources in schools. I also received the "Spirit of Enterprise Award" from the U.S. Chamber of Commerce in Alexandria for my continued support of businesses. October 6th was the start of National 4-H week and on Friday, Custom Products of Litchfield celebrated their 60th Anniversary. I called Secretary Perdue regarding agriculture disaster relief issues after hearing from farmers in the district. There have been numerous challenges this year for farmers and ranchers and the wet harvest conditions have made it even harder.* *Sincerely,* [image = Congressman Collin C. Peterson Minnesota 7th District * [image = the 7th* * Weather in Minnesota* Western Minnesota was hit by heavy rain, snow and freezing conditions last weekend. The storm further complicated harvest for farmers in the 7th District who have been kept out of the field by excessive rain. I have been watching this situation closely and keeping the U.S. Department of Agriculture aware of the conditions our growers are seeing. If you believe your farm is facing unique circumstances that are related to the weather, please contact my office at 202-225-2165. * Upcoming Service Academy Night* My office hosts Service Academy Information Nights to provide information for students who are interested in applying to a service academy. Our next Service Academy night will take place in Windom. If you have any questions about Service Academy nights, please contact my staff aide Meg Louwagie at Meg.Louwagie@mail.housegov [link 1]. Windom - October 21st, 2019 [link 2] * Parkers Prairie School Visit* [image = Parkers Prairie Principal Carey Johnson invited me to celebrate October as National School Principals Month [link 3]. I visited Parkers Prairie High School and had the chance to talk with students about farming and the meat industry, and visited with staff about mental health needs in school districts * Spirit of Enterprise Award* [image = *Ethan Hellier, Congressional and Public Affairs Manager for the Midwest Region of the U.S. Chamber of Commerce* On Monday, Ethan Hellier presented me with the 2019 "Spirit of Enterprise Award" from the United States Chamber of Commerce for my support of pro-growth policies in Congress. I am committed to helping small businesses throughout the 7th District, which is why I have been honored to receive the "Spirit of Enterprise Award" many times for my work over the years. I was also happy to spend time answering questions about agriculture, trade and other topics at the ceremony. Click here to see the award presentation [link 4] * Custom Products of Litchfield 60th Anniversary* * [image = *Top Left: Randy Renke / Bottom Right, Bob Kill, CEO of Enterprise MN* Custom Products of Litchfield recently celebrated their 60th Anniversary as a company. Since the company was founded in 1959, it has manufactured all sorts of custom safety products. Custom Products is a vital part of its local economy, employing nearly 150 people and bringing in revenue from all over the world. Randy Reinke, CEO of Custom Products, was also recognized for 40 years of service to the company. I am proud to represent such innovative businesses in Congress. * Minnesota West* [image = My staff Meg Louwagie attended the Pipestone Chamber Business After Hours event at the Minnesota West Campus. Minnesota West Community & Technical College has actively been working to improve the programing and facilities in all of their five campuses. Minnesota West employs 334 people and supports 1,140 jobs regionally generating an economic impact of $128.6 million. Over the past four years, Minnesota West secured $3.7 million in Minnesota Job Skills Partnership funding. This money has supported training for 3,210 people in over 14 district employers and 15,400 alumni are living and working in Minnesota. Each of the five campuses have recently undergone improvements. * Pipestone County Medical Center and Family Clinic Avera* * * [image = *Groundbreaking ceremony for Pipestone Medical Center* Five years ago, I attended the groundbreaking ceremony for the Pipestone County Medical Center (PCMC). This year, it was named as the 2019 Most Beautiful Hospital in the United States and I congratulate them for this recognition. Click here to read about PCMC's recognition [link 5] * National 4-H Week* [image = October 6-12 was National 4-H Week [link 6]. I was a 4-Her and currently serve as co-chair the Congressional 4-H Caucus. I am happy to support 4-H in their partnership with Cooperative Extension because 4-H empowers young people across the country through hands-on educational opportunities in agriculture, STEM, leadership development, and other fields that prepare them for success. * Minnesota Council of Non-Profits* [image = *Marie Ellis with MN Council of Non-Profits and Tiffany Gourley with National Council of Non-Profits* Marie Ellis from the Minnesota Council of Nonprofits and Tiffany Gourley from the National Council of Nonprofits visited my Washington office to talk about the impact of non-profits across the state and our policy proposals to fix the current rates for volunteer mileage reimbursements. I appreciate their efforts to get this issue solved, and we will keep working on ways to update mileage reimbursements in the tax code. * Fall Tamarack Trees* [image = Tamarack trees are unique because they are Minnesota's only native deciduous conifer. Every fall, Tamarack trees lose their leaves and beautiful foliage. The picture was taken a couple of miles north of Gully. * Exploring Tribal, County, and Municipal Cooperation in Minnesota* [image = Dr. Mitchell Berg, the Mahnomen City Administrator presented his doctoral dissertation and findings at the White Earth Tribal and Community College. His research focused on 35 Minnesota tribes, counties, and municipalities and will help further explore what elements are crucial to promoting cooperation between different levels of government. * Social Security Announces Benefit Increase for 2020* [image = Social Security announced a 1.6 percent cost of living adjustment for beneficiaries of Social Security. Social Security is a vital program that ensures our seniors can support themselves no matter their income. I am a proud cosponsor of H.R. 860 the Social Security 2100 Act, which would keep Social Security strong for future generations. [image = As hunting season winds up, share some of your thoughts about the hunting opportunity and challenges in your area. body: Congressman Carol Miller ?      Dear Friend, I h-i??? I hope you had a great week and are enjoying this beautiful Columbus Day weekend! As for myself, I had a busy week touring our great state! Last weekend, I hosted a Service Academy Day for high school students to meet with representatives from each of our nation's military academies. I was inspired to see so many young people willing to serve their country and I wish them the best as they embark on this new endeavor. ?????????????? ? On Tuesday, I addressed employers and job seekers at the Huntington Area Job Fair. I was happy to meet with so many local businesses looking to get members of our community back into the workforce. Thank you to the Huntington Regional Chamber, the Huntington Area Development Council, Workforce West Virginia, and the West Virginia Department of Commerce for putting on this great event. ? ? I was honored to welcome Senators Capito and Manchin to the beautiful Fayette County to discuss our recent legislation redesignating the New River Gorge as a National Park and Preserve. Thank you to all members of the community who attended for a productive conversation and your thoughtful input. It is my goal to preserve the natural beauty of the region, protect hunting and fishing areas, and increase tourism to our great state. Afterwards, we stopped for a bite to eat at the Secret Sandwich Society! If you are in Fayetteville, I encourage you to grab lunch at this delicious restaurant. ? ? I closed out the week by touring the quarry at RBS in Lewisburg! This local business has been providing the supplies used to build the Greenbrier Valley. It is operations like these that play a major role in improving our state's infrastructure and give West Virginia its unique character. Following my tour, I talked with community leaders in Greenbrier County about how I can better serve their needs and make this area a wonderful place to live, work, and raise a family. Thank you to all who participated. I am committed to building up our infrastructure, creating new jobs, and diversifying the economy. To end my week, I visited the Blue Sulphur Springs Pavilion. I love seeing our state's historical structures. If you have a free day, I recommend visiting this beautiful sight with friends or family. ? As always, do not hesitate to reach out to any of my offices in Washington, Huntington, Beckley, and Bluefield. I am here to help you and greatly value your input. name: Congressman Richard Hudson
subject: We're all getting older
body: Congressman Richard Hudson, 8th District of North Carolina *Friends, * *We are all getting older. *There are no ifs, ands or buts about it. People say with age comes more wisdom and more kindness - and a lot of wrinkles and grey hair.* As the stories we tell our kids get longer and longer, our memories get shorter and shorter. *But as a famous American architect once said, "The longer I live, the more beautiful life becomes." *Every day, I make it a top priority to ensure our nation's elderly and veterans are cared for.* I have worked tirelessly to protect Social Security and Medicare for our current seniors while strengthening it for future generations. I've worked to lower drug costs at the pharmacy counter and I am committed to ensuring you can access affordable, high-quality health care. *I have consistently been recognized as a "Guardian of Seniors' Rights" by leading seniors' groups for my work to keep our promises to today's seniors and future generations while cutting wasteful government spending.* I continue to fight for reforms to save your tax dollars over the long term and pave the way for a Medicare system that promotes higher quality care for seniors while strengthening the doctor-patient relationship. Last year, I was proud to support the *Strengthening Protections for Social Security Beneficiaries Act of 2017* (H.R. 4547) to improve protections for the millions of Social Security beneficiaries who rely on a representative payee to administer their monthly benefits. *President Donald Trump signed the bill into law, and we've made good progress, but there is still much more work to do.* I'm glad to see this Administration continue to put caring for our nation's seniors at the top of the to-do list. [image = President Donald Trump signed an Executive Order to strengthen Medicare. *On October 3, President Trump doubled down on that commitment by issuing an executive order to protect and improve Medicare for our nation's seniors. *In his announcement, President Trump said he will continue to build on aspects of the program that work well, including the market-based approaches in the current system. The executive order will allow seniors more choices to pick a plan that fits their needs. Additionally, it will eliminate excessive billing requirements and allow doctors to spend more time with patients. *By doing this, we will help empower patients to select and access the right care, at the right time, in the right place, from the right provider.* As a nation, another promise we've made is to honor the service and sacrifice of our nation's service members.* Last week I was fortunate enough to honor a World War II soldier and present his sister the awards he earned in service. *Private First Class (PFC) Raymond Vick was killed in action in Worms, Germany during WWII when his sister, Jean Brady, was just 8 years old. I was able to track down his WWII Victory Medal and the WWII Honorable Service Lapel Pin after they were lost for 74 years. [image = Presenting PFC Vick's WWII medal to his sister, Jean. *The ceremony took place in Carthage where I was blessed with the opportunity to present these awards to his sister. *PFC Vick was born in Nash County in November 1924. He enlisted in the U.S. Army in 1943 in the Infantry. He served in General George Patton's 3rd Army as a member of A company, 355th Infantry Regiment, 89th Infantry Division. He was only 21 years old at the time of his death on March 26, 1945. *As your Congressman, I stand ready to ensure our country keeps the promises made to senior citizens and veterans.* *Until next week,* * [image = *Richard Hudson* *Member of Congress (NC-08)* [image = [link 1] [image = [link 2] [image = [link 3] [image = [link 4] [image = [link 5] [image = [link 6] [image = [link 7] [image = [link 8] ---------------------- footnotes ---------------------- [link 1] [link 2] [link 3] [link 4] [link 5] [link 6] [link 7] [link 8] Website: Office Locations: Washington, DC Office 2112 Rayburn House Office Building Washington, DC 20515 Phone: 202-225-3715 | Fax: (202) 225-4036 Hours: M-F 8:30am-6:00pm Concord Office 325 McGill Avenue, NW, Suite 500 Concord, NC 28027 Phone: (704) 786-1612 Fax: (704) 782-1004 Hours: M-F 8:30am-5:30pm Fayetteville Office 225 Green Street, Suite 202 Fayetteville, NC 28301 Phone: (910) 997-2070 Fax: (910) 817-7202 Hours: Tues/Thurs 8:30-5:30pm and by appointment Pinehurst Office Sandhills Community College Logan Building 3395 Airport Road, Suite 221 Pinehurst, NC 28374 (910) 246-5374 Hours: Tues/Thurs 8:30am-5:30pm and by appointment Privacy Policy: Unsubscribe:

name: Congressman Buddy Carter
subject: ICYMI: We must expand telehealth for veterans
body: ICYMI: WE MUST EXPAND TELEHEALTH FOR VETERANS In case you missed it, I wrote an article in The Hill this week about the need to expand telehealth for veterans and legislation I introduced to address this. Click here to read my article. We must expand telehealth for veterans By Rep. Earl L. "Buddy" Carter The 1st District of Georgia has a rich military heritage and one of my greatest honors is serving the service members and veterans in Southeast and Coastal Georgia in the U.S. House of Representatives. Although a couple hours from home, many of our veterans travel to Charleston, S.C., or Lake City, Fla., in order to receive care from the Department of Veterans Affairs (VA) hospital and medical facility. I, too, often visit these facilities to see how we can improve the care these heroes receive. On a recent visit to the Charleston facility, we discussed a number of barriers that are standing in the way of better care for veterans. One serious concern is the VAs current limitations on telehealth. The VA Mission Act, which I was proud to support in Congress and was later signed into law by President Donald Trump in 2017, reformed multiple programs at the VA. It overhauled the Veterans CHOICE Program, improved the veterans caregiver program and aimed to modernize the VAs health care facilities. Additionally, the VA Mission Act authorized the VA to provide telehealth services across state lines. This is critical because these VA health facilities are now able to give care to veteran patients in the First District without forcing those veterans to travel hours to South Carolina or Florida to be seen by a physician. However, while were making important strides in telehealth at the VA, there is still a big problem. While at the Charleston VA medical facility, I learned that only doctors are allowed to use telehealth systems and trainees are not permitted to use the program. Just like in any health care system, students, interns, residents and fellows are critical components of the VA. They use these professionals in every aspect of care. These medical providers have graduated medical school and are training to become full-time doctors. They need access to the telehealth system so they are able to get the experience necessary to provide the best possible care to veterans once they are fully licensed. Additionally, allowing this population of health care professionals to use the telehealth system will increase access to this important care by increasing the number of providers. That is why I introduced H.R. 3228, the VA Mission Telehealth Clarification Act in the United States Congress. My legislation authorizes trainees to use the telehealth program under the supervision of an appropriately credentialed VA medical professional. This will allow better access to VA health care as well as better prepare future doctors to use the system. Our veterans served our nation and deserve access to the best possible care when they return home. Increasing the use of telehealth at VA health centers is critical to ensure veterans are able to receive the care they need no matter where they live. The VA Mission Telemedicine Clarification Act is only one small step to improve the health care system for veterans, but it is an important step that should be taken immediately FROM OUR NATION'S CAPITOL CCXXXVII Monday, October 7, 2019: Now in its fourteenth year, the Buddy Walk, sponsored by the Lowcountry Down Syndrome Society (LDSS), is held in Forsyth Park in downtown Savannah every year and this past Saturday drew thousands of people. LDSS is a family support group for people in the greater Savannah and Lowcountry area that have been touched by Down syndrome. I was very proud to join my brothers from the Band of Brothers on Saturday as we supported our good friend and fellow member Joe Marchese and his beautiful daughter Ella at the Buddy Walk. Rep. Carter at the Buddy Walk This is a special event for me, as well, as I grew up with an aunt who had Down syndrome and have fond memories of the joys and challenges my grandparents had raising a child with Down syndrome. My Aunt Jean was an integral part of our family. She was always accepted and included everywhere we went. I can still remember my family going out to eat at Williams Seafood in Savannah with my grandfather in his suit and tie with his arm extended and my Aunt Jean holding on as if he were walking her down the wedding aisle. Later Saturday morning I was able to stop by the Georgia Republican Leadership Academy held at the American Legion Post 184 in Thunderbolt to speak to them. On Sunday afternoon I was back at Forsyth Park as I attended one of the best events anywhere, Picnic in the Park, Savannahs largest outdoor musical event. Rep. Carter at Picnic in the Park Sponsored by the City of Savannah and others, this beloved event featured not only students from local schools and colleges, but also the US Army 3rd ID band and, of course, the world-class Savannah Philharmonic. What a great event! Im in Atlanta today as I have a number of meetings in the area before joining Governor Brian Kemp and others at the Georgia GOP 2019 Chairmans Dinner. Tuesday, October 8, 2019: After arriving back home late last night, my first event of the day is at the Georgia Tech Savannah Campus as I speak at the Georgia Alternative Fuel Vehicle and Clean Technology Showcase and share with them my experiences as a member of the Energy and Commerce (E&C) Committee. As a member of the E&C Environment Subcommittee as well as the Select Committee on Climate Change, we have considered many bills dealing with autonomous vehicles, electric vehicles, compressed natural gas vehicles, and much more. Rep. Carter at the Georgia Alternative Fuel Vehicle and Clean Technology Showcase Afterwards, I head to our Savannah office where I have a very productive meeting with a representative from the Savannah Freedom Society followed by a meeting with representatives from Twin Pines Minerals regarding their proposed project in Charlton County. Next, I meet with representatives from Coastal Empire Habitat for Humanity to learn more of the great work they are doing in the Savannah area before heading to Hinesville in Liberty County to meet with constituents from Liberty and Long Counties. Afterwards, I head to Cogdell in Clinch County where I meet with a number of constituents from the area. Wednesday, October 9, 2019: Im up early this morning as I head to the Coastal Heritage Society Battlefield Memorial March in downtown Savannah where we honor those who fought and sacrificed for our freedom on the 240th anniversary of the Battle of Savannah during the Revolutionary War. Rep. Carter at the Coastal Heritage Society Battlefield Memorial March The Battle of Savannah was one of the Revolutionary Wars most pivotal battles and is where Gen. Casimir Pulaski was killed. Complete with soldiers clothed in uniforms from that period who marched along the same path as the original battle, participants laid wreaths in Battlefield Park during a commemorative ceremony. Afterwards, I head out to Richmond Hill Montessori Preschool in Bryan County where I read to a group of preschool classes in celebration of Georgia Pre-K Week.  Rep. Carter with students at Richmond Hill Montessori Preschool Of the three books that I read, I have to say that my personal favorite was Llama, Llama Red Pajama. Afterwards, I head to midtown Savannah for a meeting with a constituent before heading to the Savannah Area Realtors Luncheon at the Hellenic Center in downtown Savannah where I am honored to be their guest speaker.  Thursday, October 10, 2019: Im at Lake Raybun in North Georgia this weekend for my youngest sons wedding and this morning I have a conference call with my good friend Col. Daniel Hibner, Commander of the Savannah District of the US Army Corp of Engineers, to discuss a project in the district. Later, I have a phone interview with The Capitol Forum to discuss new Committee on Foreign Investment in the United States (CFIUS) rules that are being proposed that would give the agency the authority to review non-controlling investments in 28 new categories, including some in the chemical industry. Afterwards, I have a phone conference with representatives from JCB in Savannah to discuss new tariffs being levied by the administration that could potentially negatively impact their business. body: Congressman Bruce Westerman, Representing the 4th District of Arkansas Greetings! As beautiful fall weather marks the start of harvesting season, I hosted my annual farm tour this week, with stops ranging from Ozark to Pine Bluff. This tour is always a highlight of my year, since farmers and ranchers are the lifeblood of both our state and national economy. One of the topics that came up frequently was levee breaches and flood damage from earlier this year. I got to see the sand that's covered part of a farmer's fields and visit a flooded pump station with the Army Corps of Engineers, and I know how much this damage has negatively affected farmers' ability to plant and harvest in a timely fashion. Of course, the question is, "What happens now?" We began talking through local solutions with the Corps during a Farm Bureau meeting in Paris, and I'm also working on the Water Resources Subcommittee in Washington to address infrastructure issues on the federal level. To learn more about each of my stops this week and see photos, keep reading below. I have the utmost respect for farmers in Arkansas and across the country who dedicate their lives to working the land, and it's my honor to meet you and represent you in Congress. Until next week, Bruce Westerman Arkansas' Fourth District *By subscribing to my email updates, you are authorizing me to send regular email updates from my office to your email account. *Visiting with a constituent in Mulberry* **2019 Farm Tour** I started the week in Mulberry at USDA grant kickoff event. Mulberry and Waldron are two communities in the Fourth District that USDA selected to receive Rural Community Development Grants. FFA taught me so many incredible life skills, and I could talk for hours about what I learned from the program. Ozark High School [link 2] was kind enough to let me speak to their FFA students as part of my farm tour. Like I mentioned, flood damage has severely impacted our crops this year. James Patterson of Patterson Soybean Farm showed me aerial footage of how the flooding affected his farm in Lavaca. Big River Roller is a new manufacturing business in Paris, and I stopped by for a tour while I was in the area. Colonel Eric Noe with the Army Corps of Engineers showed me the flood damage to a pump station in McClean Bottom. He also pointed out several of the breached levees in the region. This tour will be helpful to me as I work on policy in the Water Resources Subcommittee. I visited Fourche River Farm and Cattle Co. in Harvey. The Hickl family welcomed me into their home to talk about the challenges and opportunities that come with cattle farming. True southern hospitality! I met with the Jefferson County Farmers Working Group at Dell-Cam Farms, which is owned by the Goldmon family. The Goldmons are the 2019 Farm Bureau Farm Family of the Year in the Southeast District! I held two roundtable discussions with the Arkansas Farm Bureau, one in Paris and one in Pine Bluff. We discussed labor issues, trade negotiations and infrastructure issues. I wrapped up my tour at a Tyson's chicken processing plant. Not only does this location provide hundreds of jobs to the area, but it also represents the last stop in an agriculture chain that spans the entire state. ---------------------- footnotes ---------------------- [link 1] [link 2] Contact Information: Website: Office Locations: Washington, DC 209 Cannon House Office Building Washington, DC 20515 Phone: (202) 225-3772 Fax: (202) 225-1314 El Dorado 101 N. name: Congresswoman Carolyn Maloney
subject: Wrapping Up the District Work Period
body: Congresswoman Carolyn B. Maloney Dear Lindsey, I love being home here in NYC during District Work Periods because I get to spend time hearing directly from you about the issues you care about and what you want to see me working on when I return to Washington, DC. This past week was a busy one! On Monday, I joined community leaders in mourning the four homeless men who were brutally murdered and speak out on behalf of New Yorkers experiencing homelessness. On Tuesday, I assembled a roundtable with experts to talk about the importance of reauthorizing the Terrorism Risk Insurance Act. And last night, I hosted an Impeachment 101 Town Hall with special guest former Congresswoman Elizabeth Holtzman. More on all this below. *Homeless Slayings Vigil* [image = On Monday, I joined Assemblymember Yuh-Line Niou and the Chinatown community to mourn the deaths of four innocent men after a brutal attack that also left another man in critical condition. This tragic incident makes it all too clear that the city needs to do more to protect the 60,000 New Yorkers experiencing homelessness, including thousands of especially vulnerable unsheltered individuals. I promise to continue to fight for comprehensive federal programs to help individuals find and retain adequate and safe housing. Without the protection and privacy of a home, our homeless neighbors face a much greater risk of violence. Everyone has the right to the safety and dignity of a home, and we must do everything we can to guarantee that right to every New Yorker. *TRIA Roundtable* [image = The magnitude and importance of the Terrorism Risk Insurance Act cannot be overstated. TRIA provides critical government backup to private insurers in the event of a terrorist attack and is especially vital to the economy of New York City. After the terrorist attacks on 9/11, insurers realized that they could not accurately model for terrorism risks because they simply did not have all the information they needed to predict where a terrorist attack is most likely to happen, and how likely it is to occur. As a result, the market for terrorism insurance completely shut down. Without terrorism insurance, construction stopped and thousands of jobs were lost. And so, Congress came together in a bipartisan way to pass TRIA to provide a government backstop to ensure that terrorism insurance was not only available but also affordable - at no cost to taxpayers. We need to do the same now before the program expires at the end of next year. We cannot afford to let TRIA lapse and run the risk of high-target cities like New York losing construction jobs and the other economic benefits that come from new building projects. That's why I hosted a roundtable meeting this Tuesday with Rep. Nydia Velazquez, Rep. Gregory Meeks, and industry stakeholders to discuss how TRIA is working now, what improvements could be made in reauthorizing this legislation, and when Congress needs to act. TRIA is one of the most important issues before Congress and it must be renewed without disruption to coverage or lapse in renewal. *Impeachment Town Hall* [image = Thank you to everyone who joined me and former Rep. Elizabeth Holtzman last night in Brooklyn for our Impeachment 101 Town Hall! I felt it incredibly important to host an event where concerned New Yorkers could engage in a dialogue about the future of our democracy and learn more about the impeachment process. As one of the nation's strongest voices during the impeachment inquiry of President Richard Nixon, I'm grateful that former Brooklyn Congresswoman Elizabeth Holtzman was able to join us for this discussion and share her perspective. President Trump is jeopardizing our national security, in plain sight, and abusing his power for personal political gain. The oath of office that each Member of Congress makes requires us to take this solemn step to protect our democracy and defend the constitution. The seriousness of the impeachment investigation cannot be underestimated. *Snapshots from NY-12* * [image = Great to join the friends and loved ones of Cono D'Alto in Brooklyn on Saturday at his street naming ceremony. He was a dedicated businessman who provided food to families in need after 9/11, and I am so glad I got to present his family with a Congressional certificate recognizing his contributions to the community. [image = I was honored to participate in the 39th Annual Korean Day Parade on Saturday and celebrate the beauty and richness of Korean culture and the many contributions Korean Americans have made to New York! As always, your concerns still and always will remain my top priority. Please do not hesitate to email me through my website. [link 1] If you have any friends who you think should be receiving my newsletters, tell them they can sign up here. [link 2] Sincerely, [image = Carolyn B. Tina Smith for visiting Northfield this week!                              Hello all, It’s been wonderful to spend a beautiful couple of weeks visiting with you and working across the district as the leaves change. This week, I got to meet with the local leaders who are pushing for investments in transportation and infrastructure, tour small businesses in Northfield, and continue my healthcare listening tour to hold the vaping industry accountable. These are just a few of the big issues I hear from you about and am working to address. Through my work in Minnesota and in Washington, I am always looking for bipartisan, common-sense ways to work across the aisle to improve lives for our neighbors. In fact, to date, I have introduced 13 bills and cosponsored 261 more - 79% of which are bipartisan. Working across the aisle doesn’t make the cable news, but it’s important to me because it’s important to our community. If these are the kinds of ideas and efforts you are also passionate about, be sure to apply for an internship in my DC or Burnsville offices! Applications are open for spring 2020 internships. Follow this link to find out how to apply. In the District  Celebrating young farmers: This week is National 4H week! CD2 is home to so many dedicated 4H-ers working for a bright future for Minnesota’s ag economy.     Bringing nutrition to schools: This week, I was proud to announce the beginning of the Farm to School Program. Our kids deserve healthy and nutritious foods, no matter where they live, and by bringing together Minnesota farmers, school districts, and community partners, Farm to School creates meaningful community ties and healthier schools across Minnesota. I highly encourage schools in my district to apply for these grants to connect more students to our farming community. More information on how to apply can be found here.  Investing in airport infrastructure: The Minneapolis St. Paul Airport employs hundreds of folks from CD2 and helps connect Minnesotans to the rest of the world. House Transportation and Infrastructure Committee Chairman Peter Defazio and I are committed to providing the resources they need to operate with world class safety and service. We toured the Minneapolis St. Paul Airport this week and heard from officials with the Metropolitan Airports Commission about the need for critical infrastructure improvements - including a unified incident command center.     Touring small businesses: Northfield is full of thriving businesses and friendly neighbors. Thanks to Sen. Tina Smith for spending an afternoon with me touring businesses and talking to folks about economic development in Northfield and Greater Minnesota.    Fighting for a fair shot: Thanks to Commissioner Steve Kelley from the Minnesota Department of Commerce for meeting with me earlier last week - looking forward to working together with you to lower health care costs for all Minnesota families!    Fall weekend in Cannon Falls: Fall in Minnesota is best spent in Cannon Falls. I got to spend an afternoon at the Ferndale Market’s Flavors of Fall Festival and grabbed some turkey products for the road!    Putting Minnesotans first: I sat down with Esme Murphy this past week to talk about my bipartisan work to improve the lives of Minnesotans and my responsibility to hold all of our elected officials accountable. Watch here.  Supporting local credit unions: Thanks to the folks at Firefly Credit Union for giving me a tour and for talking about the ways my fellow Small Business Committee Members and I can help grow our economy and improve the work of the Small Business Administration.     Building stronger infrastructure: I took a tour of the Hastings Lock and Dam with the St. Paul Army Corps of Engineers and Colonel Karl Jensen! This infrastructure is critical to the river economy that Minnesota farmers, businesses and families rely on for exports and imports to our communities.    Keeping kids safe: The vaping industry has put our kids’ health at risk. As part of my healthcare listening tour, I held a roundtable with doctors, school, and community leaders on how we can work together to reduce teen vaping and hold the e-cigarette industry accountable for this public health crisis. subject: Americans Arent Getting a Fair Deal on Medication

Click here!                                              Dear Cormack,  As I’ve traveled across eastern Connecticut in the past weeks, a concern that is often relayed to me by folks from all walks of life is that the cost of prescription medications have become so great, and have risen so quickly, that it’s making them sick – both figuratively and literally.    A woman from Vernon told me that the cost of one of her medications was more than 9 times as much in 2019 than in 2016, and that when she called her insurance company to inquire about the price increase, she was told that in fact she should have been charged more. A man from Sterling wrote to my office with news that the cost of his generic medication had risen by over 1000% in a calendar year. Another from Old Lyme said that the cost of his eye drops had risen by over 12,000%, with no explanation.   The rising cost of prescription medication is a top-line issue for folks here in eastern Connecticut, and for millions of Americans across the country. This week, I want to talk with you about what we’re doing in the House to curb the skyrocketing costs of prescription medication, and to give Americans a better deal.    Americans Aren’t Getting a Fair Deal on Medication  We know that one of the biggest concerns people have about the stability of their care is the skyrocketing cost of prescription drugs. 24% of Americans say that they didn’t fill a prescription last year due to high costs, and 19% say they skipped a dose or cut pills in half because they’re so expensive. These statistics are playing out right here in eastern Connecticut. Just recently, a woman from Eastford told me that the copay for her husband’s medication was $1,300 a dose, and that for the first time in their lives they were choosing to forgo doctor-prescribed medication because of cost.  Patients in the U.S. pay drug prices that are nearly four times higher than other countries for the exact same prescription drugs, sold by the exact same drug manufacturers. For Americans, the prices are rising without rhyme or reason. Last month at a House Education and Labor Committee hearing on the rising cost of prescription drugs, witnesses confirmed that Americans – from pediatric patients to seniors on Medicare – are being exploited by ridiculous spikes in drug prices, and that the cost of prescription drugs in the U.S. has exploded to a whopping 25% of premium dollars.          Lowering Prescription Drug Costs, Now  Drug manufacturers are using Americans as a piggy bank, and it’s time for it to end. That’s why I was proud to join as cosponsor of H.R. 3, the Lower Drug Costs Now Act, a bill just recently introduced in the House that would change the law by finally allowing for Medicare to negotiate with pharmaceutical companies for fairer, lower drug prices – the kind of prices they offer to other countries, but not to us.  As it stands now, the Department of Health and Human Services (HHS) is banned by law from negotiating with big pharma for better, fairer prices. The Lower Drug Costs Now Act would instruct the Secretary of HHS to negotiate fair prices for some of the most expensive prescription drugs, helping to lower costs for millions across the country. These lower prices would be available not just to Medicare beneficiaries, but also to those with private insurance.    The bill also prohibits manufacturers from raising their prices faster than inflation, and requires that they pay back profits on drugs sold to Medicare beneficiaries if they do. Also under this bill, Medicare would cap the amount that patients spend on prescription drugs for the first time ever – a huge savings for seniors with high drug costs. Last month, my committee held a productive hearing on strategies for lowering prescription drug costs and heard from experts and patient advocates who are asking Congress to pass the Lower Drug Costs Now Act. You can click here to watch my exchange with our witnesses.         Click here to watch Congressman Courtney's exchange at the House Education & Labor committee hearing on prescription drug costs last month     Encouraging Competition for Lower Prices  The Lower Drug Costs Now Act is a crucial step towards making sure that Americans are given a fair deal, but it isn’t the only step we’ve taken to curb the rising cost of prescription medication. We've already passed bipartisan legislation this year that takes the issue head-on.  In May, I voted to pass H.R. 987, the Strengthening Health Care and Lowering Prescription Drug Costs Act. This bipartisan bill tackles another aspect of unfair prescription drug pricing by helping lower-priced generic drugs get to market faster, offering Americans more low-cost options to choose from. Getting more low-priced prescription drugs into the market is a key way to create billions of dollars in savings for American consumers and taxpayers – in 2017 alone, the entry of generic drugs into the market saved us a total of $265 billion. That’s good for our wallets, but certain drug manufacturers are using anti-competitive practices to keep lower-cost alternatives off of our shelves. They keep generic manufacturers from obtaining samples of drugs to create alternatives, they purposefully delay the introduction of their own drugs to market, and they even pay off generic drug manufacturers to make sure that their high-cost drugs are the only ones we see on our drug store shelves.   H.R. 987 takes the issue head-on, and would finally put an end to many of these calculated practices that are contributing to the exploding cost of prescription medication. It should be reiterated that this bill is bipartisan – it passed the House with support from both sides of the aisle. However, it’s now among a long list of other House-passed bills that have not yet received a vote in the Senate. The bill is ready to go, waiting on Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell’s desk.    The rising cost of prescription medication is a concern that’s on the minds of many of our family, friends and neighbors who struggle to pay for lifesaving, or even just routine treatments. With price tags that are on average four times higher than in other countries, it’s plain to see that Americans aren’t getting a good deal. With bills like the Lower Drug Costs Now Act and the Strengthening Health Care and Lowering Prescription Drug Costs Act, the House is working in bipartisan fashion to give Americans a fair deal when it comes to prescription drugs. I was proud to help pass H.R. 987 earlier this year, and I look forward to joining my colleagues in voting to pass H.R. 3, the Lowering Drug Costs Now Act, when it comes before the House for a final vote.  I hope you enjoyed this snapshot of my work to lower prescription drug costs. As always, thank you for taking a moment to read my weekly update. If you have any questions or concerns about the information in this newsletter, you can contact me through my website or by calling my Norwich district office at 860-886-0139.      Have a great weekend,                                    Joe CourtneyMember of Congress                            OFFICE LOCATIONS        Washington, DC Office 2332 Rayburn HOBWashington, DC 20515Phone: (202) 225-2076Fax: (202) 225-4977 Norwich Office 55 Main Street, Suite 250Norwich, CT 06360Phone: (860) 886-0139Fax: (860) 886-2974 Enfield Office 77 Hazard Ave, Unit JEnfield, CT 06082Phone: (860) 741-6011Fax: (860) 741-6036           |            p { margin-bottom:1em; } /***** SMARTPHONE STYLING RULES *****/ @media only screen and (max-width: 497px) { body, td, div, span, p {font-size:40px !important;} a { text-decoration:none; } *[class*="container"] { width:100% !important; table-layout:auto !important;} *[class*="footer"] td { font-size: 12px !important;} *[class*="mobileimg"] { width: 300px !important;} *[class*="mobile-hidden"] { display:none !important; } *[class*="mobileshare"] img { width: 288 !important; height: 50 !important;} }

line-height:0px; max-height:0px; max-width:0px; opacity:0; overflow:hidden; }   @media screen and (max-width: 497px) { a { text-decoration: none;} .mobile-menu {font-size:20pt !important;} .mobile-content {font-size:28pt !important;} .mobile-footer {font-size:8pt !important;} }   News from Representative Steve Womack‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌          News from Representative Steve Womack          HOME   |   ABOUT STEVE   |   SERVICES   |   3RD DISTRICT   |   ISSUES & LEGISLATION   |   NEWSROOM      WEEK IN REVIEW To start off this week’s From the Front… I would like to thank all of the Arkansans who stopped by my Washington office during their visits to our nation’s capital, including Robert Martin of Centerton, the Clark family of Fayetteville, the Beecroft family of Rogers, the Crawford family of Harrison, and George and Rosemary Faucette of Fayetteville. Safe travels back to the Natural State!  It was another district work period, which means I got to spend time doing my favorite thing: traveling throughout Arkansas’s Third Congressional District!  I started my week in Centerton visiting some local small businesses and meeting with owners and employees. I stopped by Heroes Coffee Centerton and 72 West to learn about the companies and get a firsthand look at their operations. They are family-owned and operated and a great example of the entrepreneurial spirit of the Third District. Not only did I get a delicious cup of coffee, but I also saw a lot of hard work, ambition, and dedication to success. It’s important that the government doesn’t stand in the way of small business growth. We need to focus on implementing policies that further empower and create more opportunities for businesses to invest, grow, and create jobs.  I then headed to Bentonville to speak with the Wholesale Beer Distributors of Arkansas about the beer industry and its impact on jobs, the economy, and entrepreneurship. The beer industry provides millions of U.S. jobs, supports our economy, and is a sector that boasts businesses of every size. Arkansas has a strong beer sector; from brewers to distributors, we’ve seen a lot of success. I recently toured the Ozark Beer Company and heard firsthand how the Tax Cuts and Jobs Act allowed them to upgrade their equipment and hire additional staff. More brewers reinvesting in their companies also provides new opportunities for distributors. As companies grow and invest -  distributors can do the same. We discussed the system between manufacturer, distributor, retailer, and consumer, as well as the importance of their work to promote responsible alcohol consumption. I appreciated their time, conversation, and thoughtful questions.  Our region is home to many people willing to give back and improve the well-being of Arkansans. It was a privilege to watch the George and Simmons families receive the Excellence in Free Enterprise Award, presented by Economics Arkansas. The award honors those whose business acumen and entrepreneurial spirit have improved the lives of countless Americans across our state and nation. Additionally, Dr. Jim Rollins, Superintendent of the Springdale School District, was also recognized for his 35 years of service on the Economics Arkansas Board of Directors. Congratulations to the honorees on their accomplishments and dedication to AR-3.  The next day, I headed down to Fort Smith for a Q&A community meeting! We talked about a range of local and federal issues, including the national debt, infrastructure, economic growth, the partisan divide, and other challenges facing Congress. It's always great to be with city leaders, state representatives, the local fire department, and area educators!  Cancer is a word that changes everything. It’s a disease that not only impacts the person diagnosed; it also affects families, loved ones, and medical professionals. The Reynolds Cancer Support House provides cancer patients, survivors, and families with assistance and programs that make a difference in their lives. From patient emotional support and financial help, to transportation assistance and understanding treatment options, the facility brings hope and help to many going through the unthinkable. I was privileged to donate books to their library, which allows patients to get lost in a good story and spend some time reading. The Cancer Support House is changing lives, and I thank them for the work that they do each day. With October being manufacturing month, I headed over to Becko Machine Works. This manufacturing center integrates old fashioned machining experience and ingenuity with today's technology and innovation. They provide one-off parts and reproduction, welding, precision, general machining, milling, turning, and other services. I appreciated getting a firsthand look at their operation and meeting with employees on the floor. It’s always amazing seeing the work done in the district, and Becko Machine Works is providing products that help businesses throughout the River Valley and the U.S.   I wrapped up the week in Harrison, where I spoke at the John Paul Hammerschmidt Men of Distinction Award Ceremony. The event celebrates the legacy of public service that John exemplified by honoring men in the community who have shown great character and dedication to service. It was wonderful to celebrate those that have given back so diligently and selflessly for many years to Harrison and the surrounding area. Congratulations to the 2019 awardees, including Richard Hart, Mark Martin, Kevin Merrill, Joe Nance, Robert Shaddox, Jim Sprott, and Steve Turner.    Wishing Arkansas’s Third District a great weekend! Remember to keep an eye on my website or check out my Twitter and  pages to stay up-to-date with the latest news from the Third District and Washington.   Policy Update  As you may have heard, the Turkish military began an invasion of northeastern Syria and attacked the Kurdish forces who hold the area. This action was made possible by the withdrawal of the small number of U.S. forces who were in the region. Let me be clear, I think the decision to remove U.S. troops from the area was a mistake. The Kurds have been loyal allies who stood with us when others would not. Furthermore, removing U.S. forces from the area threatens the security of this volatile region and only empowers Iran, Russia, and - ultimately - ISIS.   Given my concerns with the situation, I have joined many of my colleagues in the House to support the introduction of legislation that will impose sanctions against Turkey in response to Ankara’s military offensive against U.S.-allied Kurdish forces in northern Syria. This move follows similar efforts led by Senators Lindsey Graham (R-SC) and Chris Van Hollen (D-MD) in the Senate.  President Erdogan and his regime must face consequences for attacking our Kurdish allies. These sanctions send a clear message: Congress won’t sit idly by as Turkey continues its destabilizing and reprehensible actions. Erdogan and his proxies must be held accountable for their misguided actions, and it is imperative that we implement these sanctions swiftly.    In addition to my support of these sanctions, I will also be looking at all potential options to protect our interests and those of our allies. In the coming weeks, Congress will be debating the annual defense policy legislation and, hopefully, the defense spending bill. During those negotiations, our nation’s security and the safety of our global partners will be at the forefront of my mind.    From the front... Here is a recap of everything that happened throughout the last week.       Securing a Pay Raise for Veterans     I am happy to announce that that the President has signed into law my bipartisan bill bringing a much-needed pay raise to American veterans.  Starting on December 1st, my Veterans’ Compensation Cost of Living Act will provide a cost-of-living increase for wartime disability compensation that mirrors the same increase as Social Security.  It’s a privilege to come to Congress and deliver much-needed support to our nation’s bravest men and women. Providing quality benefits to our veterans and their dependents can change lives.  Through this legislation, Congress is honoring its commitment to American heroes who served in harm’s way so that our nation can live in peace at home.       Connecting with Coastal Virginians at Last Week’s Town Hall     On Thursday night at New Hope Baptist Church in Virginia Beach, I fielded questions from constituents during our latest town hall. It was wonderful to engage with everyone, answer so many insightful and thoughtful questions, and point constituents toward helpful government agencies. I truly cannot thank everyone enough who made our town hall possible. I am especially grateful to the Virginia Beach Police Department for providing security and safety at the event, and to New Hope Baptist Church for lending us their beautiful space. Town halls are one of my favorite events to host because they allow me to connect with our community. While time constraints prevented me from answering every question, I look forward to sending responses soon.       Meeting with VA Leadership to Advocate to Push for Better Care     Recently, I met with David Collins, the new director of the Hampton VA Medical Center. We had a productive conversation about improving access for patient care, reducing wait times, and increasing patient satisfaction for veterans living in the Hampton Roads region. It’s clear that this change in leadership can have a positive impact for veterans in our community. I look forward to regularly meeting with Director Collins to ensure that our local veterans receive the best possible care.       Opening New Doors for Veterans     On Friday, I had the opportunity to attend and speak at the Grow with Google & United Service Organizations (USO) Training in Virginia Beach. At this event, representatives from USO and Google facilitated networking opportunities and workshops to help veterans and their families develop skills, find jobs, and grow their careers. During my speech at the event,.  It was great seeing a service organization join forces with private industry to help our most heroic men and women. In today’s economy, it’s so important that we give veterans the resources they need to find fulfilling employment.       Full house at our Virginia Beach Town Hall! Thank you to everyone who attended.        On a fun Friday night, I attended the Kellam-Cox high school football game where I watched our talented #VA02 athletes and caught up with friends on both sides of the field.            I enjoyed meeting with leadership of the Virginia Beach Volunteer Squad and thanking them for all that they do for our community.          During our town hall, I had the opportunity to touch base with Michael Whiteside and his son. Previously, my staffer Caleb helped Michael with his naturalization application and he’s now a proud American!        It was awesome to meet with my fellow U.S. Naval Academy alumni in Williamsburg! Duty, honor, and loyalty have never been more important.       I want to provide you with content that is tailored towards your interests! Check all the subject areas that you would like to receive tailored updates for.  Gun Violence   Health Care   Economy   Defense   Infrastructure   Environment   Veterans   Education       Click here to open in a separate window.           I enjoyed telling you about my week and I look forward to telling you about many more! Please follow my official Facebook and Twitter pages, and check out our website.  I hope that you will take some time to read the news articles below.     Congresswoman Elaine Luria Secures Pay Raise for Disabled Veterans Luria urges McConnell to hold vote Gold Star Families bill Congresswoman Luria met with new director of Hampton VA Medical Center    It’s the honor of my lifetime to serve you and Virginia’s Second Congressional District in the U.S. House of Representatives. As always, you have my word that I will continue working hard each day, and I welcome your thoughts! P.S. If you have friends, family, and colleagues who would like to receive newsletters and other updates from my office, please forward this email to them and have them sign up here! Although deaths from breast cancer continue to fall, they’re declining at a slower rate than in previous years, and the number of cases we’re seeing is rising. It is very important that we take this valuable opportunity to talk about this dreaded disease and increase our knowledge on the topic.  The American Cancer Society estimates that there will be more than 271,000 new cases of breast cancer this year alone, 99 percent of which will be diagnosed in women. Of course, risk factors like age and genetics cannot be avoided, but there are steps you can take to lower your own breast cancer risk, and most of them are related to maintaining good health in general. The Center for Disease Control (CDC) recommends maintaining a healthy weight, exercising regularly, and getting regular screenings if you are older than 40.   Unfortunately, most of us have either faced a cancer diagnosis personally or been close to a friend or family member who has. Until we eradicate this terrible disease altogether, it is important to know about the resources available to those in the fight. Throughout my time in Congress, I have considered it a privilege to play in the Congressional Women’s Softball Game, a charity event benefiting the Young Survival Coalition (YSC). YSC aims to improve the quality of life for young adults affected by breast cancer. My team didn’t quite pull off a win during this year’s game, but I could not be prouder of what we accomplished. We raised more than $365,000 – a new record – to benefit YSC and their important mission supporting individuals battling breast cancer.  A cancer diagnosis is certainly never easy, but organizations like YSC make it possible to navigate these challenging circumstances, and I am grateful for their work. During the month of October, I encourage you to increase your own awareness about breast cancer and the risks associated with the disease and tell your loved ones to do the same. As with many other forms of cancer, early detection is critical and saves lives. If you are currently battling breast cancer, please know that my prayers are with you.  SECOND DISTRICT RESIDENT WINS DUCK STAMP COMPETITION    Did you know waterfowl hunters created the Federal Duck Stamp in 1934 as a way to ensure a funding source to conserve habitats for ducks and geese? Now, 85 years later, sales of these beautiful stamps to hunters, bird watchers, outdoor enthusiasts, and collectors have raised more than $1 billion, which has been used to protect 6 million acres of wildlife habitat in the United States. A couple of weeks ago, the U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service held its annual Federal Duck Stamp competition at Patuxent Research Refuge in Laurel, Maryland, and Eddie LeRoy of Eufaula won for the first time with his submission of a black-bellied whistling-duck pair, pictured above. Congratulations to this Second District resident! LAST WEEK IN THE DISTRICT  Since Congress is out of session for a district work period, I had the opportunity to take several meetings in my Montgomery office last week. I was glad to sit down with several groups of constituents and Alabamians, including: Representatives from New York Life    UPS    Folks from M1 Technologies    Camille Place    Representatives with ALS Alabama    It is an honor to serve you in Congress. Please never hesitate to let me know if there is a way my office can be of assistance.
