body: Congressman Bruce Westerman, Representing the 4th District of Arkansas Greetings! Members of Congress headed back to their districts this week, and I couldn't wait to be home in Arkansas. I've lived here my whole life, but I am still finding new places to explore. This week's tourism tour was the perfect opportunity to visit some of the beautiful campgrounds, shooting ranges, parks and more that we often take for granted. Arkansas may not be the first place that comes to mind when people think about tourism, but the Natural State has such a variety of historic buildings and outdoor recreation opportunities to enjoy. Whether you are interested in rock climbing, horseback riding, skeet shooting or camping with family, you can find a place that is perfect for you in the Fourth District. I had such a great week visiting these locations, meeting the people who own and manage them and discussing how we can better improve access to public lands. Outdoor recreation and tourism are key to our state's identity, and we are fortunate to have great people on the ground ensuring these opportunities are accessible and enjoyable. We are so blessed to have these fantastic opportunities for tourism and recreation right in our backyards. As cooler temperatures head our way, I hope you are able to take some time to enjoy the beauty of the Natural State with family and friends this weekend! Until next week, Bruce Westerman Arkansas' Fourth District Email Updates* *Yes, please per**iodically send me email updates.** *By subscribing to my email updates, you are authorizing me to send regular email updates from my office to your email account. *Visiting Hogskin Arena in Hampton with Calhoun County Judge Floyd Nutt* **Tourism Tour** I kicked off the tourism tour by rock climbing at Horseshoe Canyon Ranch in Jasper. This annual event brings hundreds of climbers from around the world to participate in a 24-hour climbing challenge. I visited two of our state parks, Poison Springs Battleground State Park and Moro Bay State Park. Thank you to Park Superintendent Paul Butler for showing me around! The Bradley County 4-H Forestry Team took home first place at the 40th Annual National 4-H Forestry Invitational! I was able to drop off copies of the Congressional Record, where they have been recognized for their achievements. *L-R: Ben Gilmore, Lieutenant Governor Tim Griffin, State Rep. Jeff Wardlaw, U.S. Rep. Bruce Westerman, Bradley County Judge Klay McKinney, Warren Mayor Denisa Pennington, Bubba York* Arkansas offers great opportunities for hunting, and I was glad to practice my shot ahead of duck season this fall. Special thanks to Warren Shooting Complex Owner Bubba York for hosting our group. One of the issues constituents frequently ask me about is access to public lands. I was grateful for the opportunity to sit down for a roundtable focused on ATV trail access in Madison County. *L-R: Michael Gregory, Scott Simon, Allison Fowler, Chris Colclasure, Bill Posey, Commissioner J.D. Neeley, U.S. Rep. Bruce Westerman, Jennifer Sheehan, John Chapman, Trey Buckner, State Sen. Bob Ballinger, Asa Ballinger, Mark Hutchings* My final stop was to the Madison County State Wildlife Management Area with the AR Game and Fish Commission and the Nature Conservancy, where we discussed efforts to restore our nation's wildlife. ---------------------- footnotes ---------------------- [link 1] Contact Information: Website: Office Locations: Washington, DC 209 Cannon House Office Building Washington, DC 20515 Phone: (202) 225-3772 Fax: (202) 225-1314 El Dorado 101 N. Click here!                                                 Dear Cormack,  Following a busy start to the District Work Period spent across eastern Connecticut, I'd like to share with you some of the key visits and updates from this week.  Highlighting National Manufacturing Day  Today, on National Manufacturing Day, I was joined by State Senator Norm Needleman for a visit to Sound Manufacturing in Old Saybrook to tour the facility and to hear from a few of their on-site employees. Sound Manufacturing is a full-service precision sheet metal fabrication manufacturer that helps to build high-powered machinery like leaf and debris truck loaders, industrial vacuums, and a variety of parts for use in a wide range of products. The company was recently recognized by The Hartford Courant as one of best workplaces in Connecticut – an impressive feat for a deserving organization. Employing 77 workers from across the region, Sound Manufacturing offers quality, high paying jobs with comprehensive benefits while also promoting employee development and career growth. Organizations like Sound Manufacturing are a great example of how a businesses can flourish while also investing in their workers, and it was great to receive an update on their activity on National Manufacturing Day. From the new House-passed National Defense Authorization Act, to the groundbreaking on a massive new production facility on our coastline, to the recent data showing that eastern Connecticut is outpacing the state and the nation in terms of growing manufacturing jobs, there has been no shortage of good news for our region when it comes to manufacturing. Sound Manufacturing in Old Saybrook is an important part of eastern Connecticut’s impressive manufacturing portfolio. I’m grateful to President and CEO Kelli-Marie Vallieres for a chance to visit them this afternoon, and for her continued leadership in southeastern Connecticut’s small business community.        Rep. Courtney receives a tour of Sound Manufacturing from President & CEO Kelli-Marie Vallieres     Update on Federal Funds for Crumbling Foundations   As many readers of this newsletter know, addressing eastern Connecticut’s crumbling foundations crisis and finding more resources to provide financial relief to its victims is one of primary focuses in Congress. This week brought news on both fronts. First, on Wednesday, the towns of Vernon, Ellington and Stafford hosted a community forum for homeowners to learn more about the new resources made available by the federal Community Development Block Grant (CDBG) pyrrhotite testing program. The program provides funding to homeowners for pyrrhotite testing, and at Wednesday’s forum folks had a chance to ask questions and receive personalized guidance on how to navigate the CDBG application process.   I first identified these federal funds as a potential source of crumbling foundations aid back in 2016, and in March of this year I was glad to announce that Vernon, Ellington and Stafford had received approval for $480,000 in CDBG funding to support the testing of concrete foundations for pyrrhotite. This is a positive development, but it should be noted that although these CDBG funds can be used for testing, there is no federal mandate that requires them to be used solely for that purpose – the State of Connecticut should get creative, and work to expand the use of these federal dollars so that they can provide relief to homeowners in other ways, too. Thanks to all who participated on Wednesday, and to the individuals who made this important informational event available to homeowners.  In addition to the update on new federal resources, I visited Birth Grove Primary School in Tolland this morning for an update on the school’s efforts to chart a path forward after the discovery of the school’s crumbling foundation. I was joined on the tour by a team of researchers from Laval University in Quebec, who studied the effect of pyrrhotite in concrete following Canada’s own concrete foundations crisis, giving them a unique understanding of the impact that crumbling foundations can have on homeowners and communities. I was also glad to be joined by a representative from the National Institute of Standards and Technology (NIST), who will be conducting research on our crumbling foundations crisis thanks to my House-passed amendment that provides them with funding to do so. It was an important opportunity to have them all at Birch Grove this morning, and I want to extend a thank you to each of them for their valuable input and their continued support.         Rep. Courtney was joined by researchers from Laval University and a representative from NIST for a tour of Birch Grove Primary School     Bringing Farms to Schools   I had a great time on Tuesday at Charles Barnum Elementary School in Groton, where I was joined by representatives from Groton Public Schools for an update on the recent U.S. Department of Agriculture’s (USDA) Farm to School (F2S) program, and the recent USDA grants awarded throughout our region that are making this curriculum possible.  Both Charles Barnum Elementary School and Catherine Kolnaski STEAM Magnet School have implemented the collaborative F2S program, which connects schools with local farms to help students learn more about farming and sustainable agriculture, and to eat healthier by providing locally sourced food in school meals. And that's not all – the F2S program also helps support our region’s farmers and their small businesses. F2S helps educate students on the importance of organic and nutritious diets, how to plant and garden, and brings farmers and educators in our community closer together to benefit our youth. It was great to see the program in action in Groton, and soon other eastern Connecticut towns will be able to join in on this unique program – just recently, my office helped facilitate more than $81,000 in federal fund grants awarded through USDA that will support F2S programming in the Thompson and Putnam School Districts.  The USDA’s Farm to School program is great for our students, and for our farmers. I want to thank Groton public schools and the outstanding students at Charles Barnum Elementary for showing us how F2S is flourishing in eastern Connecticut.      Rep. Courtney visited Charles Barnum Elementary to see USDA's F2S Program in action     A Firsthand Look at Our Region’s Shellfish Industry   It was a beautiful morning in Madison today as I was joined by Agriculture Commissioner Bryan Hurlburt and State Senator Christine Cohen for a visit to Indian River Shellfish, a local, family-owned business who are busy farming some of the best oysters on the east coast. Owners George Harris and Mike Gilman gave us a behind-the-scenes look at how they farm their oysters and shellfish, as well as a tour of their primary farm in the lower Hammonasset River. George, a lifelong fisherman with a profound understanding of southeastern Connecticut aquaculture and shellfish growth, and Mike, who has dedicated his career to marine research and education, make the perfect team. George and Mike are impressive small business owners – they're looking to put Connecticut on the map when it comes to the oyster market, and they’re busy in the community, working with the towns of Clinton, Madison and Old Saybrook to restore shellfish beds and oyster reefs. It was great to have the opportunity to discuss Connecticut’s aquaculture and shellfish industry with the two of them, and to get to witness a real professional farm some of the freshest oysters you can find.   Thanks to Mike and George for hosting us this morning, and I look forward to visiting again soon.        Rep. Courtney visited Indian River Shellfish to meet with owners Mike Gilman and George Harris     I hope you enjoyed this snapshot of my work, and, as always, thank you for taking a moment to read my weekly update. If you have any questions or concerns about the information in this newsletter, you can contact me through my website or by calling my Norwich district office at 860-886-0139.    Have a great weekend,                                     Joe CourtneyMember of Congress                   OFFICE LOCATIONS        Washington, DC Office 2332 Rayburn HOBWashington, DC 20515Phone: (202) 225-2076Fax: (202) 225-4977 Norwich Office 55 Main Street, Suite 250Norwich, CT 06360Phone: (860) 886-0139Fax: (860) 886-2974 Enfield Office 77 Hazard Ave, Unit JEnfield, CT 06082Phone: (860) 741-6011Fax: (860) 741-6036           | Privacy Policy           p { margin-bottom:1em; } /***** SMARTPHONE STYLING RULES *****/ @media only screen and (max-width: 497px) { body, td, div, span, p {font-size:40px !important;} a { text-decoration:none; } *[class*="container"] { width:100% !important; table-layout:auto !important;} *[class*="footer"] td { font-size: 12px !important;} *[class*="mobileimg"] { width: 300px !important;} *[class*="mobile-hidden"] { display:none !important; } *[class*="mobileshare"] img { width: 288 !important; height: 50 !important;} }

body: /* Client-specific Styles */ body { width: 100% !important; margin: 0px;} .ReadMsgBody { width: 100%; } .ExternalClass { width: 100%; display:block !important; } /* Force Hotmail to display emails at full width */ /* Reset Styles */ body { margin:0; padding: 0; } img { outline: none; text-decoration: none; max-width :100%;} br, strong br, b br, em br, i br { line-height: 100%; } h1, h2, h3, h4, h5, h6 { line-height: 100% !important; -webkit-font-smoothing: antialiased; } /*ly, tr#221562, add same margin as margin-block-start/end*/ h1{margin-top:0.67em;margin-bottom:0.67em;} h2{margin-top:0.83em;margin-bottom:0.83em;} h3{margin-top:1em;margin-bottom:1em;} h4{margin-top:1.33em;margin-bottom:1.33em;} h5{margin-top:1.67em;margin-bottom:1.67em;} h6{margin-top:2.33em;margin-bottom:2.33em;} table td, table tr { border-collapse: collapse; } p { margin-bottom: 1em; } table.menu-change a { text-decoration:none; } /* pre-header */ .preheader { display:none !important; visibility:hidden; mso-hide:all !important; font-size:0px; color:#ffffff; line-height:0px; max-height:0px; max-width:0px; opacity:0; overflow:hidden; }         News from Representative Luria                                       Dear Friend, From standing up for our Gold Star families to pushing for critical infrastructure projects, it was another busy week in Washington! Here is a recap of my week.           Urging Senator McConnell to Hold a Vote on a Bill to Help Gold Star Families     On Thursday, I sent a letter to Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell, telling him to bring the SECURE Act for a vote on the Senate Floor.     Gold Star Families are immediate relatives of servicemembers who gave the ultimate sacrifice. The SECURE Act contains an important provision that I introduced to provide relief to Gold Star Families that experienced drastic tax increases due to President Trump's Tax Cuts and Jobs Act of 2017.     It is wrong that the Tax Cuts and Jobs Act caused Gold Star Families to see a tax hike. The House did its job when it passed the SECURE Act with overwhelming support. Senator McConnell must stop stalling support America's most heroic families and schedule a vote for the SECURE Act now.          Introducing Legislation to Help the Victims of May 31's Tragedy     Last week, I introduced the Virginia Beach Strong Act to help ensure donations to families of victims of the May 31 Virginia Beach mass shooting are tax-deductible.  On May 31, our Virginia Beach community experienced an unspeakable tragedy that led to the loss of 12 wonderful people. In the wake of our community's darkest day, we saw countless selfless people donate to provide relief for grieving families.  I am introducing this bipartisan and bicameral bill to make it easier to send more needed support to the grieving families.          Sending a Message to Congress: Fund Critical Defense Infrastructure Projects     I led a bipartisan letter to the leadership of the House and Senate Armed Services Committees, urging them to authorize critical funding for infrastructure projects in military communities. Our letter requested that the committees authorize the Defense Community Infrastructure Program (DCIP) at $100 million.  Last year Congress created the DCIP to assist state and local governments in tackling deficiencies in infrastructure. Unfortunately, Congress did not appropriate any funds to this program. DCIP grants can be used for projects that support military installations, but are outside of military installations. Examples include transportation development to ease traffic congestion and upgrades to hospitals, schools, utilities and more.  As a Navy veteran representing Hampton Roads, I know our military communities desperately need funding for infrastructure projects to promote readiness. The DCIP is a critical and overdue investment for our country. These projects are vitally important to the strength of our national security infrastructure and to the welfare of our servicemembers and their families.          Upholding My Oath     On a very sad day for our democracy, I called for the House to move forward with impeachment and issued the following statement: In the military and in Congress, I swore an oath to protect our Constitution against all enemies foreign and domestic. In recent days, credible information has emerged that President Trump sought to pressure a foreign government — Ukraine — to produce damning information on a political opponent. Furthermore, reporting suggests he threatened to withhold critical security assistance to Ukraine, a partner that is under direct assault from Russia, in exchange for the performance of this investigation. He put the foreign policy and national security of the United States at risk while doing so. This was clearly an attempt to leverage foreign involvement to bolster his reelection campaign and shows a total disregard for our democratic political process. It is clear to me that he has betrayed the public trust and abandoned his obligations to the Constitution by elevating his own interests over the national interest. Allegations of this gross misconduct meet the threshold of high crimes and misdemeanors set by the Constitution. Congress must investigate and use the full extent of its powers to check these alleged abuses of presidential power. The House must move forward with impeachment.     Throughout my career, I have made many hard decisions. You sent me here to make these choices and to do what's right for our nation.       Photo Contest Winner     I am pleased to announce the winning submission of our VA-02 Summer Photo Contest. Below is a beautiful snapshot of Mount Trashmore that caught my eye.      Mount Trashmore is a unique Virginia Beach landmark that our community knows and loves. This photo captures a beautiful and especially picturesque day in VA-02. It hits all the right marks and more!           It was great to meet Patrick Dempsey at the Congressional Families Cancer Prevention Program and to congratulate him on his great work for supporting families and caregivers fighting cancer.           I am glad to share the stage at the Atlantic Festival with my friends, Congresswomen Chrissy Houlahan and Abigail Spanberger! It’s a privilege to serve with fellow women veterans and national security professionals in Congress.          It was a pleasure to speak with Gold Star Families ahead of Gold Star Mother’s Day at The Library of Congress with my colleagues. We thank you for your service, your sacrifice. I’m advocating for you in Congress every day!       I want to provide you with content that is tailored towards your interests! Check all the subject areas that you would like to receive tailored updates for.  Gun Violence   Health Care   Economy   Defense   Infrastructure   Environment   Veterans   Education       Click here to open in a separate window.           I enjoyed telling you about my week and I look forward to telling you about many more! Please follow my official Facebook and Twitter pages, and check out our website.     I hope that you will take some time to read the news articles below.    LURIA LEADS OVERSIGHT HEARING TO IMPROVE MEDICAL ACCESS FOR EASTERN SHORE VETS Elaine Luria’s Bill to Protect and Preserve Chesapeake Bay Advances Out of Key Committee Rep. Luria to host town hall in Virginia Beach October 3    It’s the honor of my lifetime to serve you and Virginia’s Second Congressional District in the U.S. House of Representatives. As always, you have my word that I will continue working hard each day, and I welcome your thoughts!       P.S. If you have friends, family, and colleagues who would like to receive newsletters and other updates from my office, please forward this email to them and have them sign up here!         Washington, DC Office 534 Cannon HOBWashington, DC 20515Phone: (202) 225-4215 Virginia Beach Office 283 Constitution DriveOne Columbus Center, Suite 900Virginia Beach, VA 23462Phone: (757) 364-7650Fax:(757) 687-8298 Eastern Shore Office  25020 Shore Parkway, Suite 1B Onley, VA 23418Phone: (757) 364-7631 Peninsula Office 105 Professional Parkway, Suite 1512Yorktown, VA 23693 (757) 364-7634                 Unsubscribe | Privacy  Open in browser window     Open plain text version

Presidential Impeachment: Reviewing President Trump's actions in office  My office received dozens of calls from angry constituents who support the impeachment of President Trump after press reports detailed Trump's threat to withhold foreign aid from Ukraine unless President Volodymyr Zelensky conducted a baseless investigation into former Vice President Joe Biden and his son, Hunter.   On September 24th, House Speaker Rep. Nancy Pelosi announced that the House would conduct a full impeachment inquiry of President Trump's actions to determine whether they violate his oath of office.  Personally, I believe there is enough evidence to pursue articles of impeachment against this president already.  But I do fully support this inquiry in order to present the facts, so my House colleagues can reach their own conclusions.  I am proud to be one of the original supporters of Rep. Al Green's resolution, H. Res. 498, which called for the impeachment of President Trump on July 17, 2019.       Newark’s Water Crisis: Providing clean water to Newark's residents  I am extremely concerned about the elevated levels of lead found in Newark’s drinking water.  After all, my family and I drink this water with the rest of the city's residents. The health and safety of constituents is my #1 priority. Right now, my team and I are working with city, state and national officials to help do what needs to be done to get lead out of the water.  But I wanted to see the issue personally, so I volunteered to help my constituents get clean water at two local distribution facilities.  I was grateful to the staff at the Bo Porter Sports Complex and Boylan Street Recreation Center for what they do on a daily basis to help our community.  I enjoyed meeting with my constituents to hear their concerns about this crisis.         Congressman Payne, Jr. chats with residents and helps distribute bottled water.    We talked about their fears of living with tainted water.  I told them what I am doing to help, but also asked them if there were any other actions I could take to make sure a tragedy like this one doesn't happen again. There are many actions I've taken to try and solve the issue.  I introduced the Test for Lead Act in Congress already.  I co-signed and sent two letters: one to the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (find it here) to urge them to provide more assistance to Newark and the other to the U.S. Department of Agriculture (find it here) to expand access to SNAP and low-income food subsidies to cover the additional costs of bottled water.   In addition, I’m working with my colleague Rep. Grace Napolitano, chairwoman of the Committee of Transportation and Infrastructure's Subcommittee on Water Resources and the Environment, to find out how we might be able to help the city with federal funding or other resources.  Recently, I voted for legislation in the House that would allow communities the freedom to adjust their budgets to provide additional resources to their water treatment facilities in the event of an emergency.  The legislation passed both U.S. Senate and the U.S. House and it needs President Trump's signature to become law.    I believe federal funds are appropriate because what has happened in Flint, MI. and Newark shows that lead contamination from old pipes are a national concern. There are dozens of major cities and small communities across the country that could use an upgrade regarding the way water gets from the aquifers to the household faucets. If we solve Newark’s water infrastructure issues, we create an example and template we can follow when other cities suffer the same fate. Job Fair for Veterans: Introducing veterans to future employers  More than 100 veterans participated in my annual job fair on August 7th, the largest turnout we’ve had. Next year, we are going to look at larger facilities in our district to attract even more veterans and the companies that want to hire them. I was excited and grateful to give back to the men and women who have given so much to this country.        An Amazon representative discusses a future career with a veteran (8/7/2019)    Disaster Preparation and Emergency Response: Making sure we are prepared before, during and after a crisis  Last July, I wanted to see if our district was prepared to care for the underserved and most vulnerable people of our community during an emergency. We’ve seen how changes in our climate have increased the intensity of hurricanes and other natural disasters across the country. I don’t want what happened in Puerto Rico and New Orleans after they were struck by hurricanes to happen to us.  As chairman of the Subcommittee on Emergency Preparedness, Response and Recovery of the Committee on Homeland Security, I held a hearing on the matter on July 23rd called “Protecting Every Citizen: Assessing Emergency Preparedness for Underserved Populations.” The hearing was held at the Mac Mahon Student Center in Saint Peter’s University in Jersey City, so it could be accessible to my constituents. The hearing gave all of us a better understanding of the needs of underserved or vulnerable populations before, during, and after a crisis. It was extremely informative to hear from researchers, emergency responders, and community groups regarding how we plan for and meet the needs of our most vulnerable citizens before, during and after an emergency.   Increased Manufacturing Base: Creating more manufacturing jobs for New Jersey   No area of our economy has suffered job losses like America’s manufacturing base. In August, I spoke with members of a local Machinists’ union about how we can increase the opportunities for workers affected by these job losses. The event is important because it gives me an opportunity to listen as well as speak about possible solutions to the problems that face our workers and communities.        Rep. Payne speaks to Machinists' union (8/6/2019)    Legislation:  I have introduced or signed on to support several legislative initiatives. I wanted to give you a brief introduction to just a few of those measures.    Payment Choice: Giving residents the choice to pay in cash  Recently, I heard that more businesses are trying to get rid of cash as a form of payment for goods and services. Companies say it will make it easier for consumers. In truth, it will make it easier for companies to secure transactions, reduce the risk of crime, and speed up the process to serve more customers and make more money.  While I applaud the innovation behind these technological advances, we must remember that they aren’t always good for everyone. Nearly 25 percent of Americans don’t have access to digital forms of payments, including credit or debit cards. If we eliminate cash payments, we eliminate the only option for these consumers, including seniors and low-income residents, to buy their groceries and pay for other goods and services.    That is why I teamed with fellow New Jersey delegation member Rep. Chris Smith to introduce the “Payment Choice Act of 2019.” This bill would protect cash as a form of payment and require retailers to give consumers the choice to pay with credit cards, debit cards, or cash. The New Jersey State Legislature passed a similar law this year. I want consumers here and across the country to still be able to pay for items “the old-fashioned way.”  Return of Local and State Tax Deductions: Returning tax money to Americans  President Trump put a limit on the amount of state and local taxes that workers could deduct from their federal income tax.  His Tax Cuts and Jobs Act caps the State and Local Tax deduction, also known as the SALT deduction, to $10,000. Previously, there was no cap on deductions.  This is a major concern for me because it hit the middle and lower class residents in our community the hardest.  My constituents averaged more than $17,000 in SALT deductions last year.  On average, this current law will deny taxpayers an additional $7,000 per year in deductions.  I am working to repeal it, so the hard-working families of our 10th District can get that money back in their pockets.  Donald Payne, Sr. Colorectal Cancer Detection Act: Giving patients more payment options for treatment  My father, Congressman Donald M. Payne, Sr., died of colorectal cancer. Even though his cancer is a preventable disease, his cancer screening happened too late to catch it in time. Sadly, his case was not unique.        Donald Payne, Sr.    One out of every four Americans between the ages of 50 and 75 fail to get screened for this deadly disease. African-American men are particularly vulnerable. They are 20 percent more likely to get colorectal cancer and 45 percent more likely to die from it than white men. The American Cancer Society recently found that incidences and deaths due to colorectal cancer are even increasing in people younger than 50.  On June 4th, I testified before the House Ways and Means Committee about my bill, The Donald Payne, Sr. Colorectal Cancer Detection Act, because it would address this issue directly. Until recently, there were only two methods for colorectal cancer screening: colonoscopy and stool tests. Fortunately, there is a new test that can detect the disease with a simple blood draw. It can be done during a lunch hour in any facility that can draw blood. This test has the potential to significantly increase screening and save countless lives.  Another big issue with colon cancer is how to pay to fight it. Right now, Medicare will cover the screening, but not the treatment. If doctors find cancer cells and a growth, they must wait until the patient recovers from the screening to ask if they want the cancer removed. My bill would provide Medicare coverage for all FDA-approved, blood-based tests for colorectal cancer screening and the treatment, if cancer is found. That way we can prevent what happened to my father from happening to other fathers nationwide.  SAFE Act of 2019: Making our elections safer and easier for voters  Nothing is more important to democracy than faith in the electoral system. This is why Russia is so desperate to hack and infiltrate our social media. They want to create distrust in our elections and our democracy.  I signed on to the SAFE Act to strengthen the security of our elections and the trust in our democracy. The Act will address election security concerns through grant programs and requirements for voting systems and paper ballots. Thanks to this act, the Election Assistance Commission will have several new responsibilities. It must award grants to states to replace certain voting systems, carry out voting system security improvements, find the best way to design a ballot, write instructions for how to use that ballot, and test the ease of use for future ballots. I believe these actions will make our elections safer and easier for voters.  Aviation Humanitarian Crisis Act of 2019: Denying airlines the right to overcharge passengers during a crisis  In September, I introduced the Aviation Humanitarian Crisis Act of 2019, legislation to prevent airplane ticket price gouging before and after disasters. Climate change has increased the number of natural disasters dramatically. When they hit, area residents have few options available to take shelter and find safety, particularly when they are stuck on an island. During the time of Hurricane Maria, major airlines significantly raised their ticket prices in Puerto Rico. Many citizens who tried to evacuate before or after that disaster were trapped because they couldn’t afford the outrageous costs. My bill would prevent such airline abuse in the future for all Americans.  Raise the Wage Act of 2019: Giving minimum wage workers the raise they deserve  We need to give our workers a raise to show our appreciation for the hard work and effort they put in every day.  I co-sponsored this legislation because it would increase the federal minimum wage for regular employees over a seven-year period, tipped employees, and newly hired employees who are under the age of 20 years old.  The bill would increase the minimum wage every year for six years until it reached $15 per hour for regular employees.  It would provide other increases for disabled employees as well as employees who receive tips as a substantial portion of their wages.  A pay raise for these workers is long overdue.  This legislation would give employees a living wage and increase economic opportunities in their communities.         Gateway Project Update: Pushing to rebuild bridges and tunnels connecting New York and New Jersey        Gateway construction area    In September, the Committee on Transportation and Infrastructure held a hearing on federal grants for state infrastructure projects. The Gateway Program, which will replace decaying bridges and tunnels connecting New Jersey and New York, is the most critical infrastructure project in the country. The federal government promised to fund half of the total cost of the project and then began to backtrack on that promise.  That agreement should be honored. During the hearing, I questioned the acting Administrator of the Federal Transit Administration on why they are holding up federal funding for the Portal North Bridge project when it is ready to begin.  We need this project funded and these improvements made immediately.  Constituent Correspondence: Responding to Constituent Concerns  The thousands of letters I receive from constituents are extremely important to me.  During the time period from January 3 to September 30, 2019, I received 18,860 letters from constituents throughout the district about a variety of topics.      Constituent Letters based on City of Origin    I appreciate your letters and your concerns about issues that affect our district.  The most popular subjects were support for impeaching President Trump, support for the Dreamers and Promise Act, support for gun control regulation, support for the Climate Action Now Act, support for legislation to support the Green New Deal, support for the Equality Act, support for a ban on toxic pesticides, support for the Social Security Fairness Act, support for stronger rules against robocalls, and support for the Saving America's Pollinators Act.     In closing, it has been a busy time for legislative and district activities.  These are but a few of the actions I’ve taken during the last few months to improve the health and prosperity of all my constituents. I hope you are having a great Fall and let me know how I can be of service in the future.  Sincerely, Donald M. Payne, Jr. Member of Congress                                Join the conversation. subject: Weekly Recap
body: /* Client-specific Styles */ body { width: 100% !important; margin: 0px;} .ReadMsgBody { width: 100%; } .ExternalClass { width: 100%; display:block !important; } /* Force Hotmail to display emails at full width */ /* Reset Styles */ body { margin:0; padding: 0; } img { outline: none; text-decoration: none; max-width :100%;} br, strong br, b br, em br, i br { line-height: 100%; } h1, h2, h3, h4, h5, h6 { line-height: 100% !important; -webkit-font-smoothing: antialiased; } /*ly, tr#221562, add same margin as margin-block-start/end*/ h1{margin-top:0.67em;margin-bottom:0.67em;} h2{margin-top:0.83em;margin-bottom:0.83em;} h3{margin-top:1em;margin-bottom:1em;} h4{margin-top:1.33em;margin-bottom:1.33em;} h5{margin-top:1.67em;margin-bottom:1.67em;} h6{margin-top:2.33em;margin-bottom:2.33em;} table td, table tr { border-collapse: collapse; } p { margin-bottom: 1em; } table.menu-change a { text-decoration:none; } /* pre-header */ .preheader { display:none !important; visibility:hidden; mso-hide:all !important; font-size:0px; color:#ffffff; line-height:0px; max-height:0px; max-width:0px; opacity:0; overflow:hidden; }                                                         Friends, Well, it certainly has been a busy week in Washington. From continuing the appropriations process to introducing a bill that could help boost tourism in our state, there’s a lot to report! All of the details are here in my weekly newsletter, so keep scrolling for more information. And click here or the image below to watch my weekly video message. Be sure to forward this newsletter to a few friends to share the news!    Wild and Wonderful West Virginia  The New River Gorge is a special part of West Virginia and a real source of pride for our state. Whether it’s cheering on the BASE jumpers at Bridge Day, experiencing the thrill of world-class white water rafting, catching a glimpse into our state’s history and the unique geology of Appalachia, or taking in the beautiful panoramic views, the New River Gorge provides unlimited opportunities for thousands of visitors each year. Earlier this week, Senator Manchin and I introduced a bill that will help promote the beauty and historical significance of the New River Gorge by redesignating the National River to a National Park and Preserve. This redesignation will shine a new, brighter light on the New River Gorge and its many offerings—including hunting and fishing—to help drive tourism and spur the local and regional economy. Click here or the image below to learn more about this bill and what it means for our state.     Appropriations Update  This week, we continued working in the Appropriations Committee to consider several important government funding measures. A few days ago, the committee took action to provide resources that will keep our nation secure, our citizens safe, our economy thriving, and our environment protected. The bills we considered—and ultimately passed out of committee were:   Homeland Security Appropriations bill. Interior and Environment Appropriations bill. State and Foreign Operations Appropriations bill. Commerce, Justice, and Science Appropriations bill.  Not only were we able to pass all of these bills out of committee, but they include a lot of important funding for agencies and programs that have benefited our state and so many West Virginians—from the Katherine Johnson IV&V Center, NOAA in Fairmont, CJIS in Clarksburg, the Leetown Science Center or our three Coast Guard facilities in the Eastern Panhandle, to increased resources we dedicate to fighting opioids, monitoring PFAS contamination, improving cybersecurity, and securing our border. As a leader on this committee, I made sure that West Virginians’ best interests were always front and center; and I was proud that all of these measures reflect that. Click here to learn more.    Nominating the Next Generation of Leaders  As a U.S. senator, I have the great privilege of nominating young West Virginians for entry into our military academies. This afternoon, I hosted my fourth and final Academy Day event of the fall. I hope many of you were able to attend one of these, but if not, you can still learn more about this terrific opportunity on my website. My nomination application is available online here and is due on October 15, 2019, so check out the nominations webpage to learn more and feel free to reach out to my office if you have any questions along the way. Grant Updates  Making sure our communities have the resources they need is important to improving the lives of West Virginians and building a brighter future for our state. Whether it’s providing funding for transportation infrastructure or delivering resources to support education programs, my position on the Senate Appropriations Committee has empowered me to secure funds for important West Virginia priorities. This week, I was proud to announce several grants that will help communities and programs across the state. Learn more about each one below:   $32,559,963 for affordable housing for low-income families. $6,145,690 for health services in West Virginia. $5,839,934 for economic investments across the state. $1,056,000 for job training programs in West Virginia.  How Can We Help?  Whether you need help with a casework issue or have a question about scheduling a meeting at one of my offices, my staff and I are ready to assist you. Learn more about the services we offer at .  You can also submit your feedback and share your stories with me by visiting my “Share Your Stories” webpage here: /ShareYourStories. Social Media Recap           Join me on Facebook, Twitter, and Instagram for regular updates and photos. Sincerely, Shelley Moore CapitoUnited States Senator                                      Unsubscribe          Click here to open a plain text version of this email  Click here to forward this email Click here to open this e-mail in its own browser window

name: Congressman Richard Hudson
subject: To-Do List
body: Congressman Richard Hudson, 8th District of North Carolina *Friends,* *You can learn a lot about someone by looking at their to-do list. *Maybe you use your iPhone to keep track of things you need to get done. Or maybe you do it the old-fashioned way with a pen and paper. Regardless of how you keep track of it, your to-do list says a lot about your priorities. After last week, it is crystal clear the only thing on Washington Democrats' to-do list is "impeach President Donald Trump." *They've already spent countless time and at least $25 million in wasted tax dollars on the Mueller Report - which showed zero collusion. *They've already forced the House of Representatives to vote three separate times on impeachment - and each vote failed. They've already tried time and again to launch a partisan impeachment process in search of a crime, and last week was no different. Speaker Nancy Pelosi rushed to announce an "impeachment inquiry" based on unsubstantiated, anonymous and secondhand allegations. *This is unprecedented. *The White House released the transcript of the call in question and proved these rumors to be false - there was no quid pro quo and there were no laws broken on the call. *These partisan tactics and their one-item agenda won't improve your or your family's lives.* It's clear Congressional Democrats' hatred for our president far outweighs their desire to accomplish things in a bipartisan way. At the end of the day, you deserve better. There are countless items that should be on Congress's to-do list - like lowering drug prices, paying our troops, securing our border, improving our economy and updating our nation's infrastructure. The most frustrating thing about all this is we've made some great strides on important issues in spite of Washington Democrats' unwillingness to work together. Imagine what we could accomplish if bipartisanship was at the top of their to-do list! We've seen progress like a stronger economy and more opportunities for our nation's veterans.* According to data recently released by the Bureau of Labor Statistics (BLS), our country's 19.2 million veterans have a jobless rate of just 3.5% - a near record-low. *Good policies like tax reform and smarter regulations have led to a strong and stable economy that empowers veterans with the skills needed to transition to civilian life and find good-paying jobs. *Another big factor is a law I helped champion called the Forever GI Bill. *This was the largest expansion of GI Bill benefits in a decade, and it was a bipartisan effort - both Republicans and Democrats worked together to get it done for our nation's heroes. We've also seen progress like lower-income workers seeing more opportunities with higher wages. According to recent reports, the percentage of lower-income workers in America who found new job opportunities nearly tripled. *This progress is being driven by the longest economic expansion on record, and our workers are benefitting tremendously.* Finally, we've seen progress like lower health premiums for seniors. It was announced last week that on average, Medicare Advantage premiums in 2020 are expected to decline 23% from 2018. *And on top of that, plan choices, benefits and enrollment continue to increase.* In fact, the Medicare Advantage average monthly premium will be the lowest in the last 13 years for millions of people. *While this is all incredible progress, can you imagine how much better it would be if Washington Democrats joined Republicans - put the partisan impeachment charade aside - and worked in a bipartisan way on our nation's actual priorities?* As I said to my colleagues at an Energy and Commerce Committee hearing last week, our constituents don't care which party had which idea, they just want solutions. *Working towards bipartisan solutions that benefit our community will always be at the top of my to-do list.* *Until next week,* * [image = *Richard Hudson* *Member of Congress (NC-08)* [image = [link 1] [image = [link 2] [image = [link 3] [image = [link 4] [image = [link 5] [image = [link 6] [image = [link 7] [image = [link 8] ---------------------- footnotes ---------------------- [link 1] [link 2] [link 3] [link 4] [link 5] [link 6] [link 7] [link 8] Website: Office Locations: Washington, DC Office 2112 Rayburn House Office Building Washington, DC 20515 Phone: 202-225-3715 | Fax: (202) 225-4036 Hours: M-F 8:30am-6:00pm Concord Office 325 McGill Avenue, NW, Suite 500 Concord, NC 28027 Phone: (704) 786-1612 Fax: (704) 782-1004 Hours: M-F 8:30am-5:30pm Fayetteville Office 225 Green Street, Suite 202 Fayetteville, NC 28301 Phone: (910) 997-2070 Fax: (910) 817-7202 Hours: Tues/Thurs 8:30-5:30pm and by appointment Pinehurst Office Sandhills Community College Logan Building 3395 Airport Road, Suite 221 Pinehurst, NC 28374 (910) 246-5374 Hours: Tues/Thurs 8:30am-5:30pm and by appointment Privacy Policy: Unsubscribe:

name: Senator Lamar Alexander
subject: Latest from Lamar: The whole world sings with Tennessee
body: Latest from Lamar, Notes from the Senate Desk *Important news from this week:* - One of the most beautiful bridges in America, on one of the most beautiful drives in America, was named this week after Dean Stone - a good friend of mine and of the Great Smoky Mountains. The Dean Stone Bridge is located on the Foothills Parkway in the Smokies. - I introduced legislation that will make it easier for Tennessee students to attend college. This proposal includes legislation that simplifies the dreaded FAFSA - the student aid form that Governor Bill Haslam called "the single largest impediment to more students participating in Tennessee Promise." - The United States Senate confirmed President Trump's nominee to be Secretary of Labor, Eugene Scalia. *The whole world sings with Tennessee* [image = [link 1] *Click here [link 2]or on the above image to listen to my remarks.* I spoke on the Senate floor about Ken Burns' new film series, "Country Music," which concludes this week on PBS. The first two hours of 'Country Music' were about the recordings of hillbilly music in 1927 at the birthplace of country music in Bristol, where the Tennessee-Virginia state line runs down the middle of Main Street. The rest of the episodes wind through a community called Boogertown in the Smoky Mountains, where Dolly Parton was born, to the Grand Ole Opry in Nashville, to Beale Street in Memphis. As a senator from Tennessee, I must confess my bias, but Burns' new documentary shows that the whole world sings with Tennessee. If you haven't already, consider watching these great films and learn more about Tennessee's country music history. [image = I was at the Bluebird Cafe in Nashville not long ago and heard Will Duvall play a song he wrote called, "The King of Country Music." It was good to have him in Washington this week where I got to hear him play that song again, and talk about the Music Modernization Act [link 3] - bipartisan legislation I introduced and President Trump signed into law to ensure songwriters are paid fairly. *Visitors to the Foothills Parkway will know Dean Stone's legacy* [image = If you want to see the best view of the highest mountains in the eastern United States, you'll drive the Foothills Parkway. The scene is so magnificent that it surprises even those of us who have grown up admiring the Smokies. This parkway is also home to one of the most beautiful bridges in America, and, this week, it was named after a good friend of mine and of the Great Smoky Mountains - Dean Stone. For those who don't know Dean, he was the long time editor of *The Daily Times* in Maryville, and a lifetime advocate for the Great Smoky Mountains. Dean did as much as anybody to make the Foothills Parkway happen. He enthusiastically celebrated the Great Smoky Mountains National Park and was the best historian of what I like to call the "Oak Ridge Corridor" that we ever knew. As East Tennesseans know, we all love stories about ourselves, and Dean could tell them. It is now my hope that the naming of this bridge will tell the story of Dean Stone. [image = It was good to visit with some folks from Nissan this week. The auto industry has done more for our state the last forty years than anything else and has been the number one driver of higher family incomes. *Introducing legislation to make it easier for Tennesseans to attend college* This week, I introduced a long-term solution to permanently provide funding for Minority Serving Institutions, including the six Historically Black Colleges and Universities in Tennessee. This solution is part of a package of eight bipartisan higher education bills drafted by 35 senators - 20 Democrat, 15 Republican. This package of bills will make it easier for millions of students to get a college education by simplifying the Federal Application for Student Aid (FAFSA) - which according to former governor, Bill Haslam, is "the single biggest impediment to more students enrolling in Tennessee Promise." It would also provide Pell grants to parole-eligible prisoners, allow Pell grants to be used for short-term programs and increase the maximum Pell grant award. *Confirming Eugene Scalia to serve as U.S. Secretary of Labor* [image = This week, the Senate labor committee I chair approved the nomination of Eugene Scalia, President Trump's nominee to serve as Secretary of Labor. And Thursday, his nomination was confirmed by the full Senate. Mr. Scalia has the skills to help continue to grow our economy and help workers gain the skills they need to succeed in today's workplace. I am glad we have a well-qualified Secretary of Labor, so we can continue to create a strong economy for Tennesseans. *Read below about three of the five funding bills approved this week by the U.S. Senate Appropriations Committee, on which I serve, and the impact they will have on Tennessee:* *Approving legislation that funds the border wall the right way* I support the president on border security, and I commend him for pursuing funding for the border wall in the right way - by asking the Congress for funding, allowing Congress to consider his request, and working with Congress to achieve a result. Congress has approved, for the last four presidents - Obama, Clinton, W. Bush and H.W. Bush - on a bipartisan basis, 654 miles of physical barrier - that's wall - along our almost 2,000 mile southern border. The bill approved by the Senate Appropriations Committee this week continues the work to secure our border by including $5 billion for the border wall system. When a president, elected by the people of the United States, has a legitimate objective, we in Congress should bend over backwards to try to meet that objective if we want a result, regardless of whatever you may think of him or her. This bill is now ready to be considered by the full United States Senate. *Approving more money to reduce the maintenance backlog at the Great Smoky Mountain**s **National Park* The Senate Appropriations Committee took a promising step to reduce the maintenance backlog at our national parks, including at the Great Smoky Mountains National Park. The funding approved this week will help restore the campgrounds, trails,and roads in what Ken Burns calls "America's best idea" - our national park system. The next step is to pass the Restore Our Parks Act [link 4], bipartisan legislation I introduced that would be the biggest help to our parks in a generation. Also included in this bill is money to help Tennessee protect its waterways from invasive Asian carp. Asian carp are aggressively invading Tennessee waterways and threaten biodiversity, the economy,and sporting from Memphis to Chattanooga. While the Tennessee Wildlife Resources Agency is working to combat Asian carp in the Tennessee-Cumberland Sub-basin, additional federal resources are needed. I was glad to support the $25 million in funding for the U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service to combat this issue and protect commercial fishing and our nation's waters. *Approving funding to help Tennessee fight the opioid crisis* The Senate Appropriations Committee also approved a funding bill that provides $505 million for U.S. Department of Justice (DOJ) grants to help states, including Tennessee, tackle the opioid crisis. States could use these grants to help fund their drug courts, educational efforts, law enforcement programs, recovery programs, and treatment programs. Our law enforcement officers witness almost daily the tragedy associated with the opioid crisis, which effects virtually every American community. This funding will help give them the support they need to keep our communities safe. I was also glad to see that the $12 million I requested to fund meth lab cleanup was included in this bill. This will allow DOJ to continue to assist states in the very difficult and often dangerous efforts to clean up meth labs. According to Tennessee Bureau of Investigation, between 2002 and 2012, Tennessee law enforcement agencies discovered more than 16,000 meth labs. While lab seizures are down, meth abuse continues to be a serious and deadly problem across Tennessee. [image = It was good meeting with Tennesseans this Tuesday with my colleague and friend Senator Blackburn! If you'll be in Washington on a Tuesday while the Senate is in session, we would love for you to attend Tennessee Tuesday. Sign up here [link 5]. *Below are some articles from this week I thought you would enjoy:* Sen. Lamar Alexander: Congress is trying to protect patients from surprise medical bills [link 6] The Wilson Post: Column by Senator Lamar Alexander: Legislation gets money to deserving songwriters [link 7] Maryville Daily Times: Ode to an advocate; Dean Stone Bridge dedicated on Foothills Parkway [link 8] Focus on what comes next instead of what went wrong. *#271 in Lamar Alexander's Little Plaid Book* ---------------------- footnotes ---------------------- [link 1] [link 2] [link 3] [link 4] [link 5] [link 6] [link 7] [link 8] Contact Information: Website: Office Location: Washington, DC Office 455 Dirksen Office Building, Washington, DC 20510 Phone: (202) 224-4944 | Fax: (202) 228-3398 Privacy Policy: Unsubscribe:

In Article I, Section 2, the Founders declared that the, “House of Representatives shall chuse their Speaker and other Officers; and shall have the sole Power of Impeachment.”        It is noteworthy that the founders mandated that Congress protect and preserve the balance of powers before, designating congressional authority to oversee tax and trade, or to address the question of war and peace.         This does not mean that Congress will forsake our other duties and responsibilities.  Please find below some updates on appropriations, gun violence, the Year of Return, and global peace efforts which you may find of interest.     Keep the faith,   /s  John Lewis  Member of Congress      Appropriations  The House and Senate adopted H.R. 4378, the continuing resolution (CR) to fund the Federal Government until November 21st.  The text of the H.R. 4378 is available here, and a division-by-division summary of the legislation is available here.  The CR passed the House by a bipartisan vote of 301 to 123 on September 19, 2019.  The Senate adopted the bill by a bipartisan vote of 81 to 16 on September 26, 2019.  It is expected to become public law in the next few days.  This bill will prevent a government shutdown and give Congress more time to resolve outstanding funding issues in the fiscal year 2020 appropriations bill.  Gun Violence  Similar to many people around the country, I was heartbroken by the waves of gun violence during the month of August.   On Wednesday, September 25, 2019, I accompanied gun violence survivors and those who lost their loved ones in requesting a meeting with the Senate Majority Leader on the necessity of considering H.R. 8, the Bipartisan Background Checks Act, and other common-sense House-passed bills to stem the plague of gun violence in our nation.  In the past two weeks, I chaired two congressional hearings to address gun violence that plagues our community:   The first hearing examined how the tax code subsidizes hate.  We heard moving testimony from courageous witnesses that included Mr. Jeff Binkley, from Metro Atlanta.  In 2018, his beautiful daughter Maura Binkley was killed by a misogynist who hated women. Earlier this week, I held another hearing which examined the health consequences and costs of gun violence.  Dr. David Satcher, MD, PhD, former Surgeon General, Director of the Centers for Disease Control, and Founding Director and Senior Advisor of the Satcher Health Leadership Institute, Morehouse School of Medicine testified.              During the bipartisan, public discussion Members seemed to agree on the importance of research and the overwhelming cost of gun violence to our health systems.  The response to the moving witness testimony made me feel hopeful about the prospect for bipartisan, congressional solutions to reduce mass shootings and gun violence.   400 Years: The Year of Return          As you know, this year marks the 400th year anniversary of 400 years of African American History.  In preparation for this moment in history, I was proud to cosponsor legislation to create the 400 Years of African American History Commission.        In July, I joined Rep. Bobby Scott (VA) in introducing a bill to extend the commission until 2022.  We also continue to offer amendments to increase federal funding to support the Commission’s important work.  I will continue to advocate for the highest level of funding for this important work.      This summer I had the honor to travel to Ghana as part of a congressional delegation to commemorate the Year of Return to Ghana.   It was one of the most moving and emotional visits of my life and reminded me of how Ghana’s first President Osagyefo Dr Kwame Nkrumah and African liberation movements inspired our efforts to fight injustice here in the United States.  International Peace Day       In 1981, the United Nations (UN) declared the opening day of the UN General Assembly, which falls on the third Tuesday of September, as the International Day of Peace.  In 2001, the UN officially designated September 21st as the annual day of recognizing and supporting global peace design, building, and keeping initiatives.  This year’s theme is “Climate Action for Peace.”       It is not too late for faith leaders, teachers, students, artists, and communities to participate in the global celebration for peace.  Until October 2, 2019, participants may upload and record their participation in the United States Institute of Peace’s(USIP) #PeaceDayChallenge.  If you are planning a visit to Washington, D.C., you may also set aside time to explore the Peace Trail on the National Mall.   Keeping the faith,   John LewisMember of Congress                       Washington, DC Office  343 Cannon House Office Building Washington, DC 20515 Phone: (202) 225-3801 Fax: (202) 225-0351   Atlanta Office The Equitable Building100 Peachtree St., N.W. #1920Atlanta, GA 30303Phone: (404) 659-0116Fax: (404) 331-0947               You have received this e-mail because you are enrolled in our mailing list. Fox Foundation          RiSE Center at the University of Maine         American Occupational Therapy Association of Maine          Scenes from Capitol Coffee Every Wednesday morning the Senate is in session from 9:00 a.m. to 10:00 a.m., I am pleased to host “Capitol Coffee with Angus”, an opportunity for Maine people in the area to stop by my office, say hello, and talk about issues important to them.   Along with coffee, we are proud to provide homemade blueberry bread made with real Maine blueberries!                                                                                                                                                                    A Note from Angus: Maine Communities on Display   The above picture says a lot about Maine. As we all know, there was a community tragedy in Farmington this month when a building exploded, apparently from a propane leak. The building housed a program for people with developmental disabilities. One firefighter was killed and seven others were injured.  One small positive was that the building was unoccupied at the time of the blast, or the death toll would have been much higher. What this scene symbolizes is how we come together in times of need. The trucks are parked at the entrance to Farmington where the explosion took place, but if you look carefully you can see that each comes from a different neighboring town—Jay on the right and Wilton on the left.  People in Washington often ask me what’s so special about Maine, and I always have a one-word answer—community. In many ways, Maine has the feel of a big small town (with very long streets) where people still know and care about one another, like in Farmington this week—where a brave group of first responders put their lives on the line for the rest of us. Public Actions, not Private Assurances, Will Help Repair US-Saudi relations     Trip to the Middle East with Senator Todd Young: At the beginning of September, Senator Todd Young and I traveled to Oman, the United Arab Emirates, and Saudi Arabia. In Saudi Arabia, we met with Crown Prince Mohammad bin Salman. During our conversation with the Crown Prince, we made it clear that public actions – not private assurances – will repair the US/Saudi relationship.  Saudi Arabia is a key counterweight to Iran, and as recent attacks on Saudi oil fields show, instability in the region ripples out to potentially disturb global peace and endanger American lives. Saudi Arabia is a valued security partner – but not one we will support at any cost. Our visit showed positive advancements, but if the Crown Prince truly wishes to modernize his nation, there are a number of issues – from women’s rights to the Kingdom’s conduct in Yemen to the murder of journalist Jamal Khashoggi – that must be addressed quickly and completely.   Senator King aboard the USS Gonzalez (built at Bath Iron Works)  Senator Young and I wrote an op-ed as a reflection of our trip to the Middle East. You may have first read it when it appeared in  Defense News.  On Lobster Day, Celebrating our Industry and Addressing the Threats   I wrote the following op-ed celebrating National Lobster Day. It appeared in the Ellsworth American.   This week, we celebrate one of Maine’s most famous residents — and no, I’m not talking about Stephen King or the couple who say “buttery flaky crust” in the Dysart’s commercial. Actually, this week marks National Lobster Day, when we celebrate not only our favorite crustacean, but all the men and women who help this industry and our state thrive.  Folks from away might not understand why we are celebrating the lobster, but Maine people know that this shellfish isn’t just a delicious meal — it’s a vital part of our state’s economy, supporting communities up and down our coast. Maine people also know that even as we celebrate lobsters, this industry is facing serious challenges — from well-intentioned but harmful potential regulations, to poorly designed foreign policy emanating from Washington, to the looming threat of warming waters due to climate change. So today, more than any other time in the past, it’s important to emphasize the value of this economic driver, and push back on the threats it faces.  One of the most pressing concerns facing our lobster industry is the danger of potentially misguided federal regulations to protect right whales. Now, let’s be clear: everyone, including lobstermen, wants to protect this endangered species. We just want to make sure we’re making changes based on sound data; and at this point, it is not clear that Maine’s lobster fishery is a significant contributor to right whale deaths. The possible changes threaten livelihoods and lives by calling for expensive and dangerous new equipment configurations. Even worse, these changes would disproportionately affect Maine lobstermen while not holding Canadian fisheries to the same standards.  I’ve been pushing hard with my Maine colleagues, asking everyone from the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA) to the President himself to make sure we’re not moving forward based on incomplete data. I even made the argument directly to NOAA officials at an Ellsworth scoping session last month, where more than a hundred concerned people packed into the high school auditorium on a beautiful Tuesday night. The message from the community was unified: we’re prepared to make reasonable changes to protect this species, but show us the data.  These potential regulations are a serious problem on the horizon, but there is an existing Washington policy that is already harming our industry — the President’s trade war. China was the fastest growing market for Maine lobsters, and lobster dealers spent a lot of time and money building relationships with Chinese buyers. But that all changed when the trade war started. Lobsters were one of the first products targeted by China for retaliation after the President started imposing his tariffs, and this has had a severe impact: through the first six months of this year, American lobster exports to China declined by more than 80 percent, and Canadian businesses have already seized the opportunity.  Maine people are paying the price for this reckless trade war. The drop in exports is costing jobs and undermining our state’s ability to build relationships in the Chinese market. Despite this pain, the administration refuses to compensate our industry while it provides bailouts for soybean farmers in Iowa. This is wrong — Maine people did not start this trade war. They deserve to be made whole.  Of course, neither of these concerns will matter if there are no lobsters to catch. That is the threat posed by the warming of waters due to climate change. The Gulf of Maine is the second fastest-warming portion of the world’s oceans, a fact that will dramatically alter ecosystems and drive lobster populations farther north. We’ve already seen once-stable lobster fisheries in Rhode Island and Massachusetts collapse; we don’t want Maine to be next. I’m working hard in the Senate to address climate change, through everything from energy efficiency to renewable energies. It’s the right thing to do for our planet and for our economy.  The men and women who drive our lobster industry make vital contributions to Maine. They’re our lobstermen and lobster processors and dealers, who pull the lobsters out of the water and ship them across the state, country, and world; they work in our tourism industry that is boosted by this world-renowned fishery, and in our restaurants that serve unparalleled products fresh from the sea; they are our neighbors and our friends. When we celebrate National Lobster Day, what we’re really celebrating are our people and communities who help make Maine so special.  So, to all of you who make this vital sector of Maine go: thank you. Our state wouldn’t be the same without you, and I’ll keep working to defend your livelihoods, in ways both big and small (think emoji-sized), from anyone and anything that interferes with your work. Scenes from Maine & D.C    This past Wednesday, September 25, was National Lobster Day – a day to celebrate not only Maine’s most iconic industry, but also all the important people who work this fishery each and every day. During our Wednesday morning Capitol Coffee, we offered a traditional Maine lobster egg bake (along with our usual blueberry bread and Maine coffee!).    Later in the day, I was proud to honor the new home for the Maine Lobsterman statue in Washington, fittingly located right off Maine Avenue SW.            I shared a great morning at the New England Council in Southern Maine, where we discussed some of my work with local leaders and heard about what they believe are the most pressing issues facing our state. It is a privilege to represent Maine people in the Senate, and I take my responsibility to speak on their behalf in Washington seriously.         Climate change is one of my top priorities, and energy efficiency is an often overlooked but major tool to cut emissions; the cleanest (and cheapest!) kilowatt is the one we don’t use. This month, I spoke at the Alliance To Save Energy's event about how we can work together towards a cleaner future.         Legislative Update          Worked to make the Annotated Constitution available to all Americans. To commemorate National Constitution Day, I sent a letter to the Library of Congress, urging to make the Constitution Annotated easily available to all Americans. The Constitution Annotated is compiled by the Library of Congress and details how the Supreme Court has interpreted each provision of the Constitution. Read more HERE. Advocated for family businesses in the logging industry. The Maine delegation led a bipartisan group of 16 members of Congress calling on the Department of Labor (DOL) to take action. Specifically, weurged DOL to grant a regulatory exemption that would allow 16- and 17-year-olds to learn the logging trade under parental supervision. Read more HERE. Named to the 2019 NDAA Conference Committee to advocate for Maine and National priorities. I was appointed as a conferee to the House of Representatives and Senate conference committee charged with reconciling differences between the two chambers’ competing versions of the 2020 National Defense Authorization Act (NDAA).        Good News For Maine   $2 million for Gulf of Maine Lobster research This investment will support a range of research projects to advance our understanding of the American lobster as well as to support a regional lobster extension program. The projects being funded will address the following priorities: increased understanding of life history parameters, including migration, growth, and maturity; larval studies and early biology; spatial distribution; and socio-economic lessons learned from Southern New England as they pertain to Georges Bank and the Gulf of Maine.   $2 million to revitalize Maine's forest products industry. The Northern Border Regional Commission (NBRC) has awarded $2,004,673 to East Millinocket Industrials, Maine Development Foundation, and Northern Forest Center. $500,000 for rural economic development. The Economic Development Administration (EDA), a bureau within the U.S. Department of Commerce, has awarded $446,757 in federal funding to the Maine Development Foundation (MDF) to support and assist the economic efforts of rural Maine communities who have been negatively affected by mill closures.   In the News   Maine Public (Gratz) Angus King: Donald Trump Should 'Take A Deep Breath' Before Blaming Iran For Saudi Attack Reuters (Zengerle) Activists push U.S. Congress to pass Hong Kong bill CNN (Liptak) Trump's struggle with Iran policy continues without Bolton replacement The Hill (Kheel) Senators grill Army, Air Force nominees on military funding for border wall  Thanks for subscribing to my monthly newsletter! I was so glad to hear about your favorite parks in New Mexico last month and I hope you have the opportunity to visit them this weekend. As New Mexicans, we know how important our state’s natural beauty and resources are to our way of life. National parks provide an economic boost to our communities, with more than 100 million dollars of economic output and over 1,000 jobs in New Mexico alone. Hiking, camping, and our historic sacred sites are part of who we are as New Mexicans, and hundreds of thousands of people come to our national parks every year to experience our culture.  The League of Conservation Voters gave me the honor of recognizing my work protecting our public lands in my role as the Chairwoman of the Subcommittee on National Parks, Forests, and Public Lands. Last week, the U.S. House of Representatives passed legislation to protect public lands in Alaska from destructive drilling. Recently, I held hearings on the Chaco Cultural Heritage Area Protection Act to protect Chaco Canyon here in New Mexico. I will continue to fight and care for our public lands so future generations can enjoy them as we do now. In 2015, more than six-hundred seventy thousand children spent time in our foster care system. One out of every twenty-five families with children have an adoptive child. Families adopt for a number of reasons, but whatever the reason, it is a beautiful and selfless decision.  Joining the U.S. House of Representatives has its rewards—one of them being the people I come across that I normally wouldn’t outside of this job. This year, I had the privilege of nominating Kevin and Megan Kinney for the Angels in Adoption Award. Kevin serves as a Highway Patrolman and Megan is an accomplished author and stay at home mother. After they had their oldest daughter Emma, they felt called by God to participate in South Dakota’s foster care program. Soon after joining the foster care system, they brought three sisters—Angel, Alicia, and Kylee—into their home. All of the girls were under the age of three when Kevin and Megan became their foster parents. The Kinney’s instantly fell in love with their new additions and decided to take the big step and adopt them, making Angel, Alicia, and Kylee permanent members of the Kinney clan. Even though the Kinney’s knew it would be an adventure to adopt all three young children, they understood the importance of not separating the bond of sisterhood. Every child deserves to be a part of a family that loves and supports them. Stories like these hit close to home for me and my staff. In preparing this week’s column, I asked one of my staffers, who is adopted, for input. He was born to an 18-year-old girl out of wedlock. Unable to afford a child at the time, she decided to put him up for adoption. He was adopted by a great family that lives just down the road from me in Mitchell. He is forever grateful for his parents’ leap of faith and for his birthmother in allowing him to experience the full life he is living today. Adoption creates a ripple effect of love. It’s an antidote to agonizing, painful situations. My staffer described it as the gift of life.   The Kinney’s are more than deserving of the Angels in Adoption Award. Folks ranging from Muhammad Ali to First Lady Laura Bush have been recipients of this award. I’m proud to partner with an organization like Angels in Adoption which celebrates families, individuals, and organizations across the country that have made a remarkable contribution to children in need of families. Please join me in thanking the Kinney’s, and the rest of our adoptive and foster families in South Dakota, for stepping up when children need them the most.                      Washington, DC 1508 Longworth HOBWashington, DC 20515Phone: (202) 225-2801    Aberdeen Office 304 6th Avenue SEAberdeen, SD 57401Phone: (605) 622-1060   Rapid City Office 2525 W Main StreetSuite 310Rapid City, SD 57702Phone: (605) 646-6454    Sioux Falls Office 300 North Dakota AvenueSuite 314Sioux Falls, SD 57104Phone: (605) 275-2868        Please do not reply to this email; this address is not monitored.
